White House officials oppose the Health and Human Services Department's efforts to set up a uniform, national food-labeling system that would supersede state rules, said the sources, speaking Thursday on condition of anonymity. The food industry has been lobbying strongly for the administration to propose national labeling regulations that could not be disturbed by the states, although California is the only one that currently might be affected. ``We have a national food system,'' said Roger Coleman, a spokesman for the National Food Processors Association. ``We need to have a free flow of these goods throughout the country, and to avoid consumer confusion we need to have a national, uniform system of food labeling.'' Legislation pending in the House and the Senate would pre-empt any state nutrition-labeling requirements. In announcing last March that the Food and Drug Administration would propose food-labeling changes, HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan said states would be able to add to the federal requirements. But Sullivan recently sent to the Office of Management and Budget proposed regulations for uniform national rules, government and industry sources familiar with the regulations said. The department had hoped to announce the regulations and publish them in the Federal Register next week. However, OMB officials argue the philosophical principles of federalism in opposing pre-emption of state rules, the sources said. ``There is opposition from a number of agencies,'' one source said. OMB spokeswoman Dede Spitznagel said officials at the agency could not comment on the HHS proposal because it was still under review. It was not clear whether the disagreement over pre-emption would hold up the regulations. One source said, ``I think it will resolve in the near future.'' Jeff Nedelman, a spokesman for the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said the food industry supports labeling regulations as long as they are applied uniformly across the country, as are labeling rules for meat and poultry. Food industry officials have argued that if states are allowed to add their own labeling requirements on top of federal labeling rules, food companies could face as many as 50 different sets of requirements. ``There is neither a medical nor a health reason why consumers in one state need different health information about products than people living anywhere else in the country,'' Nedelman said. Without uniformity nationwide, consumers would be confused and manufacturers might decide not to market their products in states where requirements varied from the majority, he said. California could be affected most directly by a federal pre-emption, because that state's Proposition 65 allows officials to require consumer warnings on products they deem to pose a risk of birth defects or cancer. The cancer-warning is being challenged in court. However, some observers say the California initiative would not be affected because the regulations being drafted apply only to nutrition content. Other pending regulations, though, would cover health messages or claims, and some believe that if federal nutrition labeling is deemed pre-emptive, that will be extended to health messages as well.

DOC.HEAD: `Watch List' of Foreigners Barred from U.S. Turns Out to Be Long
DOC.TEXT: The government's list of foreigners barred from the country for political reasons is far longer than previously thought, and most names were added since the Reagan administration, documents show. Details of the so-called ``lookout book'' emerged in documents released in response to a lawsuit brought by a prize-winning Colombian journalist who was turned back at a New York airport four years ago. The list, previously estimated by immigration lawyers to have some 40,000 names, has 353,324 entries from 146 countries, territories and other areas. More than two-thirds of the entries appear to come after 1980. Officials cautioned there was no way of knowing how many individuals were on the list, because some of the names are entered more than once. Assistant U.S. Attorney Chad Vignola, who handled the government's case, said that an estimate by a lawyer for the journalist, Patricia Lara, of more than 300,000 individuals is ``simply wrong.'' Nevertheless, ``It's the first time that concrete dimension has been given to the magnitude and scope of this lookout system,'' Lara's lawyer, Arthur C. Helton, said Thursday. U.S. District Judge John M. Walker, ruling last September in Lara's case, ordered the list turned over to her lawyers. He said the names of people on the list should remain secret to protect them. The list, called the National Automated Immigration Lookout System, was turned over to Helton earlier this month after more legal wrangling. In the past, the list usually came to light only when the government excluded famous people, including many whose writings and movies were widely available here at the time the artists themselves were barred. They included Nobel laureates Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Pablo Neruda, authors Graham Greene, Doris Lessing and Carlos Fuentes, French actor Yves Montand and former Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith. The entries on the list date to 1904 but the vast bulk of entries come under three sections of the 1952 McCarren-Walter Act. The sections roughly cover security risks, political beliefs, and subversion and violent activities. Most of the individuals _ at least 341,000 entries _ were barred because of their political beliefs, according to Helton, an attorney at the New York-based Lawyer's Committee for Human Rights. ``I think the disclosure is astounding both in terms of the magnitude of the listings and the high level of current denial,'' Helton said. He said that more than two-thirds of the book's entries _ 238,140 _ were made since 1980, and 4,399 in the first three months of 1990. The increased number of exclusions came at a time when both Congress and the courts were trying to narrow the scope of who could be excluded, Helton said. That goal was achieved in February, when President Bush signed a law prohibiting the exclusion of visitors on the basis of political belief in the case of anarchists, Communists, or adherents to totalitarian beliefs. Many immigration lawyers claim that the State Department is ignoring the spirit of the law and continuing to exclude aliens for political reasons. The government is not obliged to justify its exclusion decisions. In the most recent entry on the ``watch list,'' for example, dated March 1, the State Department excluded 46 people under the political provision. A State Department spokesman, Philip Covington, acknowledged that exclusion decisions have been subjective. ``Obviously, the law is interpreted in different ways at different times,'' he said. The highest number of exluded visitors were from China, with 106,777 entries. The Soviet Union was in the middle range, with 33,064. Ms. Lara, a 1980 graduate of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, came to New York in 1986 to receive the Maria Moors Cabot Prize, awarded for advancing inter-American understanding and freedom of information. She was detained at Kennedy International Airport, her visa was revoked and she was sent back to Colombia without a hearing. Authorities alleged she was linked to a Colombian terrorist group. Ms. Lara maintained she was barred for writing articles critical of U.S. policy in Central America.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Dropping Plan for Limited Clinics
DOC.TEXT: The administration is abandoning plans for limited-service methadone clinics that provide the drug but little else to heroin addicts waiting for an opening in a comprehensive treatment program. Officials at the Health and Human Services Department decided to withdraw the ``no-frills'' proposal because of hefty criticism, Mona Brown, a spokeswoman for the National Institute on Drug Abuse, said Thursday. ``The comments and testimony (at public hearings) didn't support going ahead,'' she said. ``We are rescinding those regulations.'' Interim methadone maintenance clinics were proposed by the institute and the Food and Drug Administration to help curb the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug users, who can transmit the virus when they share needles. In some cities, drug addicts have to wait for six months or more to get into a comprehensive methadone treatment program that provides support and counseling. Without the regulations, however, drug abuse treatment centers can still apply for a waiver to allow them to set up an interim clinic and dispense methadone on an outpatient basis, Brown said. Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City is the only health-care facility currently operating an interim clinic under a waiver. The proposed regulations would have eliminated the waiver process and made it easier for treatment centers to operate interim programs. In these programs, heroin addicts unable to get into a comprehensive program can get methadone daily at outpatient clinics and from mobile medical units. But critics disputed the effectiveness of methadone treatment to wean addicts from heroin, and some feared that because of tight budgets the limited-service programs would gradually replace comprehensive programs. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control who opposed the proposed regulations, praised the move by the Health and Human Services Department. ``What addicts need and seek is comprehensive treatment allowing integration into a fully productive life with education, job skills and emotional support to stay drug free,'' Rangel said in a statement. ``Just sending addicts back into the street with a different drug is no answer,'' he said. ``Now I hope we begin developing a strong comprehensive national treatment strategy.'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan told Rangel's panel last August that methadone programs were ``not ideal ... but this we feel is better than nothing for those individuals.'' However, studies by the congressional General Accounting Office and the Drug Enforcement Administration questioned the wisdom of the department's plan. They cited continued drug abuse by many patients in methadone treatment and illegal diversion of the drug.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Developer Takes Fifth Amendment
DOC.TEXT: Texas developer Leonard Briscoe refused to answer questions before congressional investigators looking into the housing scandals, citing his constitutional right against self-incrimination. Briscoe, of Fort Worth, on Thursday became the sixth witness to invoke his Fifth Amendment right in spurning questions from the House Government Operations subcommittee on housing. He is the first such witness, however, who was not a former official of the scandal-plagued Department of Housing and Urban Development. Former HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., now the object of a special prosecutor's investigation, was among those who would not answer questions. Subcommittee Chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said he intended to provide special prosecutor Arlin Adams a letter requesting that his inquiry be expanded ``and setting forth in detail evidentiary support.'' Briscoe contended that his attorney had not been given enough time to prepare for the testimony and had been refused a delay in his appearance under subpoena. But Lantos said Briscoe had initially agreed to testify voluntarily and waited too long to obtain a new lawyer after his first one withdrew because of a conflict of interest. He posed five questions to Briscoe, mostly about his relationship with Lance Wilson, a former top HUD official who later became a housing consultant and was involved in several projects receiving lucrative HUD grants. Briscoe declined to answer each question. His attorney, Irvin B. Nathan, angrily denounced Lantos outside the hearing room. ``The chairman's conduct today clearly indicates it was not a fair hearing,'' Nathan said. DuBois Gilliam, a former deputy assistant secretary of HUD now serving a prison sentence, testified under immunity last month and named Briscoe in describing how lucrative federal housing and community development grants were steered to favored developers. Wilson was involved in four low-income housing projects in Florida and Texas in which he provided assistance or was paid consulting fees or given a percentage interest. One of the questions Briscoe refused to answer was why he gave Wilson a 15 percent interest in one project in Riviera Beach, Fla. Outside the hearing room, Briscoe denied making any improper payments or gifts to Wilson or Gilliam. Wilson is a former executive assistant to Pierce and has also invoked his constitutional right to avoid testifying.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves 1990 Farm Bill With Support From Key Republicans
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 farm bill goes to the Senate without the boost in financial guarantees many Democrats wanted to give farmers, but with a promise of support from key Republicans. ``There's not everything in here that every member would want and I appreciate that,'' Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said Thursday after the panel approved the bill. But he said the measure ``makes sense for farmers and consumers and is within the budget.'' Leahy had worked particularly hard to strengthen environmental provisions, including research to help farmers reduce chemical additives, and revise agricultural trade policies to better assist poor countries and governments moving toward democracy. A section that would protect private forest land also was added to the measure that sets farm policy for five years. The estimated cost of the price supports over the life of the bill is $55 billion. Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana, the committee's ranking Republican, said both he and Senate GOP leader Bob Dole of Kansas would support the measure on the floor. The House Agriculture Committee finished work on its version of the bill last week with floor action expected early in July. The committee approved the bill on a 15-4 vote, with Sens. Thomas Daschle, D-S.D., Max Baucus, D-Mont., Howell Heflin, D-Ala., and Slade Gorton, R-Wash. opposing it. Lugar had said he would cause trouble for the legislation in the Senate if the Democrats raised subsidies and moved the bill out of committee on a party line vote. The Democrats have a 10-9 majority on the panel. ``In order to get something to the floor, we had to make some compromises,'' said Sen. Thomas Harkin, D-Iowa, who said he would fight to increase target prices and loan rates once the Senate debate begins. ``Senator Lugar and the Republicans dug in their heels.'' Heflin said target prices won't keep up with inflation under the legislation and should have been higher. Baucus and Daschle also wanted higher supports. Gorton said he voted against the bill because of its soybean program and the committee's ``refusal to reform secondary programs like honey, wool and mohair.'' The plan on loan rates accepted by the committee gives the agriculture secretary two options. The loan rate is the amount of money the government pays the farmer in advance to cover production, using the expected crops as collateral. If the market price is lower than the loan rate, the farmer can forfeit his crops to the government instead of paying back the loan. The secretary's first option would be to make loans under existing formulas, though never dipping below the 1990 level. He would not be able to activate the so-called Findley provision _ a method used to reduce loan rates to bring U.S. prices for commodities in line with the world market. The secretary's second option allows him to use the Findley provision, but requires that he pay the farmer in advance three quarters of a cent for every penny he reduces the loan rate. This would be in addition to any other advance payments and would have to be repaid by the farmer nine months after the start of the marketing year. If the secretary selects the second option he would have to give the House and Senate agriculture committees an explanation why, based on budget implications, farm income, orderly marketing, price competitiveness and avoidance of excess stocks. Acceptance of this loan rate provision was viewed as a concession by the Republicans, but barely better than nothing by the Democrats. Some other provisions of the bill: _Milk price supports at a minimum of $10.10 per hundred pounds, the current rate. _A soybean marketing loan rate of $5.50 per bushel. _If malting barley prices exceed feed barley prices by more than 22 cents, the excess above 22 cents would not be considered in establishing the barley deficiency payment. _For every 10 percent decrease in final deficiency payments that result from an increase in prices, the agriculture secretary would give 2 percentage points of the decrease back to the farmer.

DOC.HEAD: Holsteins Break Loose
DOC.TEXT: Maybe it was the coming of summer. Whatever the reason, 150 to 200 Holstein cows broke loose from a farm and strolled into this suburban community south of Seattle. The cows fanned out after escaping from Joe Neff's Auburn farm just before midnight Wednesday. But most headed south along the Valley Freeway. ``I couldn't believe it. They busted out of the barn and broke through a half-inch-thick steel gate,'' Neff said. The cows didn't make it to downtown Kent or Auburn but their proximity was sensed. ``When I came to work at midnight, it smelled like the Chicago stockyards,'' said Auburn Jail officer Jim Miller. It took police in cars and on foot several hours to round up the strays. The last of them were returned to the barn by 6:30 a.m. Thursday. ``The police are very good cowboys,'' Neff said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Faces Fine If Proposition Attempts Continue
DOC.TEXT: A short elderly man's propensity for propositioning tall women has landed him in court, with a judge threatening to impose fines if he doesn't change his ways. Even Abraham Cohen's lawyer was unable to explain the behavior of his five-foot client. ``He's addicted to chatting up tall girls _ you'd think he would be burnt out at 66,'' attorney Ron Cannon told Magistrate Malcolm Whitely this week. Cohen pleaded guilty to a charge of common assault for feeling the thigh of a woman sitting next to him on a shopping mall bench. In placing Cohen on bond, Whitley told him: ``If this happens again, it's going to cost you 3,000 dollars ($2,400 U.S.). Explain that to your wife.'' Cannon said Cohen was one of his ``most persistent clients'' with a long record of similar offenses dating back 20 years, and that he always paid his legal fees in advance to keep his wife from finding out.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,694.57, down 392.70 points or 1.22 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: US Urges American Travelers To Mideast To Be Cautious
DOC.TEXT: The State Department, in a follow-up to President Bush's suspension of the U.S. dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Thursday urged Americans traveling to the Middle East and elsewhere to exercise ``extra caution.'' Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher attributed the advisory to rising tensions in the area but said he was unaware of any specific threats. He said it was possible that the tension might increase as a result of Bush's announcement but he stressed there were other reasons for the warning as well. He recalled that on May 31, the day after the abortive attack by the Palestine Liberation Front on beaches near Tel Aviv, the department had said it was concerned about tensions in the region and that terrorists had threatened to attack American citizens or interests.
DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Increase in Airline Liability Payments
DOC.TEXT: Airlines would have to increase liability payments to passengers who die in crashes under treaty protocols approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The protocols to the Warsaw Convention, created in 1929, would raise to $130,000 the per-passenger limit on liability regardless of circumstances of the crash. The current limit is $75,000 per passenger, except in cases when an airline is found guilty of willful misconduct. The vote on Thursday was 11-2, with Sens. Joseph Biden, D-Del., and Paul Simon, D-Ill., opposing the protocols. The protocols have been fought by lobbying groups representing trial lawyers. Biden is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Despite passage of the protocols, a stiff fight is expected on the Senate floor where the measures have failed twice before.
DOC.HEAD: Senator Suggests Bargain Troop Cuts for Concessions
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military force reductions in South Korea should be used to bargain for concessions from communist North Korea, a member of the U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee says. Because some reduction of the 43,000-strong U.S. military force in South Korea is inevitable, ``we should make a virtue of necessity by using troop cuts as leverage for peace _ especially in light of the need to engage North Korea in dialogue,'' Sen. Timothy E. Wirth, D-Colo., said in a speech. ``In short, we should link coming troop reductions to a redoubled effort at reconciliation on the Korean peninsula,'' Wirth told a Wednesday meeting of Korean experts hosted by the Cato Foundation, a nonpartisan Washington think tank. Noting that North Korean propaganda since 1953 has been aimed at the U.S. military presence, Wirth suggested Pyongyang might respond to such an approach. North Korea ``cannot remain unaffected by world changes, especially in light of the changes under way in its superpower allies,'' he said. ``The issue is how Pyongyang will manage the inevitable transition from a closed society to a more open one, from the 40-year rule of Kim Il-sung to a new generation.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Conference Protests Fall Into Pattern
With PM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrations at the world's largest meeting on AIDS have taken on a predictable pattern _ a theme-of-the-day march, speakers and street theater followed by a sit-in. Each morning, a dispatch is sent out by ACT UP, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, detailing the day's planned demonstration. It ends each time with the same phrase: ``Civil disobedience is anticipated during the protest.'' The group's activities produced about 50 arrests Thursday, bringing the total to 149 since the start of the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. On Thursday, the sit-in was at the busy intersection of Market and Van Ness, where 50 protesters ignored police warnings and huddled in the street. Several hundred other demonstrators remained on the sidewalk yelling the group's slogan: ``Act up. Fight back. Fight AIDS.'' Before the sit-in, protesters lighted a small bonfire of protest placards, spray painted Day-Glo slogans and outlined their bodies with chalk to symbolize how the city's largely volunteer effort to fight AIDS has been exhausted. Despite some claims of police brutality, there has been little violence other than some shoving and a few bruised and bloodied knuckles from police batons. While anticipated disruptions of science sessions at the Moscone Center have failed to materialize, the protest organizers are pleased with their showing so far. ``I think we've been very effective about getting on the agenda and getting our voices heard,'' said Josh Gamson, a member of the San Francisco chapter of ACT UP. ``It was very ambitious to get a different theme out there each day.'' The theme for Wednesday was access for those with AIDS to research and policy making. On Thursday, demonstrators marched a winding route through San Francisco's civic center area to point out what they claim is a lack of government action and funding for AIDS programs. The march had stops at federal, state and city office buildings. A mock trial was held outside the offices of state Insurance Commissioner Roxannie Gillespi, who was criticized for failing to respond to charges that insurance companies were discriminating against people with AIDS. A few dozen demonstrators stormed into the building lobby but left a short time later.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Seeks Approval To Stop Some Construction Projects
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is asking Congress to cancel 68 of ``the most obvious'' construction projects, mostly in Europe, and excluding strategic homeports in the United States. The overwhelming majority of the projects are located in Europe, with only three sites in the United States. They were chosen from a list of 207 projects worth $1.2 billion Cheney has been considering canceling. Notably absent from the list sent to Congress on Thursday were the Navy's ``strategic home ports'' in Texas, Alabama, Mississippi and New York. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams said the remaining projects still were under consideration for cancellation, including the home ports, but that decisions on those would take more time. ``We know we are not going to need these facilities,'' Williams said of Thursday's list. ``These are the cuts that are the most obvious.'' Cheney has come under intense criticism on Capitol Hill for taking aim at military sites in Democrats' districts as he has moved to pare funds from the Pentagon budget in this time of lessened East-West tensions. The list contains a variety of construction projects, including schools for military dependents in West Germany; munitions storage centers in Italy; a mess hall on Guam; and even a ``classified'' three-unit housing project for families associated with the super-secret National Security Agency. In the United States, the list includes $39 million for a supply warehouse at Red River, Texas; $1.9 million for an addition to the flight simulator at Luke Air Force Base in Arizona; and $56,000 for fireplaces at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio. ``The secretary disapproves of installing fireplaces in senior officer's quarters,'' the Pentagon announcement said. No other site was singled out for mention. Formally, Cheney's action means that he is asking Congress to ``rescind'' the funds for the projects, which were authorized for payment in past years. The move requires congressional approval and the funds will not revert to the Pentagon coffers, Williams said. The spokesman said Cheney's decision to freeze nearly $7 billion worth of military construction projects remains in effect, and that additional requests to stop other projects could be made from that entire group. While the Pentagon weighed the fate of the Navy homeports, two senior Democrats on the House Armed Services Committee released a congressional report showing that the Navy has not halted ongoing construction at the Staten Island facility despite lawmakers' letters calling for a stoppage. ``Work under contracts already awarded has continued unabated and the Navy is going ahead with plans to dedicate the New York Naval Station on June 25, 1990,'' the General Accounting Office said. In addition, the GAO found that eight families of military personnel assigned to the cruiser USS Normandy have moved to Staten Island and 131 families are in the process of relocating from Norfolk, Va., to New York. In a letter, Reps. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., and Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., urged Cheney to ``reverse engines on all family relocations to Staten Island.'' ``Families should not have to sell their homes, leave friends and change schools just to have to turn around and return to their old homes when the Staten Island homeport is finally and permanently closed,'' Bennett and Schroeder said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Off Sharply, Dollar up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose marginally against the Japanese yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dipped moderately. The dollar ended the week at 154.75 yen, up 0.15 yen from Thursday's close of 154.60 yen. After opening at 154.98 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 154.65 yen and 155.00 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 392.70 points or 1.22 percent, closing at 31,694.57. The Nikkei index lost 0.49 points, or 0.0015 percent, on Thursday. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was 87.18 points at 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), up from Thursday's close of 87.14. Their yield stood at 7.145 percent, down from the previous day's 7.155 percent. Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said there were no major movements in yen-dollar trading in the absence of fresh news. ``Trading was rather centered on cross trading in which traders sold the British pound on profit-taking and bought the yen,'' Tsuchiko said. The British currency has risen sharply in recent days on speculation that Britain later this year would join the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System, which limits exchange fluctuations.

DOC.HEAD: Mandelas Bring Hope to Harlem
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson and Winnie Mandela made hope live again, for a while, on a Harlem street corner brimming with history. The hope, and the pride, were evident on the faces of the 100,000 admirers as two black cultures, American and South African, intertwined Thursday in a rally outside the Harlem State Office Building. ``This is a day like none other in the history of Harlem,'' resident Isabel Coles said. ``It brings together the American black and the African. This day symbolizes that we are one in spirit; we are still African.'' Some celebrated their African-American heritage by wearing red, orange, yellow, gold or green dashikis, a type of African tribal robe. Others simply wore Mandela T-shirts and buttons. Most reveled with the sound of African drumbeats, Jamaican reggae and American jazz. Even a policeman danced when a Bob Marley recording blared over the loudspeaker. Mandela, the 71-year-old African National Congress leader, told the crowd that Harlem helped him win his freedom after spending 27 years in a South African prison for anti-apartheid activities. ``I am able to speak to you because of the massive resistance of our people and the unceasing solidarity of millions throughout the world. It is you, the working people of Harlem, that helped to make it happen.'' ``The kinship that the ANC feels for the people of Harlem goes deeper than skin color,'' Mandela said. ``It is a kinship of our shared historical experience and the kinship and the solidarity of the victims of blind prejudice and hatred.'' The rally was held on a corner _ 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard _ that until a decade or so ago symbolized the Harlem equivalent of London's Hyde Park. Pan-Africanists, Garveyites and Malcolm X stood on crates or platforms to speak before rallies or to passersby. This time, the stage _ and the audience _ was considerably larger. But Mandela didn't forget the black heroes of yesteryear. The crowd cheered as Mandela evoked names like Martin Luther King; Malcolm X; Marcus Garvey, the black nationalist leader of the 1920s; singer-actor Paul Robeson; and the late congressman for whom the boulevard was named. The stage was shared by Malcolm X's widow, Betty Shabazz. She wept when Mrs. Mandela embraced her. ``Time is very short and I would like to stand right here and cry for a thousand years but I cannot,'' said Ms. Shabazz. A woman in the crowd shouted out, ``Me, too!'' ``I greet you all in the Soweto of America,'' Mrs. Mandela said. ``It is a great honor for me, and especially the women of my country, to stand here in the capital of the revolution throughout the world: Harlem.'' Mandela added: ``While my comrades and I were in prison, we followed closely your own story of the injustices of racial segregation and economic inequities.'' ``To our people,'' he said, ``Harlem symbolizes strength and beauty in resistance.''

DOC.HEAD: Yankee Stadium Finally Fills the House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS to 52,000 sted 50,000 in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: There's finally a full house at Yankee Stadium this year. It took an appearance by Nelson Mandela to pack the place, where crowds have been sparse this season for the Yankees _ the team with the worst record in baseball. All 52,000 seats for a Thursday night concert featuring the African National Congress leader were sold out, the mayor's office announced. It was the first sellout of the season, including a less-than-full house Opening Day. The last of the tickets were snatched up several hours before the 7 p.m. show was scheduled to begin, said mayoral spokesman Stanley Davis. Mayor David Dinkins' personal appeals on Wednesday for ticket sales seemed to work, as 10,000 tickets went in the last 24 hours. The most expensive seats sold for $500, while the cheapest were $5.

DOC.HEAD: Mandelamania: Adulation in Harlem, Sellout at Yankee Stadium
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `From Harlem...' to CORRECT crowd count at Yankee Stadium.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY25,26,28,29,34; LaserColor NY25
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's passionate plea for black equality inspired legions of joyful supporters who packed the streets of Harlem on Thursday in one of the most emotional and exuberant stops on his world tour. For generations of American blacks, Harlem has served as cultural capital, and Mandela's visit before a crowd that police estimated at 100,000 was a tribute to his fight for racial justice. ``Brothers and sisters, comrades and friends, victory is in sight,'' Mandela said. ``The light at the end of the tunnel is so bright but we are not yet there. ``To reach the end of the tunnel it requires that we make the necessary sacrifices. It requires that we remain unrelenting in pursuit of our goal.'' Recalling part of a speech he gave the day he was sentenced to prison, Mandela told the crowd that abolishing apartheid ``is an idea which I am prepared to live for but if need be it is an idea for which I am prepared to die.'' He added that while in prison he was ``aware of the resistance of the people of Harlem and continue to be inspired by your indomitable spirit.'' ``My only regret is that I am unable to embrace each and every one of you,'' he said. The crowd, which filled streets, balconies and fire escapes, responded enthusiastically to Mandela and his wife, Winnie, with shouts and raised fists. Mandela told the crowd he was moved by a slogan he had seen on a woman's sweatshirt earlier in his visit. It said: ``Black by nature. Proud by choice.'' Mandela's visit to the United States has tapped into a deep vein of emotion in black communities. In New York, a surge of pride has welled up in neighborhoods where self-esteem is often lacking. He spoke in Harlem at 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard, a corner long associated with political oratory from black leaders including W.E.B. duBois, Martin Luther King Jr., Paul Robeson, Malcolm X, and the former congressman for whom the boulevard was named. From Harlem, Mandela went to Yankee Stadium, in the impoverished South Bronx, where he told a sellout crowd of 52,000 that he always knew Americans were thinking of him when he was imprisoned. ``You, the people, never abandoned us even when we passed through the most difficult years,'' he said. ``We are winning because you made victory possible.'' He said the ANC vision ``of a democratic South Africa is a society free of all sort of racism and sexism.'' His solemn appearance at the stadium ended on a lighter note when Mayor David Dinkins presented Mandela a Yankees' warmup jacket and baseball cap. ``Now you know who I am,'' a beaming Mandela said after donning the cap. ``I am a Yankee.'' Ticket prices at the stadium ranged from $5 to $500. The message to ``keep the pressure on'' until apartheid is abolished has been a constant theme during Mandela's 13-nation ANC fund-raising tour. Since his arrival on Wednesday, nearly 1 million people have turned out to cheer and greet the African National Congress leader. The celebration began earlier Thursday at a joyous ecumenical service at Riverside Church that brought religious leaders of all faiths together in a call for equality. The invitation-only service was anything but solemn as participants danced in the aisles to the beat of African drummers. Caught up in the fervor, the 71-year-old freedom fighter merrily waved his fist and bopped to the crowd's rhythmic clapping after the African National Congress choir finished singing its anthem. Addressing the congregation, Mandela invited longtime supporters to ``come home to claim their rightful role in the recreation of a new South Africa'' and thanked the religious community for its long support. The ANC leader, released Feb. 11 from a South African prison after serving 27 years for anti-apartheid activities, told the crowd of about 2,000 that they were entering the final phase of their struggle for black equality. But he also cautioned that ``the age of freedom has not yet dawned'' and that to lift economic sanctions against the white-minority South African government now would ``plunge us back into the darkness from which our country is painfully struggling to emerge.'' Before the rallies, Mandela appeared on a local radio show, met with the editorial board of The New York Times and taped a ``town meeting'' with Ted Koppel, which was to be aired Thursday night on ABC-TV. During the Koppel show, former Reagan administration official Kenneth Adelman asked Mandela why he supported Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, Cuban President Fidel Castro and Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi. ``One of the mistakes the Western world makes is to think that their enemies should be our enemies,'' Mandela replied, to the audience's loud approval. ``We have our own struggle.'' He added that Arafat, Gadhafi and Castro ``support our struggle to the hilt. There is no reason whatsoever we should have any hesitation about their commitment to human rights in South Africa. They are placing resources at our disposal to win the struggle.'' Before the ecumenical service, Mandela met privately with 150 religious leaders and received a $200,000 check. Donations were also made during the service but the amount raised was not immediately available. Mandela began his day with an impromptu breakfast-hour stroll through a park adjacent to Gracie Mansion, where he is staying with the mayor. His unannounced appearance sent a dozen security men and scores of police officers scurrying to surround him as he walked four blocks to the park. ``It was very nice,'' he said afterward. ``Thank you. I'm sorry. I didn't think it would be so much trouble.'' The security detail, dubbed ``Operation Topaz,'' is part of a massive effort put together by city police and State Department agents. Police overtime during Mandela's three-day stay is expected to cost $2 million. Dinkins said the State Department has agreed to pick up the tab. During his first day in New York, Mandela addressed Brooklyn students, was given a ticker-tape parade up Broadway and received the key to the city. Police estimated 800,000 people turned out to greet him. On Friday, he is to address the United Nations General Assembly. Mandela is scheduled to fly to Boston on Saturday. Other stops include Washington, where he will meet with President Bush, Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif. He will leave the United States on July 1.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0462 to FIX cycle designator.
Panel Says Preserving Breast in Early Cancer Doesn't Affect Survival
DOC.TEXT: A panel of experts says removing a cancerous tumor in the early stages of breast cancer gives as good a survival chance to women as more radical surgery in which the entire breast is removed. Mastectomies, in which the entire breast is removed, and lumpectomies, in which only the tumor is removed, both give ``excellent'' results for Stage I and Stage II breast cancer, the panel said. The committee of 15 experts was assembled by the National Institutes of Health to consider research on the survival of women with early stages of breast cancer and to develop a consensus on what therapy should be used to treat the disease. ``The therapies appear to be equivalent in survival,'' said Dr. William C. Wood, a Harvard Medical School surgeon and chairman of the committee. ``We believe it is preferable to preserve an organ.'' Mastectomy is still the most commonly used therapy for early stage breast cancer, Wood said. A lumpectomy is followed with radiation therapy, and Wood said some patients choose mastectomy because they ``prefer to lose a breast instead of have six weeks of radiation therapy.'' In its report, the committee said surgery in which the breast is saved, or conserved, ``is an appropriate method of primary therapy for the majority of women with Stage I and II breast cancer, and is preferable'' because the breast is preserved and the survival chances are the same as for mastectomy. Wood said that both mastectomy and lumpectomy involves the removal of nearby lymph nodes. If these nodes are cancer-free and the primary tumor is smaller than one centimeter, both methods of treatment have about a 90 percent chance of cure. About 150,000 American women will be diagnosed with breast cancer this year, the committee report said. Between 75 percent and 80 percent of this group will have Stage I or Stage II disease, and about two-thirds of these will have cancer-free lymph nodes. Stage I and II cancers have not spread beyond the breast and lymph nodes. But just how to treat this early-stage breast cancer long has been controversial. Traditionally, the preferred treatment has been a radical mastectomy in which the entire breast and much adjacent tissue is removed. During the past two decades, there have been a number of studies comparing the survival results of less extensive breast surgery, including lumpectomy. The committee found that, based on the studies, survival rates are virtually the same for the two types of therapy. The experts said the picture was less clear for follow-up treatment using chemotherapy or a drug that blocks the hormone estrogen. The studies show a trend that may suggest an advantage in taking the follow up or adjuvant therapy, but the committee said the drugs may be toxic or degrade the patient's quality of life. For patients with very small primary tumors _ one centimeter or less _ adjuvant therapy is not required, the committee said. The committee also said that the use of lumpectomy should be based on an individual evaluation of each patient and with the full understanding by the patient of all the options. Lumpectomies are not appropriate for all Stage I or II patients because of the size of the breast, or the distribution of tumors or calcified lumps within the breast, the committee said.

DOC.HEAD: South African Media More Interested in U.S. Tour
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's U.S. visit splashed across most major South African newspapers, though government broadcasts played down coverage of the black nationalist leader. Mandela, on a world tour, received more subdued media coverage on his European swing, with reports focusing more on the issue of sanctions for South Africa's white government. The resurgent coverage since Mandela's arrival in New York on Wednesday may be explained by South Africa's fascination with American hype. ``The Big Apple threw its hat in the air yesterday and demonstrated in its best and most extravagant way its admiration and affection for Nelson Mandela in a parade was without precedent in the city's history,'' correspondent Ramsey Milne wrote in Thursday's edition of the The Star, the nation's largest daily. ``Mandela Wows New York'' was The Star's banner headline Thursday. It carried a large front-page picture of Mandela in almost every one of its nine editions Wednesday and Thursday. Most major newspapers in the country gave prominent play to the cheers from American throngs and the praise from American officials that greeted Mandela when he arrived in New York. However, an evening TV news program ignored the welcome, and two other government broadcast outlets put on several other news items first. Another exception was The Sowetan, the nation's largest black daily newspaper. It continued the policy it has adopted since Mandela left for his 14-nation six-week tour, by reporting his progress on inside pages and devoting its front page to activities of the black community inside South Africa. The pro-government English-language newspaper, The Citizen, carried the banner headline, ``Mandela Gets Big U.S. Welcome'' on Thursday. Its second story covered President Bush's remarks Wednesday that he wanted to show appreciation to President F.W. de Klerk for his movements toward ending apartheid. Mandela's historic ticker-tape parade through Manhattan occurred too late to be broadcast on the evening television news show of the government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. on Wednesday. It was shown on the early morning news show Thursday but not repeated Thursday evening, so most South Africans did not see it. Government-run Radio South Africa led its Thursday morning news with a report that the U.S. State Department had suggested the African National Congress could receive aid if it gave up violence. The second item focused on Bush's remarks. The third news item mentioned that Mandela had arrived in the United States, but gave no details on his welcome. The same order was followed on the Thursday evening television news broadcast in Afrikaans. But the Mandela items were carried later in the TV show, which began with a Cabinet minister saying the government wanted to begin negotiations on a new constitution next year.

DOC.HEAD: Some Skeptical About U.S. Supreme Court's Patronage Ban
DOC.TEXT: Some in this city once notorious for political patronage were skeptical that a U.S. Supreme Court ruling outlawing the system of jobs for political work will put such abuses to rest. But Michael Shakman, a Chicago lawyer whose lawsuits helped pare patronage in the city, said the ruling Thursday could affect hiring practices throughout the country. ``It should result in a much fairer system to applicants for jobs who are no longer going to be required to give a political loyalty oath, in effect, in order to get the job,'' Shakman said. Fred Cooper, a Georgia Republican Party official, predicted a barrage of lawsuits alleging discrimination. ``Many departments do hire based on what they think the next elections will bring,'' he said. ``This will be the basis for complaints in the future.'' Both political parties in Illinois have a long track record of political hiring, but Chicago's system became particularly well-known under Democratic Mayor Richard J. Daley, the quintessential big-city boss in office for more than 20 years until his death in 1976. Daley's son, Richard M. Daley, is now mayor of Chicago. Political consultant Don Rose, who worked against the elder Daley, said the Supreme Court ruling is just another step away from the late mayor's machine. ``It's just another reason for him to spin in his grave, but he's probably used to it by now,'' said Rose, viewed by many as a reformer. A 1973 federal court decree restricted political firings in Chicago and other governments in northern Illinois. Eight years after Daley's death, the administration of Harold Washington, the city's first black mayor, agreed to a system intended to prohibit most political hiring. That system remains intact. Thursday's ruling came in an Illinois case and orders an end to political hirings, firings and promotions. The court ruled that federal, state and local government jobs generally may not be awarded based on party affiliation. The justices, voting 5-4, said constitutionally protected rights are violated when people are denied government jobs, promotions or transfers for reasons of political partisanship. Partisanship now may play a role in deciding who gets a government job only when political affiliation is an appropriate requirement, such as for high-level policy advisers. Two earlier high court rulings, in 1976 and 1980, basically restricted political firings. ``I just think it's a futile attempt to try and change something that's been here since the beginning of this city,'' said one of Cook County's nearly 25,000 employees. Told that the high court had basically outlawed patronage, the employee said, ``It'll still be the same thing, but it'll have a different name to it.'' The man, like other workers interviewed in the lobby of the Cook County Building, refused to give his name. ``I think patronage will always be. ... Everybody has their own people,'' said an administrator who has worked for the county for 14 years. The Supreme Court ruling stems from a 1985 federal lawsuit on behalf of three Illinois residents who claimed they were denied state jobs or promotions because they were not active Republicans. The suit was filed against Gov. James R. Thompson and other GOP leaders in Illinois and contended the governor made party allegiance a requirement for 68,000 state jobs under his control. Robert Chanin, a lawyer who represented the National Education Association in urging the justices to stamp out patronage, predicted little impact for federal jobs but wide impact on states. ``There are probably 40 states that have some type of comprehensive merit system, but perhaps as many as 10 states and Puerto Rico don't have such systems or have slippage in their merit systems. They rely primarily on what amounts to a patronage system.'' Thompson, who is not running for re-election, again denied the lawsuit's allegations Thursday. He said he has hired Democrats and Republicans, but said he would choose a Republican if applicants were equally qualified. ``I think the parties are worth saving and I think the Supreme Court is naive in saying that patronage has no basis in strengthening political parties,'' Thompson said. But Rose said, ``If the only reasons political parties can exist and thrive is through abusive hiring and firing practices, than there is no reason for them to survive.''

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Nears For Constitutional Pact on Quebec Status
DOC.TEXT: With the weekend deadline for its passage approaching, a constitutional agreement aimed at keeping French-speaking Quebec in the Canadian federation was still blocked in two provinces. The agreement must be ratified by all 10 provinces by midnight Saturday or expire. Eight of the provinces favor the Meech Lake accord, as it is called. The five-point agreement would designate Quebec a ``distinct society,'' something the Supreme Court would be obliged to consider when looking at specific laws challenged under the constitution. Quebec is the country's largest province in terms of land area and includes more than one-fourth of the country's 25 million people. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, one of the most ardent supporters of the agreement, flew Thursday to Newfoundland, one of the holdout provinces, in an effort to save the agreement. In Manitoba province an Indian lawmaker demanding constitutional recognition of Indian tribes as distinct societies has used procedural delays to block debate for a week on approval of the agreement. In a restrained but tough address on Thursday, Mulroney confronted Newfoundland's 52-seat legislature with the possibility of constitutional paralysis, economic problems and increased support for the separatist cause. ``On that night, when you're sitting there with your family and your children, one thought is going to go through your mind: do you mean to tell me that we could have avoided all of this for Meech Lake?'' Mulroney said. ``If that night were ever to come, the terms of Meech Lake are going to look very, very reasonable indeed to every member of this House of Assembly and every house of assembly across Canada,'' he said. The Meech Lake agreement, first approved by the prime minister and the premiers of the provinces in 1987, is aimed at winning Quebec's signature on Canada's 1982 constitution. At that time, the ministers set a three-year deadline for approval by the Parliament and legislatures. In the interim, governments changed in three of the provinces _ Manitoba, Newfoundland, and New Brunswick _ and the premiers reneged on the signatures of their predecessors. In early June, Mulroney called the premiers to Ottawa, where they spent a week in intense private meetings. They agreed to pass the original accord as it is. New Brunswick passed it last week. For many Quebecois in Montreal, Canada's second-largest city, the arguments have worn thin and the endless debate over a document thought signed and sealed in 1987 has led to widespread cynicism and a rise in nationalist feelings. Premier Robert Bourassa has categorically rejected suggestions for extending the Saturday deadline. ``There will be a profound disappointment, sadness and much disillusionment in Quebec,'' he said. A poll published Thursday in the French-language newspaper La Presse indicated that 57 percent of Quebecois favor sovereignty, up slightly from 56 percent in March. But, unlike a decade ago when a referendum was held by the separatist Parti Quebecois to determine the future of the province, passion is missing. ``I think people have accepted that it (Meech Lake) won't pass with a shrug,'' said Robert Gagnon, a computer systems specialist for a Montreal insurance company. Jean Chretien, leading candidate for the leadership of the opposition Liberal Party, told the party's congress in Calgary that failure of Meech Lake would not necessarily mean a breakup of Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Study Indicates Heterosexual AIDS Risk Higher for Women than Men
With PM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Men infected with AIDS are 14 times more likely to pass on the deadly virus to women during sex than the other way around, a new study indicates. Researchers looked at 58 male sex partners of infected women and found that only one man became infected. In that case, the couple reported having intercourse without condoms more than 1,000 times over seven years. The research suggests that in the United States, at least, the AIDS virus is transmitted far more efficiently from men to women than from women to men. A similar study conducted in Europe found considerably less difference between the sexes. The risk of male-to-female transmission was only twice as high as female-to-male. Dr. Nancy S. Padian, who directed the U.S. study, said it was unclear whether the difference could be attributed to biological differences between the sexes or whether other factors are involved. Heterosexual transmission of AIDS is still relatively rare in the United States. It accounts for 5 percent of the 130,000 cases reported so far. In Africa, heterosexual AIDS is far more common. The virus seems to spread with equal proficiency from men to women and from women to men. Some experts believe that is because untreated venereal disease is relatively common in Africa and resulting sores provide openings for the virus to enter the body. Despite her findings, Padian said men should not become complacent about the risk of catching acquired immune deficiency syndrome from women. ``We still recommend caution with unknown sexual partners, regardless of their gender,'' she said. Padian's research, conducted at the University of California in Berkeley, was reported Thursday at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. Her group also studied 269 women who had sex with infected men. Of them, 54 women, or 20 percent, caught the virus. When the figures were adjusted for the number of sexual contacts, the researchers calculated that the male-to-female transmission was 14 times more common than female-to-male. In the United States, AIDS is transmitted largely by male homosexual intercourse and by sharing hypodermic needles. However, women who have sex with male drug addicts are also at risk, as are their babies, who can catch the virus before birth. In another report, doctors from Johns Hopkins University recommended that all pregnant women be offered the option of AIDS tests. Current health guidelines generally recommend that the tests be suggested only for women who admit risky behavior, such as drug abuse. However, the Johns Hopkins study showed that limiting testing to these women will miss many who are infected and risk passing the virus to their babies. At Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, health care workers found that the number of women discovered to be infected more than doubled when everyone was offered the test.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Second Day in U.S. _ What He Said
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Excerpts from remarks by South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela during his appearances Thursday in New York City:

After his early morning, unannounced walk near the East River caught security guards and police by surprise and sent them scurrying to surround and protect him: ``It was very nice. Thank you. I'm sorry. I didn't think it would be so much trouble.''
Asked about his health after the walk: ``I'm feeling on top of the world.''

At an ecumenical service at Riverside Church, speaking about ending apartheid: ``We are now closer to this goal than at any time in our history. In the words of the prophet Isaiah, we have risen up on the wings of eagles. We have run, and not grown weary ... and finally our destination is in sight.''
After American religious leaders gave $200,000 to combat apartheid: ``You are our comrades in arms, you are our brothers and sisters. We feel perfectly at home with you.''

After breaking into a spontaneous dance at the church service, he thanked religious leaders for their longtime support: ``When our cause was not a popular cause in the corridors of power in Western nations, it was religious communities, college and university campuses and anti-apartheid organizations that stood firm on economic sanctions. I am here today to say `Thank you.'''

At a large outdoor rally in Harlem: ``Brothers and sisters, comrades and friends, victory is in sight. The light at the end of the tunnel is so bright but we are not yet there. To reach the end of the tunnel it requires that we make the necessary sacrifices. It requires that we remain unrelenting in pursuit of our goal.''
``My only regret is that I am unable to embrace each and every one of you.''

At Yankee Stadium rally in the Bronx: ``You, the people, never abandoned us even when we passed through the most difficult years. Not for a single day, did you forget us, not for a single hour did you forget us. Indeed, you have not forgotten us for a single minute. We are winning because you made victory possible.''
At Yankee Stadium, after Mayor David Dinkins presented him a Yankees baseball warmup jacket and cap: ``Now you know who I am. I am a Yankee.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia's President Calls Rebel Successes `Dangerous'
DOC.TEXT: President Mengistu Haile Mariam told lawmakers rebel offensives must halted, warning that ``the very survival of the nation is at stake.'' The Marxist president spoke Thursday at the opening of the annual session of the Shengo, or parliament. In his speech, Mengistu cited recent successes by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front and the Tigre People's Liberation Front. ``An extremely dangerous and critical situation now hangs not only over the northern regions of the country but also throughout the country,'' Mengistu told the 652 deputies and 2,500 government and party officials. Mengistu urged lawmakers to pass a resolution ``expressing the immediate answer of the Ethiopian people'' to the Eritreans' refusal to resume peace talks. A round of talks had been set for this month. The Eritreans, fighting a 3-decade-old secessionist war, said last week they planned to achieve their goals militarily. Eritrean and government representatives held two rounds of preliminary peace talks late last year. The Eritreans, in their largest offensive to date, in February captured the Red Sea port of Massawa. That cut all but air access to Asmara, the capital of Eritrea, Ethiopia's northernmost province. The Tigrean rebels, a smaller group, control Tigre, Eritrea's southern neighbor. Since August, they have claimed battlefield victories in Tigre's neighbors, Gonder, Wollo and Shoa, coming to within 62 miles of the capital, Addis Ababa. The Tigreans, who began fighting in 1974, seek Mengistu's ouster and the establishment of a more hard-line Marxist government. They often coordinate their offensives with the Eritreans.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Slightly Against Yen; Tokyo Stock Exchange Dips
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dipped moderately. The dollar closed at 154.75 yen, up 0.15 yen from Thursday's close of 154.60 yen. After opening at 154.98 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 154.65 yen and 155.00 yen. ``It's been a quiet day,'' said Chizuko Satsukawa, a currency dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. She said the dollar stayed in a relatively narrow range because of a lack of fresh market-affecting news. The dollar was sold against the British pound on profit-taking after the U.S. currency gained ground, she said. The British currency has been advancing on speculation that Britain will join Europe's unified exchange system this year, dealers say. About $8.65 billion changed hands in spot trading, down from Thursday's $10 billion. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 392.70 points or 1.22 percent, closing the week at 31,694.57. The Nikkei index lost 0.49 points, or 0.0015 percent, on Thursday. Volume traded on the first section totaled 350 million shares, down from the previous day's 400 million shares. Akira Shimoda, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities, said many investors refrained from participating because of rising short-term interest rates. He cited 7.5 percent interest rates on three-month certificates of deposit. Shimoda said institutional investors in particular took a wait-and-see position in advance of major political events set for next month, including monetary unification of the two German states and a seven-nation summit meeting of major industrialized countries scheduled in Houston. In bond dealings, benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 87.18 points, up from Thursday's close of 87.14. Their yield stood at 7.145 percent, down from the previous day's 7.155 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Hit Plains, Mid-Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms raked parts of Arkansas, Tennessee and the middle Atlantic Coast today after severe storms with damaging hail and lightning swept from New York to Mississippi to New Mexico. Tornadoes touched down Thursday near Liberal, Kan. Twisters also were reported at Childers and Nowata, Okla., and in several places in Arkansas. High winds blew down trees, knocking out power and blocking roads in Madison, Washington and Benton counties in Arkansas. Hail the size of softballs accompanied a storm that moved across Perry and Faulkner counties in Arkansas, the National Weather Service reported. Lightning strikes late Thursday caused forest fires in Guadalupe Mountains National Park in west Texas. Alabama thunderstorms produced walnut-sized hail at Inverness, flooding in Homewood, and wind gusts near 60 mph and damage at Birmingham. Hail the size of baseballs fell near Gem, Kan. Golf ball-sized hail fell near Bartlesville, Okla., near Emporia, Kan., at Newfield, N.Y., and at Flora, Miss. Flooding also was reported in Uniontown, Kan. Rain showers and thunderstorms late Thursday extended from Florida across the Deep South to southeast Texas and Arkansas. Storms also reached from east-central New Mexico across the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles into Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Iowa, Colorado, the Dakotas, Minnesota, northern Wisconsin, lower Michigan and much of Illinois and northwest Indiana. Rain showers and thunderstorms reached from New England across New York and northeast Pennsylvania; rain also fell over west-central Oregon. Thunderstorms were reported early today in Memphis, Tenn., Hatteras, N.C., and parts of Arkansas. Two inches of rain fell Thursday evening at New Orleans. High temperature records were broken Thursday at Astoria, Ore., where it was 89; Augusta, Ga. 104; Charleston, S.C., 100; Columbia, S.C., 106; Wilmington, N.C. 101.
