Bacon, a former city planning commission director and one of those responsible for the park and mall, maintained a steady stream of criticism and passed out typed lists of his complaints at the open house. ``What's going on here is supposed to be the monument to the Constitution, which in a certain sense transcends even the Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln memorials because it is not to an individual, it is to a great concept,'' he said. ``I think it looks dinky; I think it looks like Bugs Bunny ears. ``Somebody else said it looks like the security things you pass through when you go into an airport. And other people think it looks like billboards. ``And it is so clear that in that huge space it will look absolutely ridiculous, and it will make the city of Philadelphia and the nation look silly.'' Replied Cawood, superintendent of the park: ``What is Ed Bacon's monstrosity is somebody else's work of art.'' Under the plan, the walls would have the Constitution, amendments and all, etched in bronze. On the outside, the walls would be faced with stone slabs from all 50 states. ``It's a sincere attempt to make something appropriate, something that is a thing of beauty,'' said designer Bruce Thompson, who had to pretend not to hear such comments as, ``I don't like this at all.'' The plan would require the demolition of the circular fountain, which has been dry since 1987. Cawood said it is beyond repair, dangerous and too expensive to operate. Opponents argue the fountain could be fixed for half the expected $5 million cost of the new monument. Citizens were encouraged to write down their comments and leave them in a box. Besides the differing opinions, money is a problem. Though Congress passed a bill in 1988 authorizing the building of a monument, it's up to Cawood to find the money from private and public sources. ``As Benjamin Franklin said, nothing in life is certain except death and taxes,'' Cawood said.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor to Parents: Tell Kids Ninja Turtles Just a Movie
DOC.TEXT: Children entralled with the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles should be reminded that the swashbuckling exploits of the movie aren't meant to be played out in the streets, safety experts said Friday. At the Northampton studios where the popular characters were created, a few calls have been received, mainly dealing with children who apparently went looking for their heroes in real-life drainage systems, said Cheryl Prindle, executive director of Mirage Studios. Since the sewer-dwelling comic-book heroes made a smash screen debut in April, there have been a few reports of injuries. Officials said they don't see any widespread problem, but they do recommend using some parental common sense. ``There are isolated things here and isolated things there,'' said Bob O'Brien, director of public relations for the Chicago-based National Safety Council. The comic-book characters, a quartet of green, hip creatures who got their super crime-fighting powers after falling into a puddle of radioactive goo in a New York City sewer, use martial arts techniques learned from the mutant pet rat of a Ninja master. ``Basically, our feeling is that kids need to be able to discern what is real and what isn't,'' Prindle said. ``Definitely, the Ninja Turtles don't encourage the kids to go in the sewers looking for them,'' she said. ``I do definitely agree with the National Safety Council that children need supervision, whether it be from the home or the school or wherever it is they're playing.'' In Worcester, the director of the University of Massachusetts Medical Center pediatric trauma care said he has seen about a half-dozen young patients since April who said they were playing at being turtles. ``The kids are very impressionable and the turtles have never looked so cool as they do in the movies so I think they're bound to be imitated,'' said Dr. Michael P. Hirsh. Elsewhere, two young boys in the Dayton, Ohio, area had to be pulled from a pond by adults after they followed a sewer culvert to its end. The mother of one of the boys said the children were pretending to be Ninja turtles. Also in April, a Lombard, Ill., boy dropped a manhole cover on his foot, authorities said. The turtles have been around since 1984, when Northampton friends Kevin Eastman and Peter Laird scraped up the funds for the first printing of their characters. From there the characters _ Michelangelo, Raphael, Donatello and Leonardo _ got their own television show. Their film debut was the biggest spring opening in Hollywood history.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Says it Gave Wrong Solution to Premature Infants Who Died
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with one employee cleared; names, ages, of victims; coroner's report. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Two hospital pharmacy workers were fired Friday after the deaths of three premature infants that had received an incorrectly mixed intravenous solution, hospital officials said. ``The infants were given an IV solution, incorrectly prepared in the pharmacy, that contained potassium,'' said Martin Goldsmith, president of Albert Einstein Medical Center. ``The potassium caused a drop in heart rate in the three babies. Despite aggressive resuscitation efforts, the infants died.'' An internal investigation into the deaths of two girls and a boy in the neonatal intensive care unit June 15-16 revealed that pharmacy workers incorrectly prepared a solution used to flush an IV tube after medication is given, the hospital said. ``The IV solution should have contained heparin, dextrose and water,'' Goldsmith said. ``Instead, it contained heparin and potassium.'' Three employees were initially suspended but one was cleared Friday by the hospital investigation. The two others, a pharmacist and a pharmacy technician, were fired, the hospital said. The employees' names were not released. Goldsmith said the infants were very ill. All were born 13 to 15 weeks premature and weighed less than 2{ pounds at the time of death, the hospital said. All three deaths were ruled accidental by the medical examiner, said spokesman Bill Gilbert. Immediate cause of death for all three was hyperkalemia, or abnormally high potassium levels in the blood, he said. The medical examiner's office identified the victims, all of Philadelphia, as Latoya Simmons, 1 month old; George Rodriguez, 3 months; and Rayna Williams, 15 days old. Prematurity was listed as a contributing factor in the deaths. Goldsmith said the hospital reviewed safety procedures and is strictly monitoring compliance. He ordered mandatory in-service training for all pharmacy workers and will bring in outside experts to review safety procedures. ``We are certain this was an isolated occurrence due to human error, and we want to make sure we're doing everything possible to prevent future accidents,'' Goldsmith said. Goldsmith said hospital officials felt ``remorse'' about the deaths. ``We are distraught that we had a mistake made in our pharmacy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Declares Rare Owl Threatened; Timber Jobs in Jeopardy
LaserPhoto WX19
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department, citing evidence the northern spotted owl may become extinct, ordered the reclusive bird protected Friday as a threatened species, putting thousands of logging jobs into jeopardy. The decision was expected to dramatically curtail logging across millions of acres of virgin forests in the Pacific Northwest, where intense clearing of ancient trees over decades has destroyed the owl's habitat and put its survival into question. But the government said the region's jobs complicated the issue and postponed an announcement of a specific owl recovery plan on what logging restrictions will be required to protect the brown bird. An announcement on the forest management plan was expected next week. ``The biological evidence says that the northern spotted owl is in trouble,'' said John Turner, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, who made the decision to declare the owl threatened under the Endangered Species Act. ``We will not, and by law cannot, ignore that evidence.'' Industry and government estimates said as many as 28,000 timber industry jobs could be lost in the next decade and entire logging communities disrupted by restrictions to protect the owl. Environmentalists who have fought to protect the owl say those estimates are exaggerated. ``Our intention now is to find ways to protect the owl with the least possible disruption to the timber economy in the Pacific Northwest,'' said Turner. He said he is convinced ``there is room to protect both the owl and loggers.'' The estimated 3,000 to 5,000 pairs of remaining northern spotted owls are scattered in old-growth forest in Washington, Oregon and northern California _ an area that also accounts for by far the largest supply of lumber in this country. Turner said ``compelling evidence shows that the spotted owl is at risk'' of extinction if current logging practices continue and more forest is destroyed in the three states. Although the decision to protect the owl is expected to have widespread impact on logging, Turner said he does not foresee significant disruption of this summer's harvesting of Northwest timber. ``Planned logging is going to go on and with very little disruption,'' said Turner. Timber cutting under current contracts with the government would proceed, he said. The effective date of Turner's listing of the owl as threatened goes into effect July 23. About 90 percent of the remaining spotted owls live in forests owned by the federal government and managed by either the U.S. Forest Service or Interior's Bureau of Land Management. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter are to announce next Tuesday a plan aimed at protecting the owl on the government lands and at the same time ``reduce the disruption'' to logging communities. ``Our plan will be to achieve a balance,'' said Interior spokesman Steve Goldstein. The management plan, which is envisioned to include curbs on logging, must be approved by the Fish and Wildlife Service to assure it provides protection to the bird. Private landowners seeking to cut in areas where the owl lives will also have to take steps to limit the impact on owl habitat, officials said. Designation of a species as threatened makes it illegal to harm any of the owls or destroy their critical habitat without federal government approval. A threatened species is one that is likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future. It is afforded similar protections as species classified as endangered. The protection applies to owl on both private and government land. Under some circumstances private land owners may petition to cut in areas occupied by the owl. Federal agencies may not allow cutting on federal lands unless a tree harvesting plan has been approved by the Fish and Wildlife Service. The decision to protect the owl represents a reversal by the Fish and Wildlife Service which for many years refused to list the bird and had to be forced by a federal court in 1988 to reconsider the status of the owl.

DOC.HEAD: Metropolitan Opera Chief Announces Surprise Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th `I, therefore ...'' to UPDATE with attempt to get further comment
DOC.TEXT: The general manager of the Metropolitan Opera resigned Friday, less than eight months after he took over the position with the nation's largest opera company. Hugh Southern, 58, surprised the opera community with his resignation, effective July 1. ``I have been reluctant to make such a choice, but I have become aware over the course of the season that I had not found fulfillment in the position of general manager of the Metropolitan,'' Southern said in a statement. ``I, therefore, felt it would not be fair or productive either to myself or to the Met to continue, and have tendered my resignation.'' David Reuben, a spokesman for the Met, said, ``Nobody is going to make any further comment. The statement speaks for itself.'' On Nov. 1, Southern replaced Bruce Crawford, who decided to return to the corporate world. Both had been seen as general managers who would cope with financial matters while artistic director James Levine was in charge of aesthetic decisions. Southern, a native of England, went to the Met from the National Endowment for the Arts, where he had been deputy chairman for 12 major arts disciplines programs and, for a few months last year, acting chairman. Before that, he had been executive director for New York's Theater Development Fund for 14 years.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Merger Sealed As Allies Meet To Discuss Unification
DOC.TEXT: The two Germanys, for 40 years the most visible symbol of the Cold War divide, on Friday took their biggest step toward unification by reaching final agreement on economic merger. In East Berlin, representatives of the World War II victors and vanquished gathered to discuss German unity, and one of the most notorious markers of East-West conflict _ Checkpoint Charlie _ was removed from the Berlin Wall. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, in Berlin for the unity talks, said a united Germany could join NATO after a five-year transition period and the pullout of foreign troops from the country. Secretary of State James A. Baker III rejected the proposal, saying it was a decision for the Germans to make after unification. Nonetheless, Shevardnadze said later he hoped agreement on unification could be reached ``by the end of the year.'' Despite international differences over unification, the German states continued the race to merge. Government officials in Bonn, speaking on condition of anonymity, said an all-German election was most likely Dec. 9. They said Chancellor Helmut Kohl preferred that date because it would allow a new parliament to convene in early January. An earlier date would have required the new parliament to meet between Christmas and New Year, the sources said. Wighard Haerdtl, an official in West Germany's Interior Ministry, said Friday negotiations were under way between East and West Germany for a second treaty outlining the consitutional aspects of German unification. He said it should be ready for signing in September. The only real remaining obstacle to unification is the military stance of a united Germany. The United States and Western Allies want the new country to be a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization; the Soviet Union has refused to accept this. Baker rejected Shevardnadze's conditional acceptance plan Friday, saying the issue should be decided by a sovereign Germany. With little fanfare, the upper house of the West German parliament on Friday approved the treaty that will merge the economies of the German states on July 2. On that day, the powerful West German Deutsche mark takes over, East Germany's 40 years of rigid socialism gives way to capitalism and the borders that once separated families and worlds will fall. On Thursday, lawmakers in the East German parliament and the powerful lower house of the West German parliament overwhelmingly approved the economic treaty and sealed their decision with joyous applause. Both countries also pledged to respect Poland's Western border and not make any territorial claims after unification on German territory lost after World War II. The issue had become one of the most sensitive in the unification realm; about a third of present-day Poland is former German territory. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel appeared before the Bundesrat, or upper house, Friday to argue for passage of the economic treaty. The West German opposition Social Democrats had long criticized the swift pace of unification and complained the treaty on monetary, economic and social union didn't contain enough safeguards for East Germans as they move from a socialist economy to a free market. Nontheless, passage had been virtually assured. Social Democratic chairman Hans Jochen-Vogel had said Thursday they wouldn't torpedo the treaty because East German expectations were too high and ``uncontrollable'' events could result from a no-vote. In Friday's debate, Lothar Spaeth, governor of the Baden-Wuerttemberg state and a member of Kohl's Christian Democrats, called it a ``most ridiculous argument'' that economic unification move more slowly. ``The people over there have set the pace,'' he said, noting the hundreds of thousands of East Germans who fled their repressive communist country last year after borders were open to the West. Kohl was meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand on the Rhine when the economic treaty gained final approval, and there was no immediate reaction from the man who aspires to be the first chancellor of a unified Germany. In a plea Thursday for approval of the pact, he said ``the hopes of the people of Germany for the unity and freedom of all Germans are about to be fulfilite the rush to unification, there are many fears about next month's economic merger. Some experts have predicted up to 2 million East Germans will lose their jobs as outmoded government-owned factories and businesseled.'' Desps try to compete in the free-market system. More than a third of the enterprises are expected to close, and social unrest could result. West Germans worry how much unification could cost them, either in possibly higher taxes or inflation. However, the West German government has said it won't raise taxes, and in May unveiled a nearly $70 billion German Unity Fund to be used to rebuild East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Chiefs Chairman: Don't Break Military With Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top military officer jumped into the Pentagon budget battle Friday, arguing that hasty cuts in military spending will end up ``breaking the back'' of America's defense. ``If you suddenly cash in your insurance policy to buy a so-called peace dividend, you will get neither,'' Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in a speech to the National Press Club. ``As we get smaller, we also need to get better. If we do it too fast, we don't get better _ we get hollow,'' he said, warning against a return to the post-Vietnam War and World War II reductions. Powell's blunt remarks were his first major commentary on the debate over spending for the nation's military arsenal at a time of lessened East-West tensions. A former national security adviser, Powell now serves as the president's primary military counselor and coordinator of the nations' military leaders. Powell said that even though the Berlin Wall has fallen and the Warsaw Pact has nearly evaporated, he has had to place the American military in dangerous situations during his brief stint in office. ``I have been reminded again and again since becoming chairman that this is still a dangerous world and that you'd better be able to respond if someone challenges your interests,'' he said, citing Panama, the Philippines, the Persian Gulf, Europe and Korea as examples. Powell said that despite changes in the Soviet Union, the Soviets still have the ability to destroy the United States with nuclear weapons. ``We must not confuse a decline in defense spending with a decline in the nation's enduring defense needs to deal with the enduring realities we face,'' Powell said. The four-star general said that although Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev remains ``very much in charge,'' his policies ``are sowing the seed of his own weakness.'' The Soviet Union will remain a superpower well into the next century, Powell said. ``So even as we reduce, we must maintain our ability to deter and defend,'' he said. Powell said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plan released earlier this week to cut military forces by 25 percent over five years shows ``we are willing to examine any reasonable proposal.'' But the general also defended President Bush's $303.3 billion spending plan for fiscal 1991 as ``a realistic, prudent response'' to the changing world. The administration budget blueprint, Powell said, will begin to reduce the nation's forces over time. ``On this glide path we will reach a base force which I believe is not prudent to go below if we wish to match enduring defense needs with enduring realities,'' Powell said. ``We know we will get smaller. That is inevitable, that is the correct thing to do,`' Powell said. But if Bush's budget request is cut back significantly, ``You will force us to start breaking the back of our armed forces,'' he said. The general also took aim at lawmakers who are seeking more severe cuts over a shorter period of time. Although he named no names, House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., has been sharply critical of Cheney's 25 percent plan, and Senate Armed Services Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has complained about strategic ``blanks'' in Cheney's budget. ``We are looking ahead with our eyes open. We're cutting programs. We want to close bases. We've frozen construction and hiring. We're cutting troops, and believe it or not _ we're cutting generals,'' Powell said. ``What we need are not more insights on how to trim the margins, what we need is breathing space. We need to time to make the plans work,'' Powell said.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Communists Lean Toward Conservative for Leader
DOC.TEXT: A hard-line critic of Mikhail S. Gorbachev gained the most votes Friday in the election for a new Communist Party chief in the Russian Federation and was favored to win the post in a runoff. A victory by Ivan Polozkov could turn the Communist Party in the Russian Federation _ the Soviet Union's largest republic _ into a power base for conservatives. It could also cause a split in the national Communist Party. The new leader was expected to be named Saturday. Polozkov received the most votes among seven nominees Friday, with 1,017 to 848 for moderate Oleg Lobov. Soviet journalists predicted Polozkov would win enough of the total 2,633 votes from the defeated conservatives to triumph in the runoff. Technically, all Communists are automatically considered members of both the national and republic parties. But a delegate from the Volga River city of Kuibyshev said the election of the conservative Polozkov as head of the Russian party could cause half the Communists in his area to quit. The national Communist Party congress meets in nine days to revamp its program and leadership, and many expect it to split. Just three weeks ago, radical reformer Boris Yeltsin was elected president of Russia. That gave Gorbachev a strong rival on the other side. It is not known if Gorbachev and his centrists would side with conservatives, with reformers, or head out on their own. But this week's Russian party congress made a Gorbachev alliance with hard-liners seem unlikely. They repeatedly attacked the Soviet president's reforms and applauded speakers calling for Gorbachev's replacement as head of the national party. Leaving the party job legally would not affect Gorbachev's position as president of the Soviet Union. The Russian Communist Party was re-established this week for the first time since 1925. At that time, it was absorbed into the national party partly for fear its leaders could become competitors in the struggle for power. Russia contains half the Soviet people, more than half of its Communists and three-quarters of its land. Despite Polozkov's harsh criticism of reform, Gorbachev backed him three weeks ago for president of the Russian republic against populist reformer Boris Yeltsin. In his campaign speech on Thursday, Polozkov moderated his most extreme views. Adding to the confusion, Gorbachev was beaming Friday, laughing and joking at the Russian party congress, where he has been under severe attack by hard-liners all week. Reformist Vyacheslav Bragin, a Communist Party chief from Kalinin, told the congress before the vote, ``If we elect Polozkov, it will mean the sunset of the party.'' Many delegates reacted to Bragin's speech, which also criticized the military, with derisive whistles. Gorbachev, who presided over the proceedings, quieted the delegates down but also rebuked Bragin for fostering confrontation. Lobov, 53, an ethnic Russian construction engineer and a member of the national parliament, supports Gorbachev's proposed party platform and favors transferring power from the party to the government. In his campaign speech, he said his bywords include ``Don't panic'' and ``There are no unsolvable problems.'' The government daily Izvestia said he believes the party should have a dialogue with its opponents and cooperation with local governing bodies. Polozkov, 55-year-old party chief in the southern Russian region of Krasnodar, has called for strict party discipline and has complained that older party members are not respected. He also has condemned informal political groups and has become famous for warring against the small private businesses legalized by Gorbachev. On Wednesday, he rejected reformers' calls for the party to apologize for decades of dictatorship. The 2,700 Communists of the Russian congress will be the majority of the 4,700 delegates at next month's national party congress. Reformers have complained they were bypassed in the selection of delegates.

DOC.HEAD: Bells And Banners to Welcome Mandela to Boston
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Radios rang with the African National Congress anthem Friday as Boston prepared for to celebrate Nelson Mandela's one-day visit. Green and gold billboards welcomed Mandela and his wife, Winnie, to a city that is often gripped by racial strife but is home to some of the South African freedom fighters' staunchest American supporters. The black, green and gold African National Congress Flag flew at City Hall Plaza. Last week, a city councilman objected to the flag, but his objections were brushed aside by Mayor Raymond Flynn's administration. Church bells were scheduled to ring at 11 a.m. Saturday as part of the noisy welcome organized by the Rev. Vernon Carter, a Lutheran pastor and longtime community activist. Mandela's schedule includes a visit to a Boston high school, a motorcade, a rally and free concert, a luncheon with the Kennedy family and a reception with prominent business leaders. The 71-year-old deputy head of the African National Congress, recently freed after 27 years in prison, is on a grueling six-week tour of 13 countries. He is working to raise money and keep international pressure on South Africa's government to end its policy of racial separation. Along Mandela's motorcade route through the predominantly black Roxbury section, there were few signs Friday that residents knew the anti-apartheid leader would drive through their neighborhood. A lone T-shirt salesman staked out one intersection. Carefully hung Winnie Mandela shirts provided shade for a fruit vendor's stall nearby. Connie Johnson, who is helping coordinate Mandela's visit, said the route of Mandela's motorcade hadn't been publicized for security reasons. Just a couple blocks off the route, residents of the Mandela housing development spoke Friday of their disappointment they won't be getting a visit. The motorcade won't pass the building as the tenants had wished, but the Mandela complex is visible to Mandela from his route. ``We want him to stop and wave at us,'' said Amy Port, who like many tenants is a native of Africa. Port is from Liberia. The privately owned, 22-building complex houses 1,500 blacks and Hispanics. It was officially named for the South African activist by the tenants in 1987, and Mandela is spelled out in large white letters on one of the buildings. ``Nelson Mandela would be proud of it,'' said Barbara Jones, the property manager. Organizers say up to 500,000 people may attend a star-studded free concert in Mandela's honor on the bank of the Charles River. The performers include Jackson Browne, Paul Simon, Livingston Taylor, Bobby McFerrin, and the South African group Ladysmith Black Mambazo. Actor Danny Glover and comedian-activist Dick Gregory were scheduled to attend.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Study Supports Herbal AIDS Treatment
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A controversial study by AIDS activists of a Chinese herbal treatment has produced promising early signs of stopping the AIDS virus's lethal destruction of blood cells, its organizer said Friday. The treatment, called compound Q, is being tested by a community group outside the usual control of medical schools and hospitals that ordinarily evaluate new medicines. ``At this stage, we have seen a major and dramatic change in what happens to these patients,'' said Martin Delaney. Delaney, director of San Francisco's Project Inform, said his group wanted to speed up the time-consuming process of figuring out whether potential AIDS drugs work. However, some experts said the group's data is of limited value in assessing compound Q, and one prominent physician called Delaney irresponsible for releasing his conclusion without providing data to back it up. Delaney described his group's work at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. Compound Q, a protein derived from an herbal plant root, is also being tested by researchers at the University of California, San Francisco. But doctors there said it's too soon to say whether the treatment is worthwhile. Dr. James Kahn, who is conducting that study, said Delaney's work ``doesn't invite scientific scrutiny, but it helps us focus on what's important.'' Kahn also cautioned that compound Q can have toxic, even fatal, side effects. ``This is a very dangerous drug,'' he said. In their experiment, Project Inform has tested compound Q on 46 patients for 116 days. Before the treatment, their helper T cells _ the primary target of the AIDS virus _ had been steadily declining. But after treatment, the loss stopped or even reversed itself in 38 of them. Delaney cautioned that his work does not prove that compound Q will be an effective AIDS drug, but he said, ``We don't see anything like this with AZT,'' the only AIDS drug now approved for routine use. He did not reveal basic information about the study, such as other drugs the patients were taking, how sick they were or how they were recruited. ``You are irresponsible in making such statements without providing your data,'' said Dr. Arnold Relman, editor of the New England Journal of Medicine. ``We don't know if this is just another flash in the pan or something great.'' Dr. Dan Hoth, director of the Division on AIDS at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said he did not consider Delaney to be irresponsible. But he said he worried about what sick people would make of his conclusions. ``I fear that patients, because they are so desperate, will grasp at this,'' he said. ``We simply don't know. We haven't reviewed it.'' Joel Thomas, a patient taking compound Q, said he thought the medicine had made a dramatic difference for him. ``It has literally turned my health around,'' Thomas said. ``There is a clear regression of the disease.'' Compound Q appears to work by attacking infected macrophages. These blood cells, which eat germs and debris in the bloodstream, become virus-making factories when they are invaded by HIV, the AIDs virus.

DOC.HEAD: Israel To Try Old Tactic: Seeking Non-PLO Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Israel will not wait for U.S. help in arranging peace talks but will try on its own to find Palestinians willing to negotiate without the blessing of the PLO, officials said Friday. All such efforts have failed in the past, and prominent Palestinians say the new quest is doomed without the approval of Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization. Yossi Ben Aharon, a top policy adviser to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said Israel was not dependent on the United States to arrange a dialogue with Palestinians. ``We do not need to wait for mediation. We will try to reach out to Palestinians,'' he said in an interview. ``We will not rely on one channel to try to do things that can be done by Israel.'' The effort by Israel's new right-wing Cabinet comes after the last government collapsed when its liberal and conservative members split over accepting U.S. proposals for opening Israeli-Palestinian talks in Cairo, Egypt. Secretary of State James A. Baker III wanted to include Palestinians that have been deported by Israel as a compromise to PLO demands that Palestinians not living in the occupied lands be included in the delegation. But Shamir said this amounted to indirect PLO control. Ben Aharon disputed Baker's statement Thursday that any dialogue needs ``PLO acquiesence.'' ``We are going to make a determined effort to convince our Palestinians here that the PLO option is not available,'' he said. ``We have been seeking peace for 42 years, and no one has come forward. It's a long haul, but there is no alternative.'' Palestinian sources said Defense Minister Moshe Arens has already sought to arrange meetings with influential Palestinians to explore the prospects for a formal dialogue. But most efforts to even talk about talks have failed. Arens spokesman Dan Naveh said the goal of such talks was making progress toward Israel's proposal for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. He refused to say whether Arens had succeeded in arranging any meetings, but denied Palestinian claims that he was refused by Hilmi Hanoun, mayor of the West Bank town of Tulkarem. Mansur al-Shawwa, a Gaza businessman, said he met with Brig. Gen. Arieh Ramot, head of the army-run government in Gaza. ``He told me that Israel is working towards building up a new generation of Palestinians who are willing to talk with Israel without any OK from the PLO,'' he said. Al-Shawwa said he might agree to meet Shamir or Arens but did not believe Israel would find much support among Gaza's 750,000 Palestinians. Palestinians have resisted more than 20 years of efforts by Israel to create an alternative leadership to the PLO. Since the Palestinian uprising began 30 months ago, Palestinians who cooperate with Israel have come under attack. Some 225 Palestinians have been killed by other Palestinians, most on suspicion of being informers. Ben Aharon said it may be impossible to find Palestinian partners unless the United States completely severs its dialogue with the PLO. President Bush on Wednesday suspended the 18-month-old dialogue when the group failed to condemn an aborted terrorist attack on Israel May 30. Abu Abbas, a member of the PLO executive committee and a leader of a PLO faction, claimed responsibility. Ben-Aharon said that by suspending the talks instead severing them, ``The United States has not shut the door. It has just shut the window.''

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer of Photojournalism, Sir Tom Hopkinson, Dies
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Sub last graf to correct succeeded to survived.
DOC.TEXT: Sir Tom Hopkinson, a pioneer in photojournalism who used stark, unadorned pictures to raise awareness of society's ills, has died, his family said Friday. He was 85. Hopkinson died Wednesday at Oxford, where he lived. No cause of death was given. Hopkinson was editor of the now defunct magazine Picture Post from 1940 to 1950 and was also editor of the South African magazine Drum from 1958 to 1961. After earning his master's degree at Oxford University, he worked in advertising and as a free-lance journalist. He became involved in the art of photojournalism in 1934 as assistant editor of the magazine Weekly Illustrated. Picture Post was launched in 1938 by publisher Edward Hulton, with Stefan Lorant as editor and Hopkinson as his assistant. Hopkinson took over as editor when Lorant emigrated to the United States in 1940. Hopkinson specialized in bold, observant photographs and coverage of news and social issues in Britain and abroad that depicted people's lives without gloss or gimmickry. ``We (on Pictire Post) were out to influence events in a particular direction _ that of a more just and equal society,'' Hopkinson said once in an interview. Picture Post photographs such as one by Bert Hardy of slum kids in the Scottish city in Glasgow in 1948 became classics of photojournalism. Hopkinson quit the magazine in 1950, along with reporter James Cameron, when Hulton stopped publication of a story Cameron brought back from the Korean war about mistreatment of political prisoners by South Korea. In his time at Picture Post, Hopkinson schooled a generation of young photographers and writers to link pictures and words to increase the impact of a story. The magazine folded in 1957. After leaving the magazine, Hopkinson wrote several books. From 1954 to 1956 he was features editor of the now defunct London newspaper the News Chronicle and also worked as a journalistic adviser to Independent Television's current affairs program ``This Week.'' In 1958, he accepted an invitation by Jim Bailey, the owner of Drum, to go to Johannesburg as editor of the magazine, which was aimed at black readers. He recalled his experiences with the magazine and his travels in Africa in his 1962 book ``In the Fiery Continent.'' He later moved to Nairobi, Kenya, where from 1963 to 1966 he was regional director of the International Press Institute and headed an IPI center to train black journalists. In 1967 he became a lecturer in journalism at the University of Sussex in southern England. He was a visiting professor in journalism at the University of Minnesota from 1968 to 1969. In 1970 he became director of the Center for Journalism Studies at University College in Cardiff in Wales. He was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II for his services to journalism in 1978. He is survived by his wife and three daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Wilder in Iowa _ Testing the Waters?
DOC.TEXT: Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder, the first black elected governor, campaigned Friday in the state that breeds presidential dreams but insisted he was here to stump for Iowa Democrats. Wilder was appearing around the state Friday and Saturday to campaign for Don Avenson, the Democrat seeking to unseat Republican Gov. Terry Branstad, and other candidates. He conceded one goal of his tour would be ``to speak about what I think is taking place around the country in terms of people recognizing the need to have voices articulating what the new mainstream is.'' The ``new mainstream'' is a key Wilder theme, one that enabled him to win election in a southern state that is just 19 percent black. Many Democrats view Wilder as a less threatening national candidate than the more charismatic, and radical, Jesse Jackson. As to who belongs to the new mainstream, ``There are any number of those persons around and I'd like to think I'm one of those persons,'' Wilder said. Wilder insisted he would serve out the four-year term as Virginia governor to which he was elected in November. ``I've only been elected for six months and I don't think I've established a sufficient enough record of accountability as a chief executive ... to talk about trying to lead a nation,'' said Wilder. Nevertheless, he said, it isn't too early for others to talk about the 1992 campaign. Wilder had harsh criticism for some leading Democratic contenders who seem to be keeping a low profile in light of President Bush's high approval ratings. ``I think it's bad, I think it's a mistake to believe that you can sit out for four years and come back and be a leader four years later,'' said Wilder. ``For instance, in 1992 you say `we'll just sit back and wait because who wants to run against an incumbent, it's difficult it's hard. In 1996, I'll be your leader.' ``The people need leadership now,'' said Wilder. ``This is one of the reasons I'm hoping we can frame the issues, force the dialogue.'' Asked how reporters should judge his visit to the state whose caucuses kick off the presidential season, Wilder said: ``I guess I'm a politician, I guess you'll have to judge me that way. Trust me, I'm here for the purposes of electing a good man governor.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan Surpasses U.S. as No. 1 Foreign Aid Donor
DOC.TEXT: Japan surpassed the United States to become the world's largest donor of foreign aid in 1989, providing nearly $9 billion in official development assistance, the foreign ministry said Friday. The $8.96 billion that Japan supplied to poor nations was down 1.9 percent from the previous year in dollar terms, but still put Japan in the No. 1 position, the ministry said. In yen terms, Japan's contributions to developing countries increased by 5.6 percent, according to Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development statistics cited by the ministry. Among the key donor nations in the 24-member OECD, however, Japan ranked 12th in the percentage of its gross national product spent on development aid at 0.32 percent, identical to the previous year. Norway and Denmark were in first and second place at 1.02 and 1 percent respectively, the OECD said. The United States, previously the top donor, provided $7.66 billion in foreign aid in 1989, or 0.15 percent of its GNP, the OECD said. France was next at $7.47 billion, followed by West Germany with $4.95 billion and Italy with $3.33 billion, it said. Foreign Ministry officials said Japan would continue to boost its aid budget in yen terms, but that a five-year aid plan calling for more than $50 billion in assistance in 1988-92 might be hard to fulfill because of exchange rate fluctuations, the Kyodo News Service reported.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Dismisses Mandela's Support for Radicals, Says Focus Belongs Elsewhere
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration brushed aside Nelson Mandela's support for anti-American leaders and said Friday that his meetings here next week will focus on negotiations to end apartheid in South Africa. President Bush and other administration officials will ask Mandela on Monday about his ``road map for negotiations'' with the white minority government, Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen told reporters. Cohen, who heads the department's Africa affairs bureau, said he believes agreement will be reached soon on releasing South African political prisoners and that the administration wants to know Mandela's view on subsequent steps in the democratization process. ``What happens after that?'' he asked. ``Who sits at table? What would be the format? What are his (Mandela's) constitutional ambitions? What are his economic models?'' Cohen spoke as the African National Congress leader wound up a tumultuous three-day visit to New York and prepared to head for Boston. Cohen said he disagreed with the statements of support Mandela has made for Cuban President Fidel Castro, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat. All have been accused by the United States of engaging in terrorist activities, but Mandela said the three support ``our struggle to the hilt.'' He declined to criticize their human-rights record. ``We feel that one cannot fail to take into account the human rights records in their own countries,'' Cohen said. ``Just to feel that these are good people because they are helping your cause we think is an insufficient response to human rights violations.'' Mandela's observations on Gadhafi, Castro and Arafat won't be a central element in Monday's talks, Cohen said. Mandela has said repeatedly the United States must retain the sanctions it has imposed against South Africa. To do otherwise would ease the pressure on the South African government to dismantle apartheid, he has said. Cohen said the sanctions will remain in place because South Africa has not met the congressionally mandated requirements for lifting them. He said he does not see sanctions as an important issue during the 2{ hours Mandela will spend with Bush and a subsequent meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Sanctions, Cohen said, ``are not a key element of the talks.'' The administration, he said, hopes to get clues from Mandela on how it can best support negotiations on ending apartheid.

DOC.HEAD: EC Official Says Summit's `Main Test' Will be on East-West Relations
DOC.TEXT: West European leaders will be put to the test at an upcoming summit to see if they can fall behind a common approach to East-West relations, a top official of the European Community said Friday. ``It is very important that the European Community should have an overall vision of the way in which it wants Europe to develop,'' said Jacques Delors, president of the trading bloc's executive agency. He told reporters the 12-nation community must show that it can be as ``firm, dynamic and convincing in this area'' as it is in economic and monetary fields. The ``main test'' of the summit, opening Monday in Dublin, Ireland, will be the leaders' ability to come up with a similar analysis of the changes under way on their continent and how to deal with them, he said. The test, he said, is ``to see whether (the officials are) able to respond to the challenges of a new international situation.'' The community should unite behind common positions in preparation for a 35-nation summit in Paris in December, he said. The gathering will be held as part of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a forum used in the past for discussing human rights issues. Without a united approach, Delors said he was concerned that ``the sirens (at the summit) may pull them one way or another,'' a reference to a variety of proposals being offered for reshaping Europe. He also said the leaders would discuss at the Dublin meeting whether they should put together an aid package to help Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev rescue his failing economic reform program. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand have urged their colleagues to discuss the issue at the summit. Delors declined to elaborate on possible options for the Kremlin. He said the executive body, the European Commission, was ``waiting to see how and on what terms (the leaders) wish to tackle this matter.'' ``We will be ready,'' he said. ``We have our ideas on this.'' The commission was put in charge last summer of an effort by two dozen Western countries to help Poland and Hungary. The program will be expanded next month to include some other emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. Some officials believe it is unlikely that the Soviet Union would be brought into that program because of the country's enormous size and extent of its economic woes.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega In-Law Gets 15 Years, Fine
DOC.TEXT: An in-law of ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega was sentenced to 15 years in prison for his involvement in a drug smuggling ring. Domingo Negrette, whose wife is Noriega's cousin, also was placed on probation for 15 years and fined $250,000 in Thursday's sentencing. Negrette, 26, of Miami was convicted May 30 of cocaine trafficking and grand theft. He was among 37 people charged in connection with what law enforcement officials called ``Operation Corinthian,'' so named for the Colombian nickname for high-grade marijuana. The investigation was set up to bust a large Colombian drug operation headed by Carlos Escobar, of Colombia who remains at large, prosecutors said. Undercover deputies posing as drug dealers befriended Escobar and convinced him they could provide discreet locations in rural areas of Polk County to store drugs for distribution. Negrette's defense was that he was entrapped, coerced into the drug deal by an informant working for the state.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Aims to Burn Democrats Over Flag Vote
DOC.TEXT: Republicans on Friday tried to inflict political pain on Democrats whose votes defeated President Bush's constitutional amendment against flag desecration. ``The House, the so-called people's body, has said `no' to the millions of concerned Americans who believe that Old Glory deserves one type of protection only _ and that's cultural protection,'' said Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the Senate Minority Leader. ``These guys are tone deaf to cultural anger,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House Republican Whip. The House on Thursday voted 254-177 for the amendment, 34 votes short of the two-thirds required to send the proposed change in the Constitution to the states. Democrats who led the opposition glowed in their victory over what they termed as an assault on the Bill of Rights. Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., even suggested that Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and others join the ``honor roll'' beside ``Thomas Jefferson and James Madison. '' ``What we defeated was a rather homely form of politics that will sacrifice anything, even our hallowed Constitution, to air an ad, defeat a candidate or grasp for power,'' he said. Within minutes after Thursday's vote, GOP campaign operatives sent out press releases attacking Democrats who voted against the amendment. Gingrich told reporters Friday that the Democrats ``have totally misunderstood America'' and Republicans would make that point in this fall's elections. Foley's leadership on the flag issue ``was an extraordinary mistake, politically,'' he said. Gingrich said he and House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., were meeting with veterans groups to enlist their help in defeating Democrats who voted against the amendment. ``You're going to see a systematic effort to use it, and I think it's going to be effective in some places,'' he said, especially when combined with other issues Republicans contend show a lawmaker's ``values.'' ``It's not a killer issue. By itself, it's not going to beat anybody. But for somebody whose values are in question anyway,'' he said, it could make the difference. Although the House action killed the amendment's chances for this year, the Senate is expected to start debate on Monday and is looking to vote Tuesday night. The GOP hopes to take over the Senate this fall from the Democrats, who now hold a 55-45 majority, and could make the `no' votes of liberal Democrats a factor in the races. Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, who has said he would oppose the flag amendment and who faces a challenge from Rep. Thomas Tauke, R-Iowa, on Friday introduced a bill to foster public education about the flag. But Dole said the choice would be very simple. ``We can either follow the House's lead and embrace the Beltway `know-it-alls' or we can embrace the will of the American people,'' Dole said.

DOC.HEAD: Maker of `Read My Lips' Game Donates Money for Federal Deficit
DOC.TEXT: The gesture is unlikely to make a dent in the federal deficit, but the maker of a new board game called ``Read My Lips'' thought it might be able to sell a few more games if it offered to contribute. Pressman Toy Corp. of New York has pledged to donate $1 from the sale of each $17 game to the federal government to help reduce the nation's deficit. The board game, whose title was the campaign rallying cry for President Bush in his pledge not to raise taxes, involves one partner trying to guess the words being mouthed by another. To promote its move, the company sent copies of the game to Bush and reporters in Washington. Buyers have to send the company their sales receipts and a game scorecard to put the donation into effect, said Pressman spokesman Mark Kulkis. The promotion is good from June 25 through July 4, to give the gimmick an Independence Day angle. The money that is collected will go to the Bureau of the Public Debt in Washington, the agency that accepts donations to reduce the $152 billion deficit, said Kulkis. He said the company asked whether Bush would agree to be photographed receiving a check for the amount raised, and perhaps play a couple rounds of the game. But it's unlikely that Bush will ever see the game sent to him, or receive the check in person. The company received a reply from Joe Hagin, a deputy assistant to the president, instructing that the game be sent to the White House ``gift room'', the cemetery for unsolicited gifts that come to the president from the public, said Kulkis.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Delays Unimproved Despite Reporting Program
DOC.TEXT: The percentage of delayed passenger flights has not improved since 1987 when airlines first were required to disclose their performance, a congressional study said Friday. The study by the General Accounting Office criticizes the government reporting system for failing to show how late flights are and said some flights are not accurately reported by the airlines. Since September 1987, on-time performance logged by the Transportation Department's monthly reports has ranged from a low of 66 percent in December 1987 to a high of 86 percent in September 1988. The data is based on reports airlines are required to file with the government. In 1988, 20 percent of all flights were late; last year, late flights increased to 24 percent, the GAO said. Airline industry and government officials agree that most flight delays are due to poor weather and that airport congestion is a growing factor. Delays generally are greater in winter months. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner on Thursday said that if something is not done about airport capacity, the number of airports experiencing 20,000 annual hours of delay will increase from 21 now to 39 by 1997. A flight is considered on time if it departs or arrives within 15 minutes of its scheduled time. Delays due to mechanical problems are not counted, and the GAO said the department does little to verify information about the 23,000 such flights each month. That's about 5 percent of scheduled flights. The GAO study said that the department's inspector general found last year that a tracing of sample flights of 12 major airlines showed that of 3,903 flights excluded from delay statistics because of mechanical problems, 564 should have been reported. The study also said about 4,700 flights a month are cancelled for non-mechnical reasons but are reported simply as late flights and put in the same category as those running more than 15 minutes behind. Some of the non-mechanical cancellations, the GAO said, are caused when a flight is cancelled for mechanical problems and other flights schedules are adjusted to accommodate the most passengers possible. The GAO recommended changes in the reporting system to include the reasons for non-mechanical delays.

DOC.HEAD: Government Declares Rare Owl Threatened; Timber Jobs in Jeopardy
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 6 grafs after 9th graf pvs, The estimated, to add Congress, environmental reaction; picks up 10th graf pvs, Turner said
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX19
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department, citing evidence the northern spotted owl may become extinct, ordered the reclusive bird protected Friday as a threatened species, putting thousands of logging jobs into jeopardy. The decision was expected to dramatically curtail logging across millions of acres of virgin forests in the Pacific Northwest, where intense clearing of ancient trees over decades has destroyed the owl's habitat and put its survival into question. But the government said the region's jobs complicated the issue and postponed an announcement of a specific owl recovery plan on what logging restrictions will be required to protect the brown bird. An announcement on the forest management plan was expected next week. ``The biological evidence says that the northern spotted owl is in trouble,'' said John Turner, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, who made the decision to declare the owl threatened under the Endangered Species Act. ``We will not, and by law cannot, ignore that evidence.'' Industry and government estimates said as many as 28,000 timber industry jobs could be lost in the next decade and entire logging communities disrupted by restrictions to protect the owl. Environmentalists who have fought to protect the owl say those estimates are exaggerated. ``Our intention now is to find ways to protect the owl with the least possible disruption to the timber economy in the Pacific Northwest,'' said Turner. He said he is convinced ``there is room to protect both the owl and loggers.'' The estimated 3,000 to 5,000 pairs of remaining northern spotted owls are scattered in old-growth forest in Washington, Oregon and northern California _ an area that also accounts for by far the largest supply of lumber in this country. The decision brought mixed response from Congress. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said the designation ``recognizes the mistakes of the past which allowed massive clear-cutting of our last remaining ancient forests.'' But congressmen from the Northwest states urged that loggers and the local communities not be forgotten in developing an owl recovery plan. ``We have to protect the environment and maintain the livelihood of our people. ... Finding the balance will be difficult,'' said Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., adding that ``every man, woman and child (in his state) is going to be affected'' by the decision. Some environmentalists, meanwhile, cautioned that the future of the bird may depend on how aggressively the Bush administration seeks to curtail timber cutting in owl recovery plan. ``Our concern is ... if they do not put appropriate restrictions on timber harvesting today's listing decision will be gutted and it will be meaningless,'' said Frances Hunt of the National Wildlife Federation. Turner said ``compelling evidence shows that the spotted owl is at risk'' of extinction if current logging practices continue and more forest is destroyed in the three states. Although the decision to protect the owl is expected to have widespread impact on logging, Turner said he does not foresee significant disruption of this summer's harvesting of Northwest timber. ``Planned logging is going to go on and with very little disruption,'' said Turner. Timber cutting under current contracts with the government would proceed, he said. The effective date of Turner's listing of the owl as threatened goes into effect July 23. About 90 percent of the remaining spotted owls live in forests owned by the federal government and managed by either the U.S. Forest Service or Interior's Bureau of Land Management. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter are to announce next Tuesday a plan aimed at protecting the owl on the government lands and at the same time ``reduce the disruption'' to logging communities. ``Our plan will be to achieve a balance,'' said Interior spokesman Steve Goldstein. The management plan, which is envisioned to include curbs on logging, must be approved by the Fish and Wildlife Service to assure it provides protection to the bird. Private landowners seeking to cut in areas where the owl lives will also have to take steps to limit the impact on owl habitat, officials said. Designation of a species as threatened makes it illegal to harm any of the owls or destroy their critical habitat without federal government approval. A threatened species is one that is likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future. It is afforded similar protections as species classified as endangered. The protection applies to owl on both private and government land. Under some circumstances private land owners may petition to cut in areas occupied by the owl. Federal agencies may not allow cutting on federal lands unless a tree harvesting plan has been approved by the Fish and Wildlife Service. The decision to protect the owl represents a reversal by the Fish and Wildlife Service which for many years refused to list the bird and had to be forced by a federal court in 1988 to reconsider the status of the owl.

DOC.HEAD: Young Soldier Gets Death Sentence for Killing Liberian Civilian
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grear is correct
DOC.TEXT: A young soldier was convicted of killing a Liberian civilian and sentenced to death Friday, and an Israeli-trained presidential guard was ordered jailed for 10 years for shooting an American. They were the first government troops sentenced in a wave of violence against civilians that began after rebels invaded Liberia in late December. Many slayings have been tribal reprisals against people accused of supporting the rebels trying to oust President Samuel Doe. Pvt. James M. Grear, 24, hung his head but showed no other emotion when he received the death sentence from a court-martial sitting at the Barclay Training Center, Monrovia's main army barracks. He is scheduled to be executed by firing squad early Saturday. Court president, Col. Isaac Nyeplu, presiding over a three-man board, read charges that Grear shot and killed Edward Welmongah on April 7 after an argument outside an oceanside nightclub near downtown. Grear admitted killing Welmongah ``because the deceased made him vexed,'' Nyeplu said. Pvt. Alphonso G. Kahn, the second soldier, was found guilty of manslaughter in the death of Joseph Martin Millay, an American aircraft mechanic in his 20s. Millay died of a heart attack on the operating table nearly two days after being shot in the leg on April 4 by Kahn. Kahn, 25, belongs to the Israeli-trained Special Anti-Terrorist Unit of the presidential guard. The court is set to convene again Monday to hear the case of three other soldiers accused of butchering three civilians, including sculpture R. Vanjah Richards. The public has not been allowed into the trial since opening day. The insurgency, led by Charles Taylor, has escalated into a tribal conflict since the rebels invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast six months ago. Most rebels are from the Gio and Mano tribes, while government supporters are mostly Krahns and Mandingos. Doe himself is a Krahn. The rebels, who have been advanced for weeks toward the capital, are now fighting around Careysburg, 15 miles from Monrovia. Panicked Monrovians have been fleeing the capital by the thousands. Rebels accuse Doe of corruption and rights abuses. Doe took power in a violent 1980 coup that ousted the descendents of American slaves who founded the West African nation in 1847. The American descendents historically monopolized power and discriminated against indigenous Liberians. In Brussels Friday, the European Community's executive commission announced it has sent more than $2 million in medical aid to Liberian refugees.
Eds: DISREGARD a0664, which duplicate a0662, AM-Iran-Rally.
DOC.HEAD: The AP, Washington
Student Who Addressed Tiananmen Square Anniversary Rally Expelled
DOC.TEXT: A student who addressed a Beijing University rally marking the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators has been expelled, a school official said Friday. An official of the Students Office said Li Minqi, a 21-year-old economics major, had been expelled from school days earlier. Li was the only student to deliver a speech during a spontaneous campus rally by hundreds of students on the night of June 3 to protest the brutal military suppression of the student-led pro-democracy movement a year earlier. The school official, who declined to give her name, could not confirm reports from Hong Kong that Li had been detained by police and charged with making anti-government speeches. An official at the Public Security Bureau said he did not know whether Li had been arrested. In his speech to the rally, Li denounced government corruption and exploitation of workers and called on Communist authorities to return factories to the workers and treat intellectuals with more respect. Large police and military forces had been deployed around the city to prevent any commemorations of the anniversary, and the Beijing University rally was the only group protest to be held. Party officials at the campus said the students had been influenced by ``foreign and domestic reactionaries.'' Li fled the campus on June 4, but sources at the university said he returned June 5 and was attending classes while waiting for university authorities to decide his fate. Tiananmen Square in central Beijing was the focal point of last year's pro-democracy demonstrations. Troops occupied the square on the night of June 3-4, and hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of people were killed in the ensuing violence.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Meatpacker Recalls 20,000 Pounds of Frankfurters
DOC.TEXT: J.M. Schneider Inc. of Ontario, Canada, is voluntarily recalling 20,000 pounds of frankfurters distributed to retail grocery stores in the Northeast because the meat may be contaminated, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Officials said the recalled franks are suspected of being contaminated by Listeria monocytogenes, which can cause listeriosis, a potentially serious disease. The product, labeled ``Schneider's Franks,'' is sold in one-pound plastic packages. The words ``Canada 35'' appear inside the inspection seal on the label. All bearing the ``Best before'' date of ``Jul 03'' are being recalled. ``Although no illnesses have been reported, we urge consumers to return the suspect franks to the place of purchase,'' said Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. None of the company's other products is involved in the recall. The problem with the franks was discovered May 31 during a routine USDA import re-inspection in Buffalo, N.Y. Laboratory tests confirmed the bacterial contamination on June 20, said agency spokesman Jim Greene. ``In general, healthy people are believed to be at little risk from listeriosis,'' the announcement said. ``Most vulnerable are those with weakened immune systems _ infants, the elderly and the chronically ill. Listeriosis in pregnant women can cause miscarriage.'' Symptoms in adults include the sudden onset of flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, backache and sometimes abdominal pain and diarrhea, it said. In newborns, symptoms include respiratory distress, refusal to drink and vomiting. Consumers with questions about the recall may phone the toll-free USDA hotline at 1-800-535-4555 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EDT, Monday through Friday. At other times a recording will provide information. Washington, D.C., area consumers can call 447-3333.
Eds: DISREGARD a0683 which duplicates a0682, AM-Airline on Time.
DOC.HEAD: The AP, Washington
Rival Christian Forces in Lebanon Clash, Young Girl Slain
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces clashed with artillery and mortars in east Beirut on Friday, killing a young girl, and a French envoy continued trying to mediate an end to the 4{-month-old conflict. Police said three other women, including the dead girl's sister, were wounded in pre-dawn fighting between troops of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and militiamen led by Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces before it died down. The sisters were hit when a mortar round, fired by Aoun's gunners, landed on their house in East Beirut's Sin el-Fil district, controlled by the Lebanese Forces. By police count, 1,044 people have been killed and 2,789 wounded since the Aoun-Geagea power struggle for control of the small Christian enclave broke out Jan. 30. The fighting has forced more than 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million inhabitants to flee to safer areas or leave the country. French envoy Francois Scheer on Friday crossed from west Beirut, where he met with government leaders, into the Christian sector of the divided Lebanese capital to meet with Aoun. Scheer briefed Aoun on the reactions of Syrian and Lebanese leaders to France's six-day effort to implement an Arab League-brokered peace pact to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war between Christians and Moslems. He later returned to west Beirut to catch a plane bound for Paris. Shortly before his departure Scheer said he conveyed to President Elias Hrawi's government proposals from Aoun. He refused to disclose further details. Scheer, director-general of France's Foreign Ministry, arrived in Beirut late Monday. The Christian rivals have been fighting continually since then despite a nominal, month-old cease-fire. Scheer held a series of meetings with Lebanese leaders then made an overnight visit to Damascus Wednesday to meet Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa.The French envoy returned to Beirut Thursday for further talks with Lebanese leaders. The peace accord was endorsed by the Lebanese Parliament last October. Syrian-backed Lebanese President Elias Hrawi was elected Nov. 24 to implement the accord, which shares power equally between the long-dominant Christians, and Moslems _ now 55 percent of the 4 million population. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi and rejects the peace accord because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops, in Lebanon since 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate. The general's actions have blocked Hrawi's efforts to extend his authority to the Christian enclave and put constitutional reforms into effect. Geagea, whose militia is the largest Christian private army in Lebanon, has recognized Hrawi and termed the peace accord ``a gateway'' to national reconciliation.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Treaty on German Unification, Resolution on Poland
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of the treaty that prepares the economic merger of the two Germanys in July, and the separate resolution recognizing Poland's borders.

OVERVIEW _ The two Germanys agreed to create a monetary, economic and social union as a first step to unification under the West German constitution. The international implications of the merger must be resolved in talks among the four victorious World War II powers _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France.

MONETARY UNION _ On July 1, the West German mark becomes the legal tender in East Germany, but because that day is a Sunday, actual implementation will be July 2. The West German Bundesbank, or central bank, will have control over monetary policy in both countries. The economic union will be based on a free-market economy.

CONVERSION RATES _ Workers will have their wages converted from East German marks to West German marks at a 1-1 rate. For savings deposits, East Germans 14 and younger will be able to convert up to $1,200 at a 1-1 rate. Those aged 15-59 will be able to convert $2,400 at the 1-1 rate. People 60 and older can covert up $3,600 at the favorable rate. All other savings will be converted at two East marks for one West mark. East German pensions will be brought to West German levels, raising most of them. Debts will be converted at a 2-1 rate, more favorable to troubled East German companies.

BORDER RESOLUTION _ In a separate resolution, the parliaments of East and West Germany recognized Poland's Western border, delineated by the Oder-Neisse rivers. The resolution said ``both sides declare that they will not raise territorial claims now or in the future.'' The resolution was necessary to generate international support or the rapidly approaching unification. About one-third of present day Poland is former German territory lost after World War II. Poles feared a united Germany might try to reclaim the land, a wish of many ultraconservative German voters who considered it rightful German property.

DOC.HEAD: Government Lawyer Says Barry Found Slumped Near Drug Paraphernalia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 3rd pvs, Mcwilliams, who, to raise Santa Claus reference; INSERTS two grafs after penultimate graf pvs, ``I didn't, to ADD Lewis associate's testimony
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for the city government testified in Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial Friday that he found the mayor slumped one night in a bathroom littered with drug paraphernalia. ``The smoke and the ... smell ... got stronger as the evening went on,'' said James McWilliams, recalling a December 1988 night he spent with Barry and key prosecution witness Charles Lewis at a Washington hotel room. McWilliams, who is cooperating with prosecutors after pleading guilty to drug-related charges, backed up testimony from Lewis about the evening of alleged crack cocaine use by the three-term mayor. McWilliams said he went to Lewis' room that night to discuss a job transfer with the mayor. But the bearded McWilliams said that as he pressed his case, Barry just told him at one point, ``you know, you look a lot like Santa Claus.'' A legal counsel for the city's Department of Public Works, McWilliams testified he helped Lewis and Barry hide the alleged drug use from police investigators ``because I was protecting Marion Barry.'' Barry, 54, is facing three felony charges of perjury, 10 misdemeanor charges of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor count of conspiracy to possess cocaine. He has pleaded innocent. Lewis, a convicted drug dealer, testified earlier this week that he used drugs with Barry repeatedly between 1986 and 1988 and smoked crack cocaine with him on four occasions in Lewis' Washington room, including Dec. 19, 1988. McWilliams said he went to Lewis' room that night to talk discuss a job transfer with the mayor. But Lewis first asked McWilliams for $40 to ``got out and get some stuff,'' McWilliams testified, ``I understood he was going to go out and get some drugs'' with the money, said McWilliams. Lewis came back with a plastic bag ``that had a white substance inside,'' he said. Barry, who he said arrived later, then went repeatedly with Lewis into the bathroom and kitchen. Smoke and ``a strong unusual smell'' from the bathroom grew as McWilliams watched Monday Night Football, McWilliams testified. ``What did they say when they came back'' from the bathroom? asked assistant U.S. attorney Richard Roberts. That ``this is good stuff ... I will go back and have another hit,'' replied McWilliams, quoting Barry and Lewis. McWilliams, a former assistant attorney general in the Virgin Islands, said he tried to talk to Barry about the job transfer, but ``I didn't think I was getting through.'' In the bathroom, an arms-length from the mayor, a vanity was littered with matches, white residue in a plastic bag and a tin-foil-covered glass, testified McWilliams. The mayor ``appeared restful, peaceful,'' McWilliams said. ``He was sitting on the commode and he was just slumped over a little bit. I kept making my pitch about the job. ``He looked up and said, `you know, you look a lot like Santa Claus,''' testified McWilliams, whose beard is heavily streaked with gray. McWilliams never said, however, that he saw Barry using drugs. McWilliams said he didn't use drugs himself. McWilliams also backed up parts of Lewis' testimony that Lewis and the mayor conspired to hide their alleged acts as a police investigation closed in on Lewis, saying he acted as a go-between for Lewis and Barry. McWilliams said he lied to police when detectives interviewed him about his visit to Lewis' room. ``I didn't tell the truth because I was protecting Marion Barry,'' he said. Barry was ``someone who I respected'' and the mayor's ``services to the city and civil rights were something I considered important,'' he testified. Testifying after McWilliams, a long-time friend of Lewis' said he hosted Lewis over the Christmas weekend in the days just after Barry and Lewis found out about the police investigation. John W. Olsen testified that Lewis called the mayor Dec. 23 and assured him, ``I've got things under control, I will take care of business.'' McWilliams pleaded guilty in January to aiding and abetting Lewis' possession of cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Romania, and Weeping Iliescu, Marks Six Months Since Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Six months after the violent revolution that overthrew Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, his successor stood and wept Friday by the graves of those killed in the fighting. Official observances and prayer services marked the half-year anniversary of the revolution. But among many Romanians there was a sense of uncertainty about the future following last week's crackdown on anti-government demonstrators in which six people died and hundreds were injured. Ion Iliescu, sworn in as president on Wednesday, and Premier Petre Roman laid wreaths at the Young Heroes' Cemetery, where students and other young people killed in battles with Ceausescu's security forces are buried. According to the official death toll, at least 1,033 people were killed in the December revolt. At the cemetery in southwest Bucharest, the crowd observed a minute of silence as Iliescu wept by the graves. Earlier, he exchanged brief remarks with mourning relatives. Iliescu and Radu Campeanu, leader of the opposition National Liberal Party, were among those attending a memorial service at Bucharest's Patriarhie Cathedral. Patriarch Teoctist, spiritual leader of the Romanian Orthodox Church, told the worshipers that remembering the heroes of the revolution provides ``a moment of reflection over our consciousness and life.'' Despite better-stocked food stores and an influx of imported Sony TV sets and JVC video recorders for the first time, some people felt the revolution's aims were unfulfilled. ``At least if we knew why these people had to die. We do not really enjoy peace,'' said Iuliana Vasiliu, who mourned at the grave of her son, Florentin, 37. Bucharest residents joined the revolution on Dec. 21. Ceausescu was ousted on Dec. 22 and executed three days later together with his wife, Elena. ``I do not think George would have been happy to see the latest developments,'' said Iolanda Radulescu about her brother, who was killed in December and buried in the Young Heroes' Cemetery. ``He did not die just to see us hate and beat each other,'' she said, referring to the riots that started June 13 when police broke up a 53-day anti-government demonstration in Bucharest's main square. The demonstrators had been demanding the ouster of Iliescu, accusing him and other government officials of being neo-Communists. Iliescu was a former Communist Party secretary who fell into disfavor with Ceausescu. After angry crowds attacked official buildings, Iliescu appealed to workers to help defend the government. Thousands of loyalist miners heeded the appeal, attacking political foes, students and bystanders throughout Bucharest. In addition to the six dead, more than 500 were injured. The government said more than 1,000 people were detained, including student leaders, most of whom have been released. In another development Friday, Ceausescu's sister, Maria Agache, went on trial under charges of fraud involving public property and abuse of privilege. A brief report by the state Rompres news agency did not provide further details, but knowledgeable Romanians said Ms. Agache had amassed a fortune by buying and selling property illegally. Her trial started a day after the Supreme Court sentenced Nicolae Andruta Ceausescu, a general and one of Ceausescu's five brothers, to 15 years in prison for inciting mass murder and attempted aggravated murder during the revolution. He had said he was innocent of charges that he shot at demonstrators in Bucharest on Dec. 21.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Showers Sweep Over Much of the Nation
DOC.TEXT: Summer showers and thunderstorms swept through New England and much of the South and the nation's midsection Friday, ripping down power lines and tossing trees. The showers and thunderstorms reached across northern and central New England early Friday afternoon. The storms also rumbled through parts of North and South Dakota and across Minnesota, Iowa, Missouri, Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Virginia, North and South Carolina and Georgia. At least one tornado was reported as swift-moving thunderstorms whipped through central and eastern North Carolina, knocking out power to 25,000 Wake County residents and causing three fires, officials said. The storm dumped torrents of rain and stirred up winds that reached 48 mph at the Raleigh-Durham International Airport. But within a half-hour of the storm's arrival, it had moved on. The wind gusts over North Carolina damaged trees and power lines in northeast Johnston County and Person County, as well as at Wake Forest, south of Oxford and near Jackson.
