Trees were toppled onto most major highways in central Iredell County. Thunderstorms and wind also ripped down several trees near Hickory Tavern, S.C. Temperatures across Georgia cooled as a series of thunderstorms moved across the state, but the rain was spotty. Five Georgia cities recorded temperatures above the 100-degree mark Thursday, the first day of summer, but temperatures were generally in the 80s and 90s Friday afternoon. Rain showers and thunderstorms also stretched across Florida, Alabama, Mississippi and southern Louisiana. Rain and thundershowers were scattered over eastern and southwest Washington and northwest Oregon. Locally heavy rain from thunderstorms brought urban flooding to northeast and east central Wisconsin. The low temperature for the nation Friday morning was 31 degrees at Jackson, Wyo. Temperatures in the Lower 48 states at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 55 degrees at Sawyer Air Force Base at Marquette, Mich., to 107 degrees at both Palm Springs, Calif., and Phoenix, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Industry Decries `Threatened' Listing; Environmentalists Cautious
With AM-Spotted Owl, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The northern spotted owl's listing as a threatened species marks ``a dark day in the history of the Pacific Northwest,'' leading loggers said Friday. Environmentalists said the listing was long overdue, adding they wanted to see what steps federal agencies would take to protect the uncut forests where the two-foot-tall brown bird lives. The Interior Department, citing evidence the owl may become extinct, ordered the reclusive bird protected as a threatened species Friday. But it postponed until Tuesday an announcement of a plan that will determine how much logging is to be permitted in the owl's habitat. ``The listing by itself will not protect the owl or the ancient forests,'' said Melanie Rowland of the Wilderness Society's office in Seattle. ``The key is what the agencies are going to do, and how much politics interferes with biology.'' Members of the Northwest Forest Resource Council, which represents the timber companies and 131,000 workers, told a news conference they would seek to limit the bans on logging by emphasizing the economic impact of setting aside land for owls. The government estimates that as many as 28,000 timber industry jobs could be lost in the next decade in Oregon, Washington and northern California. Entire logging communities could be disrupted by the logging restrictions. The listing ``represents a dark day in the history of the Pacific Northwest,'' said Gary Jones, president of Summit Timber Co. While the Endangered Species Act requires listing of a species be made on scientific evidence alone, it has a provision that gives an endangered species committee, including Cabinet members and other state and federal officials, the power to modify how the listing is enacted. Jones said the council was considering a lawsuit against the Fish and Wildlife Service, and would probably go to court if plans to protect the owl failed to provide sufficient protection for logging. Environmentalists said the declaration should mark the end of an era. ``The timber frontier is over,'' said Rick Johnson of the Sierra Club. ``This is the clear indication where you cannot go over the next hillside and have something to cut. We have a limited and finite timber base and we have to have some understanding of the consequences of what that logging will have.'' People in the logging towns claim that environmental groups, many of whose constituents are urban dwellers, don't understand how damaging the decision will be to a way of life. ``It's like Boeing leaving Seattle. What would that be like?'' said Jerry Leppell, president of the American Loggers Solidarity Committee in Forks. Timber is the leading industry in Oregon and also is key in Washington. The governors of both states said they would lobby against overly strict owl recovery plans. ``Federal legislation is needed to protect some old-growth forests while allowing logging to continue without administrative delays in others,'' said Oregon Gov. Neil Goldschmidt. Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington said the ruling ``presents a challenge to the Northwest. Clearly, what the timber communities and workers need is assurance of an ongoing and adequate timber supply.'' He said the federal government should provide special assistance to communities hurt by the decision. According to a federal study, at least 8.4 million acres of the timberlands should be preserved as habitat to save the owl from extinction. The area is equivalent to a swath about 5 miles wide stretching from Los Angeles to New York City. About 5.4 million acres of owl habitat already are in national parks or wilderness areas off limits to logging, so an additional 3 million acres would have to be withdrawn.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Would Bar Imports of Flags
DOC.TEXT: Two lawmakers who opposed one another on a constitutional amendment banning desecration of the flag joined forces Friday to support a measure to end imports of U.S. flags, most of which come from Taiwan. Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas, voted against the proposed constitutional amendment on Thursday. Rep. Harley O. Staggers Jr., D-W.Va., voted for it. On Wednesday they introduced a bill of their own to ban imported flags. On Thursday the proposed amendment failed to get the necessary three-fourths vote in the House, despite strong support from President Bush. At Alamo Flags in Dallas, Texas, a major dealer, an employee said imported flags were much cheaper. An aide to Bryant said 90 percent of them came from Taiwan and smaller quantities from China and Hong Kong. He added that when Bush, a fellow Texan, went into Bryant's district two years ago to campaign against him, Bush supporters were waving flags made in Taiwan. The Senate will vote on the proposed amendment Tuesday but its vote will have no practical effect and no further action on the propoal is likely this year. The issue is expected to be widely used during the campaign leading to the congressional elections in November. During the debate on Thursday, when it seemed likely that the proposed amendment would be defeated, Bryant and Staggers sent letters to the other members of the House, seeking co-sponsors for their bill. An aide to Bryant said Friday that there had been no response yet. The bill would set up an official United States Flag Commission to regulate the manufacture and use of flags. ``The commission may only grant a license to manufacture official flags of the United States if such flag will be manufactured in the United States,'' the bill says. The Commerce Department reported that the United States imported 321,877 flags in the first four months of this year, more than twice as many as the 132,667 brought in during all of 1989. The Bryant-Staggers bill would punish with a $5,000 fine the sale of a flag not made in the United States. Anyone already owning such a flag could submit it to the commission for designation as an ``official flag''. The bill also calls for a 1-year prison sentence and a fine of $5,000 for anyone ``who knowingly mutilates, burns, tramples upon, or otherwise damages an official flag of the United States.'' The Supreme Court has declared unconstitutional two laws with similar provisions to this, prompting the unsuccessful effort to pass a constitutional amendment. The new bill says a flag may be burned if it's no longer in condition for display.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela Condemns `Necklacing'
LaserPhotos staffing
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Winnie Mandela on Friday condemned ``necklacing'' and said a statement she made on South African militants' practice of killing with burning tires had been reported out of context. The wife of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela made the comment in a morning interview with Phil Donahue, whose syndicated talk show was to air in some areas of the country Friday and others on Monday. Mrs. Mandela later had lunch with the U.N. African Mothers' Association, and in the afternoon spoke at a Brooklyn church symposium of about 200 women active in civic and religious organizations. They included Joyce Dinkins, the mayor's wife; Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger; Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman; Hazel Dukes, head of the local NAACP; Betty Shabazz, Malcolm X's widow; and ``Mother'' Clara Hale, founder of a Harlem home for babies sick from crack, AIDS and other maladies. Mrs. Mandela later attended a tribute at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where she listened to Sweet Honey in the Rock, an acapella group known for its songs calling for black liberation. In brief remarks, Mrs. Mandela said the ANC would go to war if negotiations to end apartheid stall. ``If talks fall apart and they very well might, we know you will be there to take up arms with us,'' Mrs. Mandela told the sold-out crowd of 2,000. Much of the audience jumped out of their seats with shouts of support for her statement. Speaking at the earlier church meeting, Mrs. Mandela described the social problems encumbering blacks in South Africa, including a high infant mortality rate, inadequate health care and schools. ``Poverty and disease are the everyday companions of our people,'' she said. ``This is our legacy, a legacy of apartheid.'' ``In South Africa, we believe that if the women were in the forefront, we would have long won our freedom,'' she said, winning a roar of appreciation from the 200 women. In her comments on the Donahue program, Mrs. Mandela condemned ``necklacing'' _ killing government collaborators by putting a gasoline-soaked burning tire around his neck _ as ``brutal and barbaric.'' The practice has been employed by some militants in confrontations between rival groups in South Africa's black shantytowns. Mrs. Mandela was quoted as telling a rally in South Africa in 1986: ``With our boxes of matches and our necklaces, we shall liberate this country.'' She reiterated Friday her claim that the comment was quoted out of context. ``Our children have been so oppressed and met up with such violence from the government that they have resorted to that method of eliminating their enemies,'' she said. ``That was not the form or method approved by the ANC. No sane person would ever approve of that.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Propose Withdrawal of German Troops; U.S. Rejects Idea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with details of Shevardnanze's statement, diplomats interpretation, minor editing. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Baker replied ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said Friday that a united Germany would have the right to eventually join NATO but only after a five-year transition period during which all Soviet and U.S. troops would leave the country. The United States, supported by the Western Allies, rejected the plan as a delaying tactic. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze made the proposal during unification talks involving the four World War II Allies and the two German states. Shevardnadze also proposed pulling U.S. Soviet, British and French troops out of Berlin within six months of a German merger, which could take place by the end of year. At a news conference afterward, Shevarnadze said, ``We would like to build a new Europe without military confrontation.'' But Secretary of State James A. Baker III told reporters the plan would leave Berlin, which is expected to become Germany's capital again, surrounded by 380,000 Soviet troops. As for all of Germany, Shevardnadze proposed a 50 percent reduction in foreign forces over five years from East and West Germany, and then over an unspecified period removing all of them except ``token contingents.'' Over a five-year transitional period, Shevardnadze said, East and West Germany would be obliged to maintain ``all concluded international treaties and agreements'' now in effect. Western diplomats interpreted this statement as a Soviet attempt to delay NATO membership for the merged Germany. However, Shevardnadze went on to say that afterward, ``the united Germany within its rights can conclude international agreements unhindered by other considerations.'' He thereby gave approval to the Germans' right to join any alliance after the five-year period. Baker replied: ``Why not let the sovereign, unified Germany make that decision?'' He said the withdrawal of foreign forces should not be imposed on the Germans in the final settlement to be worked out by the Allies _ the United States, Britain, France and Soviet Union _ and the East German and West German foreign ministers. The question of a united Germany's military stance is the biggest obstacle to that agreement. The United States wants the new country to be a member of the Western alliance, NATO. The Soviet Union opposes NATO membership for Germany. Currently, West Germany is in NATO and East Germany is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Shevardnadze's plan would have the effect of delaying full sovereignty for a united Germany since during the five-year transition period, it could not declare itself a member of NATO. A U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said U.S. officials objected to the five-year time limit before Germany could join NATO. The official said the other Western ministers expressed the same reservations. A senior West German official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told reporters his government was opposed to a transition period but that there might be room for a ``winding-down process.'' A senior British offical, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said that ``everyone rejected the idea of a transition period.'' The British official said that a united Germany must have ``full sovereignity'' and not be subject to discriminatory treatment. Despite the disagrement, Shevardnadze said he expected the Allies would reach agreement on German unification by the end of this year. The two German nations already are planning joint elections for December. On another difficult issue, the ministers agreed to meet in Paris on July 17 to consider Poland's concern about its border with Germany. Poland is concerned that lands ceded to it from Germany after World War II may be lost to reunification. Shevardnadze said his proposal regarding troops on German soil was an outline on which the Kremlin was prepared to compromise. It also contained the following provisions: 1. The united Germany must not produce, possess, receive or deploy nuclear, chemical or biological weapons. 2. The Four Power occupation of Berlin that has existed since World War II would end within six months of the formation of a single German government. 3. The final settlement being drafted by the six nations should propose measures to limit the size of Germany's armed forces. 4. NATO and the Warsaw Pact would agree on a new code of conduct toward each other in which the two alliances no longer would be ``potential military adversaries.''

DOC.HEAD: 2 Lions Escape from Circus; Mauling Kills 1, Injures 3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with 1 dead; picks up 3rd, `The incident...'
DOC.TEXT: One man was killed and three people were seriously wounded when they were mauled by two lions that escaped from a traveling circus, the government news agency Telam reported Friday. The lions were shot and killed by police. The incident occurred Thursday evening in this town 90 miles north of Buenos Aires. The lions apparently got loose as the Acari Circus was departing for a show in another village. Each lion wandered into a private home and attacked two occupants, according to Radio San Pedro.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Separatists Hack to Death 62 Moslems in Sri Lanka
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD details, color from war zone, background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Tamil separatist guerrillas hacked to death 62 Moslem men, women and children in eastern Sri Lanka on Friday after accusing them of being government informants. A Defense Ministry official and a Moslem leader said the village massacre at Nintavur came on the 11th day of an increasingly violent war between Tamil guerrillas and Sri Lankan forces for control of the northeast. The separatists are also believed to have gunned down 278 unarmed policemen last week. In the north, rebel forces overran one army base and attacked four other strategic government garrisons. Ethnic strife between Tamils and Sinhalese spread to south and central Sri Lanka. Military officials said at least 139 more people died in fighting that has already left more than 1,400 people dead. The government announced more than 210,000 people had fled the bloodshed, seeking shelter in temporary refugee camps in schools, temples, churches and mosques across Sri Lanka. Troops found the bodies of 62 Moslem men, women and children in Nintavur, a village 28 miles south of Batticaloa town, a Defense Ministry statement said. Corpses were found floating inside water wells. Military officials said rebels used knives to kill the villagers instead of guns so the noise wouldn't alert security forces posted nearby. Survivors said the rebels raided the village early Friday because they feared villagers would reveal the site of their jungle hideout, according to Mahroof Gani, an official of the Sri Lanka Moslem Congress, an opposition party. Earlier this week, government attacks in the east pushed the rebels into the jungle. ``It was a slaughter of innocent Moslem men, women and children,'' Gani said, calling the rebels ``bloodthirsty criminals.'' He said after killing villagers, the rebels set fire to a mosque, looted and burned down the village's 150 houses and left placards written in red paint warning Moslems not to work for the government. The government on Thursday claimed its troops had captured the strategic east coast region from the Tamil Tigers, who are fighting for a separate Tamil homeland. The rebels contend Tamils are discriminated against by the Sinhalese majority. But an Associated Press reporter who visited the area on Thursday and Friday found the rebels appeared to control large parts of the region. The coastal town of Batticaloa, which the government claimed to have captured, was virtually deserted. In Batticaloa, the three-story police station, gutted by a fire set by Tamil rebels, was empty and shops were boarded up. Several people roamed the streets searching for food, which residents say is running short after nearly two weeks of fighting. Government troops only controlled an airstrip on Batticaloa's outskirts. On the roads, rebels could be seen driving tractor trailers, loaded with looted food, soap and other essentials. A 25-year-old rebel leader, who identified himself only as Newton, said the Tigers had withdrawn from most of the major towns in the east and were readying for guerrilla war. ``From now on there will be no negotiations. We will ambush and attack government troops,'' he said, cocking his new Chinese-made automatic rifle as he spoke to reporters in Pullamalia, a village near Batticaloa. Eight miles away, Sinhalese police peered warily from their bunkers in Maha Oya. No one was allowed in or out of the town without police permission. Tamil rebels took reporters on a tour of the east coast region in an effort to show they were still in control. At Periyaparativu, a village 12 miles south of Batticaloa, most of the 300 homes were gutted. Rebels and some villagers claimed the homes had been destroyed by government troops before they withdrew. ``When the army came here last week, the people fled. When they withdrew, we returned,'' said a 26-year-old Tamil university student. The Tamil Tigers have been waging a seven-year insurgency to set up a separate state in the north and east where Tamils predominate. The fighting flared again on June 11 when the rebels abrogated a 13-month-old cease-fire by attacking police stations after a Tamil civilian complained he was manhandled by Sinhalese police. Tamils, who are predominantly Hindu, make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The Buddhist Sinhalese comprise 75 percent, while Moslems constitute seven percent.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Inspector General Slams Plan For State-backed Art Museum
DOC.TEXT: A $77.5 million plan to convert a vacant electronics mill into the world's largest contemporary art museum is a ``risky venture'' that won't work, a state official said. ``In my view, it's not legal,'' Inspector General Joseph Barresi said Friday in a telephone interview from his Boston office. Barresi is responsible for pointing out fraud and waste in government. In a report released Thursday, Barresi said the city of North Adams had ``no credible plan'' to raise the more than $10 million required as its share for the first phase of construction. Without that money, the state cannot legally proceed with any spending for construction, Barresi said. Bids were scheduled to be let this year. He also contended a proposed plan to have a private developer build the building and lease it to the museum is not allowed under Massachusetts bidding laws. And he warned that the venture could end up costing North Adams taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, if attendance didn't meet ``optimistic'' projections of 150,000 visitors a year. Two years ago, the Legislature authorized $35 million to help convert the vacant, 28-building Sprague Electronics Co. mill complex into an art museum. But release of the money depends on acceptance of a feasibility study by state planning and finance officials as well as a museum commission. Local officials in North Adams hope a museum to house ultracontemporary artworks, many of them room-sized, will boost the economy of this industrial town of 18,000. Critics question whether it could ever attract enough people to the town, at least 2{ hours by car from Boston. The idea of using the huge complex as an art museum was devised by Thomas Krens, then director of the Williams College Art Museum in nearby Williamstown and now director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York. An Italian art collector, Count Giuseppe Panza di Biuomo, has said he is willing to make a long-term loan of 300 works to the museum. State Rep. Daniel Bosley, who represents North Adams and strongly supports the museum plan, criticized Barresi for issuing his report. ``It's not his job to pass judgment on a project,'' Bosley said. ``That's for others to do.'' But Bosley said he may seek to amend the enabling legislation to change the financing requirements to meet Barresi's objections. Krens was traveling abroad Friday and could not be reached for comment on Barresi's criticisms, while North Adams Mayor John Barrett III was not available for comment because of a death in his family, his office said. Barresi said North Adams taxpayers need to be aware that they museum ``is a risky venture. ... The feasibility study relies on optimistic forecasts.'' The study, released in April, contends upwards of 150,000 people annually would be willing to travel to the town in the northern Berkshires and pay $6.50 apiece to view ultramodern work such as a 300-foot sculpture of lighted neon tubes. But the well-established Clark Art Institute with free admission in nearby Williamstown gets just 120,000 visitors annually, Barresi said. If the proposed museum got that many visitors _ 30,000 fewer than its break-even target _ it would run a $274,000 deficit that would have to be made up by the taxpayers, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Black Friends Of Bensonhurst Defendant Say He's No Racist
DOC.TEXT: The defense rested in the latest Bensonhurst murder trial Friday after calling four black men who drove from Ohio to tell jurors the defendant was a good friend and not a racist. Napoleon Bonaparte Brown said he and defendant John Vento became ``best friends'' in the seven or eight years they've known each other. The two worked together in a Dayton, Ohio, pizzeria owned by Vento's brother. ``Johnny's an A-OK guy amongst me and my friends,'' Brown testified. Yusuf Hawkins, 16, was shot to death after he and three friends, all black, crossed paths with a gang of bat-wielding whites on a street in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst neighborhood last August. The highly publicized killing heightened racial tensions in New York City. Last month, one white teen was convicted of murder and another acquitted of murder but convicted of lesser charges in the case. Other defendants are expected to stand trial later. Vento, 21, was put on trial after he backed out of an agreement with prosecutors to testify against others in the case and fled the city around Christmastime. He surrendered to authorities in March. Prosecutors attempted on Friday to have first- and second-degree manslaughter added to the charges, but Justice Thaddeus Owens refused when defense lawyer Gerald DiChiara objected. The state Supreme Court jury chosen to decide Vento's fate will hear final arguments Monday before beginning their deliberations. Brown and Vento's other black friends said the allegations against Vento hadn't diminished their feelings of friendship for him. Brown said he didn't believe much of what he had heard and read. ``You know how the media is _ they say what they want to,'' Brown told the jury. Vento lived with his brother in Dayton for several years, and went back to Dayton after fleeing New York six months ago. In his testimony Friday, Brown said Vento gave himself up the day after he had confided that he was in trouble in New York. Under cross-examination, Brown acknowledged that Vento hadn't told him that he was wanted for his role in the murder of an unarmed black teen-ager. Brown learned the details only from news reports, he said. Vento confided ``basically something went down in his neighborhood and it was real big. That was enough for me,'' Brown said. ``We're best friends. I said, `Whatever it is, go straighten it out.''' Other defense witnesses included a woman from Bensonhurst, a police officer and three more of Vento's black friends who drove from Dayton on Thursday to testify.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Trading Assistant Gets 10 Months for Perjury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Longer version on business wires
DOC.TEXT: Lisa Jones, a teen-age runaway who became a $100,000-a-year trading assistant at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was sentenced Friday to 10 months in prison for lying to a grand jury investigating Wall Street fraud. U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand reduced the 18-month sentence Jones received last year after an appeals court threw out the term on grounds it was longer than mandated by federal sentencing guidelines. Sand also fined Jones $25,000 and ordered her to pay $14,850 for the cost of her incarceration. He required Jones to receive mental health treatment during her term. Jones, 27, was convicted in March 1989 of seven counts of perjury and obstruction of justice for lying in January 1988 to a federal grand jury investigating trading activities at Drexel. Sand said he was sympathetic to Jones' psychological problems and troubled childhood _ she ran away from home at age 14 _ but said deterrence was necessary because she lied repeatedly to investigators. Assistant U.S. Attorney Neil S. Cartusciello said Jones still had not cooperated with the government. He also said there was nothing to indicate she was suffering from ``diminished mental capacity'' at the time of her crimes. Jones, who worked at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., junk bond department, was the first person convicted in the government's lengthy investigation of fraud on Wall Street. Prosecutors showed at her trial that Jones handled transactions that constituted illegal stock ``parking,'' which typically involves hiding the true ownership of securities. In three appearances before the grand jury, Jones said she did not recall any discussions about stock parking in contacts with Princeton-Newport Partners LP. The principals of the defunct investment firm were convicted last July in a scheme to generate illegal tax losses through bogus securities trading. Jones was an assistant to Drexel trader Bruce Newberg, who was convicted in the Princeton-Newport case and sentenced to three months in prison. Newberg reported directly to Michael Milken, the ex-head of Drexel's junk bond department who pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties earlier this year to settle fraud charges. The government showed that Jones had a history of lying _ about her age, birthplace, job title and other matters. She lied about 150 times during testimony at her trial, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Manhole Is Now Officially Maintenance Hole
DOC.TEXT: Manholes have disappeared from the streets of California's capital city, replaced, in deference to the city council's female majority, with ``maintenance holes.'' The Public Works department in April announced an informal contest to find a gender-neutral name for the places in the street where workers go to make underground repairs. The contest brought suggestions from far-flung locations. A radio station in Hamilton, New Zealand _ Sacramento's sister city _ came up with ``sewer viewer.'' Others suggested ``peopleholes'' or even ``peepholes.'' ``The Nonsexist Word Finder: A Dictionarty of Gender-Free Usage,'' by Rosalie Maggio, proffers ``sewer hole'' or ``utility access hole.'' The city council was to have named a winner at a May 9 meeting, it ducked the issue. The new name came finally without any fuss: Reporters noticed that ``maintenance hole'' had replaced ``manhole'' in a sewer code packet adopted without discussion by the council on Tuesday. The women on the council never ordered the name changed. The idea came from city engineering staff members who noted women controlled the council. ``I noticed the different references in the staff report, but I don't know why they handled it that way,'' Mayor Anne Rudin said. ``I think they just wanted the matter to quiet down.'' Public works officials said the new name was adopted for a practical reason: Officials won't have to change the ``MH'' abbreviations already in use on city utility maps.

DOC.HEAD: Folk Singer Says He Was Forced Out of China
DOC.TEXT: A Taiwanese folk singer sent back home by China seven years after he defected to that country said Friday he would have preferred to remain in Beijing to continue criticizing the Communist Chinese leadership. ``It was not my plan to come back to Taiwan at this moment,'' Hou Dejian told reporters one day after being released on bail by Taiwanese authorities. ``I wanted to stay in China and remain an acceptable, reasonable dissident.'' Hou, 34, and two others disappeared May 31 in Beijing just hours before they were to issue an open letter to Chinese leaders calling for the release of political prisoners. The singer said Chinese authorities had accused him of spreading rumors about the death toll in the June 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. Hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of people died. Hou said Chinese authorities offered him a choice of either going to prison or being sent back to Taiwan. ``I didn't want to go to jail, and I don't want to be irrational. So I chose to come back,'' Hou told a news conference at a Taipei hotel. The two others seized, Gao Xin and Zhou Duo, resurfaced earlier this week in Beijing. Gao said he had spent the two weeks ``vacationing'' under police supervision. Hou arrived in Taiwan on Wednesday aboard a fishing boat. Prosecutors said they would review Hou's case to determine if he entered Taiwan illegally, but Premier Hau Pei-tsun indicated the folk singer would not be sent to jail. ``Since he turned himself in, there shouldn't be any serious consequences,'' the premier said Friday. Hou was a popular folk singer in Taiwan when he defected to China in 1983 in what he described as a move to seek his roots. His father was a soldier in the Nationalist army that retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces on the Chinese mainland. Hou was one of four young intellectuals who staged a hunger strike in Beijing during the pro-democracy movement's final days. Following the military crackdown, Hou took refuge in the Australian Embassy in Beijing for more than two months until the Chinese government promised he would not be arrested. After leaving the embassy, he was one of the few Chinese to continue to publicly call for democratic reform.

DOC.HEAD: For The 90s: Concentrating On Living Well With AIDS
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For the 20 months after her AIDS diagnosis, Kathy and Chris Pitkin made the most of the life she had left by caring for her at home. She lived well with AIDS, instead of simply dying well with it. The 20 months of care before her death in 1988 cost $150,000, 80 percent of it for six hospital visits. The cost of home care, which helped extend and improve her life, had to come out of Pitkin's pocket. ``It's one of the most frustrating things we face,'' said Merle Sande, chief of medicine at San Francisco General Hospital, during a panel discussion Friday in connection with the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. ``We can get resources if you hospitalize a patient. But to take care of them at home _ to focus on the quality of life _ to try to keep them out of the hospital, you can't get support for it. It doesn't make any sense.'' As AIDS enters its second decade, care-givers, community AIDS groups and people infected with the deadly virus are talking about quality of life _ home care, good nutrition and critical emotional support _ and how it can help lengthen life and give them a sense of control over a disease that often seems out of control. It's easier to see what's needed in the bigger picture than it is to find money to pay for it. ``Finding the resources to support it is almost harder to do than finding the resources to support what it takes to die well,'' said Jean McGuire, executive director of the AIDS Action Council, a Washington, D.C.-based lobbying group. The Council recently challenged the continuing reviews of Social Security and Medicaid benefits of people with AIDS. Ironically, current drug therapies were often improving the health of AIDS patients so dramatically that they were deemed no longer eligible for the benefits that had given them access the very medical care that had helped them, she said. Kathleen Squires was an intern at a Philadelphia hospital in 1981 when patients started popping up with an illness no one could identify. ``By the time these patients presented at the hospital, they never made it out of the hospital again,'' said Squires, now assistant attending physician at New York Hospital. ``They were subjected to every test known to man, and every kind of medication. And in terms of quality of life _ there was none.'' In many cases, there still is none. Doctors have to begin incorporating those concerns into their mainstream care, psychiatrist Stuart Nichols said. ``We have to go beyond what doctors can do for patients. We can help patients live longer and function better. But quality of life ultimately depends on having the courage to look at your life and see if you're doing enough with it, doing the kind of things you want,'' said Nichols of Beth Israel Hospital in New York. Physicians tend to focus too narrowly on the negative aspects of AIDS, he said. ``If you ask most doctors about the basic psychological response to being diagnosed, they'd tell you about the catastrophic reaction where your sense of who you are and where you're going is wiped out,'' he said. ``But they seem to forget entirely there's a second, and more important phase, where the patient (emerges) with a new sense of who they are, a new sense of what they want to do, with new friends, new goals in life.'' Pitkin, who learned he was HIV positive six years ago, has all but abandoned the conservative lifestyle that found him pursuing an advanced business degree and socking away retirement money. Attitude is everything, he believes. ``That's the thing with AIDS. It's like, death and dying and everything's going to hell,'' he said. ``Let's get out and play some golf, do some sailing and have some fun.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Give Assurances on Continued Emigration of Jews
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, responding to repeated urgings by the United States, late Friday gave new assurances that his government would keep allowing Jews to leave the country. Shevardnadze, however, requested Israel keep the refugees from settling on the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip territories. ``We have very good reasons to insist,'' Shevardnadze said after a two-hour meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The session was held after a conference on Germany's future, attended also by the foreign ministers of Britain, France, East Germany and West Germany. Before flying home to Moscow, the foreign minister said the Soviet parliament would complete legislation establishing the right to emigrate. That would meet a precondition set by the Bush administration for lowering tariffs against Soviet products. Baker raised the issue after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev threatened to suspend Jewish emigration, which is now at an all-time high, if some of the refugees are settled in the lands formerly held by Jordan and Egypt. But Shevardnadye told reporters: ``As for our practice in regard to emigration, nothing has changed.'' Two weeks ago, Shevardnadye gave similar assurances to Baker during a meeting in Copenhagen, Denmark. But then Gorbachev raised the possibility again, as he had at the Washington summit with Bush that ended June 3.

DOC.HEAD: Two Defense Contractor Employees Convicted
DOC.TEXT: Two defense contractor employees were convicted for conspiracy in U.S. District Court after they stole and distributed secret weapons systems documents, officials said on Friday. Frank J. Caso, a former hughes Aircraft Co. employee in Canoga Park, Calif., and John R. Kiely, a Raytheon Co. employee in Bedford, Mass., had conspired to obtain the documents in the early 1970s, said a statement from Defense Department Inspector General Susan J. Crawford. The two men had worked together to distribute the documents to other defense contractors and employees, the court ruled. Other conspirators and their employers have already been convicted. Hughes Aircraft earlier pleaded guilty to related charges and paid $3.67 million to settle the criminal and civil charges. Raytheon also agreed to pay $1 million, the statement said. The convictions stem from an investigation called Operation Uncover that targeted unlawful traffickers of classified documents by top defense contractors and their employees.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says Yes to Earthquake Aid from Private US Agencies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with seven grafs details of relief effort, other info, picks up 5th graf: ``There have,''
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government Friday night prepared to airlift blankets, tents and other items for earthquake victims in Iran after being informed by Iranian authorities that American assistance would be welcome. The relief items were to donated through the American Red Cross. Iran had informed the State Department that it was willing to accept contributions from that agency or similar private organizations. The State Department said the goods, valued at $225,000, were to be flown via charter from a U.S. government logistics base near Pisa, Italy. The charter cost was listed at $66,000. ``We want to be helpful without regard for our political differences with Iran,'' said deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. Iranian officials put the death toll at more than 36,000. The State Department said the U.S. contribution would consist of 1,000 hard hats, 1,000 leather gloves, 10,000 face masks, 2,940 wool blankets, 160 5-gallon water jugs and 800 tents. Meanwhile, in Stamford, Conn., the Americares relief organization said it would send a medical team and 80,000 pounds of supplies to Iran on Saturday. ``We really can't be perceived as so bad if we reach out to the people there,'' said Terry Tarnowski, who has worked for AmeriCares since it was founded in 1982. There have been only rare instances of U.S.-Iranian cooperation since the two countries broke diplomatic relations a decade ago. The United States holds Iran partly responsible for the continued detention of American hostages by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. Boucher said Iran told the U.S. government that private donor agencies should contact the Iranian Red Crescent Society, a humanitarian group that is the conduit for all outside assistance. The U.S. government routinely channels humanitarian assistance through the Red Cross and other donor groups. Pat Davis, a spokeswoman for the American Red Cross, said the agency has donated $50,000 in cash and is accepting cash donations for the purchase of blankets, medicines, clothes and flashlights. She said checks payable to Iran Relief can be sent to the American Red Cross, P.O. Box 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013. Checks also can be sent to local Red Cross chapters. Boucher said the Iranian message to the United States presumably was delivered through a third party but added that he was uncertain. Messages between the two countries normally are handled by the Swiss Embassy in Tehran. The type of help U.S. charitable groups could send would be based on the recommendations of a U.N. disaster relief team that has been sent to the affected area. The Iranian message came a day after the Bush administration responded to the tragedy in the northwest part of the country with a message of condolences and an offer of humanitarian aid. Iran reportedly said it would accept aid from all countries except Israel and South Africa. U.S. officials said an American offer of aid after an earlier natural disaster in Iran was rejected.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Vaccine Possible By Mid-1990s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Before being...,' to CLARIFY 46 patients were tested; SUBS 22nd graf, `In Massachusetts...,' to CLARIFY that three of three monkeys in Gardner test were protected by vaccine.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-AIDS-Compound Q
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: Large-scale testing of AIDS vaccines could begin in two years and a vaccine could be widely available by the middle of the 1990s, researchers said Friday. In an address at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, Dr. Jay A. Berzofsky of the National Cancer Institute said the most effective vaccines will probably be synthetic _ made through recombinant DNA technology, or genetic engineering. ``We're now in a position to take advantage of recent advances in immunology to design an artificial vaccine,'' Berzofsky said. ``And it should be possible to develop such a vaccine in the near future.'' Near the Moscone Center convention hall, more than 200 protesters, mostly women, gathered in the latest of a string of daily demonstrations sponsored by ACT UP, the AIDS Coalition To Unleash Power. More than 140 people were arrested when the group of demonstrators marched from near the convention hall into the center of an intersection and lay down in a symbolic ``die-in.'' Another group of 100 activists demonstrated Friday afternoon in front of the Hall of Justice. Friday's demonstration focused on what ACT UP contends is the exclusion of women, children and minorities from research, treatment and other services. Many protesters bound themselves to metal barricades with symbolic red paper chains, chanting, ``Women die faster, this is a disaster,'' and waved signs reading ``Health Care Now,'' Women Gets AIDS Too'' and ``Prostitutes Make Safe Sex Their Business.'' Catherine Ritter, a New York woman who said she has AIDS, said, ``I've been denied access to clinical trials, I've been denied medical treatment.'' Inside the conference, the AIDS vaccine group led by Dr. Jonas Salk reported that the Salk AIDS vaccine has boosted immunity in about 60 percent of the 82 people with AIDS virus infections who have so far received it. The vaccine is intended not to prevent the AIDS infection, but to ward off disease in people already infected. None have died up to two-and-a-half years after being given the vaccine, said Alexandra M. Levine of the University of Southern California. Three developed the AIDS-related cancer Kaposi's sarcoma. One developed pneumonia and another developed an eye infection, she said. The results were encouraging enough for the researchers to announce that large-scale trials of the vaccine will begin in several months with the approval of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. A San Francisco community research group also reported improvement in AIDS patients given a drug called compound Q, derived from a Chinese herb. Before being given the drug, the patients suffered a steady decline in immune system cells called CD4 cells. After administration of the drug to 46 patients, 38 of the patients showed either a stabilization of CD4 cells or an increase, said the study's director, Martin Delaney. ``At this stage, we have seen a major and dramatic change in what happens to these patients,'' Delaney said. But he said he could not yet recommend that the drug be taken widely because of potentially dangerous side effects. Wayne Koff, chief of the AIDS vaccine research branch at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said the most promising human vaccines should be ready for large-scale testing in two or three years, and it will take two or three more years to determine their effectiveness. ``So, we're still looking at the mid-to-late 1990s as a minimal time frame for selection of a vaccine for general use,'' Koff said. ``I think there is reason to be more optimistic now, in 1990, than at any previous international AIDS conference,'' he sid. Some 30 approaches toward the development of vaccines are now being studied, Koff said. Half a dozen vaccines are already being tested or are about to be tested in humans, he said. Optimism about an AIDS vaccine is spurred by recent successes with vaccines in animals, said Dr. Murray B. Gardner of the University of California, Davis. In Massachusetts, two of six monkeys given vaccines did not get infected when exposed to the simian AIDS virus. In Louisiana, vaccines prevented infection in eight of nine vaccinated monkeys. At Gardner's primate research center, three of three monkeys vaccinated were protected against infection. ``It should not be too long before these laboratory-successful vaccines can be translated into HIV vaccines for the real world,'' Gardner said. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. Even if human vaccines aren't successful in protecting humans against disease, they might well delay the onset of serious symptoms of AIDS, Gardner said. The animal vaccines tested were so-called whole-virus vaccines. They consist of killed AIDS viruses injected to trigger an immune response that can defend against live AIDS virus. The danger in using such vaccines with humans, however, is that there is some risk they will inadvertently transmit the disease, because they contain intact AIDS viruses, researchers said. ``Because a synthetic vaccine would lack viral components, it could not inadvertently cause AIDS,'' said Berzofsky. Furthermore, such a vaccine could be designed to stimulate only those parts of the immune system known to attack the AIDS virus, he said. Stimulation of other parts of the immune system could actually intensify an AIDS infection, because those immune cells are infected with the AIDS virus, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Zaire Sharply Reduces Ties With Belgium Over Massacre Report
DOC.TEXT: Zaire sharply reduced diplomatic and other ties with Belgium on Friday in response to Brussels' criticism of human rights abuses in the former Belgian colony, according to news reports. The move came a month after Belgium ``froze'' relations with Zaire over the May 12 massacre of students at the University of Lubumbashi. On Friday, Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko accused Belgium of meddling in Zaire's internal affairs. He suspended a 1989 accord under which Belgium canceled $311 million in debt and rescheduled another $399 million, halved the four weekly flights from Brussels to Kinshasa, by Sabena, Belgium's national airline, and closed three of Belgium's four consulates in Zaire. He also ``put an end to the presence'' of hundreds of Belgians working on development projects in Zaire, according to that country's official news agency, Azap. Belgium denied it was interfering in Zairean affairs. Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens summoned the Zairean ambassador to protest Mobutu's actions. ``The government has only asked for clarifications about the grave incidents that took place in Lubumbashi,'' the government said in a statement. According to Belgian press reports, dozens of students were killed at the university by masked members of Mobutu's personal guard. The students apparently had beaten other students accused of being spies for Mobutu. Students have been at the vanguard of opposition to one-party rule in this central African country. On Thursday, U.S. lawmakers voted to cut off military aid to Zaire over that country's human rights record. The decision by the House Appropriations Committee is expected to be upheld by the full House of Representatives when it debates the foreign aid bill next week. Zaire, a country of 25 million residents, marks its 30th anniversary since independence from Belgium at the end of this month. Mobutu seized power in a 1965 coup and imposed authoritarian, one-party rule. The U.S. State Department said recently in its annual human rights report that security organizations in Zaire regularly harass, detain and brutalize citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Unitarian Leaders to Discuss Euthanasia at Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to Gloucester, sted Glouchester.
DOC.TEXT: The highly publicized suicide of a member of the Unitarian church focused new attention on the denomination's liberal social stands as leaders began their annual conference Friday. Two years ago, the church endorsed the right to die, and leaders voiced support for Janet Adkins, an Alzheimer's disease patient who used a suicide machine to end her life June 4. The issue was expected to be a prime topic of discussion at the five-day annual conference of the Unitarian-Universalist Association, said the Rev. William Schultz, the church's national president. Schultz, who was scheduled to speak on the issue late Friday, declined to say if he expected attempts to reverse the church's support for euthanasia. He continues to support the principle, and noted it is characteristic of the denomination, which has endorsed homosexual marriages and marijuana legalization and prides itself on its open-minded approach to social issues. ``Unitarian-Universalists have always affirmed that religion is not a Sunday morning experience,'' Schultz said in an interview. ``Unitarian-Universalists believe religious principles need to be brought to bear on public policy questions and the political events of the day.'' About 3,000 delegates were expected to attend the conference of the Boston-based church, which claims about 190,000 members and 1,010 congregations nationally. Mrs. Adkins, of Portland, Ore., ended her life June 4 in a van in a Detroit suburb. Dr. Jack Kevorkian hooked her up to a suicide device he built, enabling the 54-year-old woman to give herself a lethal dose of chemicals. Kevorkian hasn't been charged with a crime, but a court issued an injunction barring further use of the machine. Unitarian-Universalists endorsed the right to die at their 1988 meeting. Leaders voiced support for Mrs. Adkins, though a Unitarian minister in Michigan refused to let her use the machine inside a church. Euthanasia is far from the first difficult issue for Schultz, who has led the church since 1985. ``We have always been outspoken that we as religious people have every right and even an obligation to speak out the truth as we see it to those who govern us and who are in positions of power,'' he said. At their general assembly in 1984, the church became the first majopr denomination to sanction marriages between homosexual couples. In 1975, the Unitarian-Universalists set up a national office for homosexual concerns. In the early 1970s, it sponsored sex education courses and passed a resolution calling for the legalization of marijuana. It has long supported abortion rights, and supported birth control as early as 1962. Schultz said unlike most mainstream Christian bodies, the church doesn't have a single doctrine. Instead, it attempts to keep faith as open and tolerant as possible. ``There is no theology that everyone is required to believe in, but that doesn't mean there aren't common principles we adhere to,'' he said. ``We believe the world, the universe is too grand, too complex, too mysterious to be captured or capsulized in any one creed on any one religious tradition.'' The first Universalist church in North America was established in Gloucester, Mass., in 1779. In 1961, it merged with the Unitarian church, a 16th century church founded in Romania.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Offers to Send Medical, Rescue Teams to Iran
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy offered Friday to send humanitarian relief to Iran to help search for trapped survivors of that country's killer earthquake. ``Israel is very sorry for the grave natural disaster in Iran and is prepared to give the Iranians immediate aid as it has done for various other nations,'' said Eliza Goren, Levy's spokeswoman. Iran reportedly said humanitarian aid would be welcomed from all nations except South Africa and Israel. Goren said Levy made the offer through the League of International Red Cross. Israel has had no diplomatic ties with Iran since the Islamic revolution ousted the Shah in 1979. Dr. Mark Heller, a top researcher at the Jaffe Center for Strategic Studies, said no one really expected the offer to be accepted. ``I suspect that this is an attempt to demonstrate to the Iranians that Israel has no intrinsic hostility to Iran,'' Heller said. ``But I don't think that anyone seriously expects the Iranian government will accept.'' Levy's offer to Iran comes as the new right-wing government has made various moves toward neighboring Arab states. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has invited Syrian President Hafez Assad to unconditioned talks and published his phone number, requesting any Arab states seeking peace to call. But Goren said Levy's offer to send a relief team to Iran was made on humanitarian grounds only. Before Khomeini rose to power, Iran was an island of support for the Jewish state in the Middle East, and home to a wealthy Jewish community of about 60,000. It also provided 40 percent of Israel's oil needs. Israel sent relief teams after Iran's September 1978 earthquake. Israel has hoped that President Ali Khamenei would be more moderate than his predecessor. ``Israel has tried to cultivate better relations with Iran for a long time but since the revolt the Iranian regime has been extremely hostile to Israel,'' Heller said. ``The offer is consistent with Israeli policy in the past the only change will be if Iran actually accepts.'' Clandestine contacts between Israel and Iran, however, have continued. They largely involved the sale of weapons and spare parts during Iran's eight-year war with Iraq. In December 1987, Israel sent a 42-member rescue team to search for survivors in Soviet Armenia.

DOC.HEAD: Women Activists Snarl Downtown Traffic
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 140 AIDS activists Friday after they blocked downtown traffic to protest claims that women are denied access to AIDS treatment and research. The protest marked the fourth day of demonstrations by AIDS and gay rights activists, many who traveled to San Francisco for the Sixth International AIDS Conference. Friday's arrests brought the total to 299. Nearly all the protests have taken place outside the conference. The only incident inside the Moscone Center came Friday morning when several demonstrators briefly interrupted a morning seminar. There were no arrests. The demonstration, a few blocks from the conference, included a march and several women speakers, including those advocating the rights of prostitutes. The crowd shouted slogans such as, ``Women die faster, it's a disaster,'' and ``NIH we think you're vile. We need clinical trials.'' The call refers to the National Institutes of Health's trials of experimental drug, which rely heavily on male subjects. ``I've been denied access to clinical trials and I've been denied medical care,'' Catherine Ritter, a New York woman with AIDS told the crowd, as a number of women tied themselves to police barricades with red paper chains. Carol Leigh, a self-professed prostitute from San Francisco complained that prostitutes are being wrongly persecuted as AIDS carriers. Dressed in a Gay 90s music hall dress and a red feather boa, Leigh said prostitutes help stop the spread of disease by using condoms. ``Prostitutes are safe-sex educators,'' she said. Protesters moved from their spot near the Moscone Center and marched through crowded lunchtime streets, chanting and blowing whistles before finally halting for a ``die-in'' at a busy intersection. Police issued what has become a standard warning to clear the street. When a group of protesters elected to stay, police circled them and began the long process of arresting them as noon time shoppers and other demonstrators looked on. Most were booked for failure to disperse and then released. A half hour later, a second group of demonstrators ran back into the street, starting the process all over again. Many shoppers were trapped on the street until police finished the arrests. Most watched patiently, but some expressed frustration with the week of demonstrations that have tied up the city. ``I can understand their emotions, but I question their tactics,'' said Lillian Schneiderman, a shopper from nearby East Bay. But not everyone was aware of the ongoing protests. An elderly woman, startled by the crowds, asked what was going on. When told it was an AIDS demonstration, her face wrinkled in disgust. ``It's their own fault, she said. ``They shouldn't have ever taken that stuff.''

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Meech Lake Constitutional Accord Declared Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with government aide declaring accord dead, quotes, details. No pickup. ADDS laserphotos
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XSTJ1, WFP1
DOC.TEXT: A constitutional accord aimed at keeping French-speaking Quebec in the Canadian federation died late Friday and a government official blamed the premier of Newfoundland. The agreement, which would have designated Quebec a ``distinct society,'' had to be ratified by all 10 provinces by midnight Saturday. All but Newfoundland and Manitoba had ratified the so-called Meech Lake accord. Newfoundland's Premier Clyde Wells on Friday night suspended debate indefinitely on the measure, a move that effectively killed the accord, said Sen. Lowell Murray, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's top constitutional adviser. Murray said Mulroney would address this nation of 26 million residents on Saturday. Quebec's Premier Robert Bourassa told his provincial legislature Friday that ``the Meech Lake accord has not been ratified.'' ``In the name of all Quebecois, I want to express my profound disappointment,'' he said. The federal government had made a last-ditch effort to save the accord through a Supreme Court extension of the deadline. Government lawyers believed that only Quebec's ratification, which took place June 23, 1987 and started the process, would expire Saturday night. But Murray said an extension of the deadline would only have worked if preceded by a positive vote in Newfoundland, one of Canada's poorest provinces with about 500,000 residents. Earlier, the Manitoba legislature pushed the agreement close to death when it was forced to adjourn by the lone Indian member of the assembly. The lawmaker wanted constitutional recognition of Indian tribes as distinct people. ``Manitoba did its best, but was obstructed. Premier Wells' decision to break his committment and not hold his vote tonight killed the last hope for Meach Lake to succeed,'' Murray said. In Newfoundland, Wells said he felt Meech Lake ``is wrong for the long-term future of Canada and wrong for the long-term future for this province.'' The five-point agreement, first approved by the prime minister and the premiers of the provinces in 1987, is aimed at winning Quebec's signature on Canada's 1982 constitution. In that year, the ministers set a three-year deadline for approval by the Parliament and legislatures. But in the interim, governments changed in three of the provinces _ Manitoba, Newfoundland, and New Brunswick _ and the premiers reneged on the signatures of their predecessors. In early June, Mulroney called the premiers to Ottawa, where they spent a week in intense private meetings. They agreed to pass the original accord as it is. New Brunswick passed it last week. The dithering over the accord has given rise to increased nationalist sentiment in Quebec. It has been implied that if the Meech Lake accord is not ratified, Quebec, which contains one-fourth of Canada's population, will have to rethink its role in the Canadian federation. ``English Canada must clearly understand ... Quebec is today and forever a distinct society,'' Bourassa told the legislature. Opposition Parti Quebecois leader Jacques Parizeau extended his hand to Bourassa ``to work together'' to find a new path for Quebec. ``Let's just accept the idea of being together and discussing the future among ourselves,'' Parizeau said. Manitoba's delay was the work of legislator Elijah Harper, who managed to put off a vote on the accord in Winnipeg. On Friday, the Manitoba legislature legally was required to adjourn in the early afternoon unless it extended its session unanimously. Harper, holding an eagle feather, uttered ``no.'' ``We will use every tactic to make sure that the aboriginal people are heard,'' said Harper, a Cree Indian. Quebec's minister for intergovernmental affairs, Gil Remillard, said Thursday that if Meech Lake was not ratified, Quebec would not make another effort to revive the process and would start looking for something else. ``We will not start again,'' Remillard said. ``We've had enough. That's it.'' There has been speculation Quebec may again threaten to secede from Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Government Gives Press `Last Chance' to Discipline Itself
DOC.TEXT: A government official on Friday warned British newspapers that they could face legally binding controls if they fail to take steps to within one year to stop invasions of privacy. Home Secretary David Waddington, writing in the Times of London, said it was the ``last chance'' for the newspapers to police themselves before the government intervenes. ``We will not flinch from introducing statutory regulation of the press,'' Waddington said. ``We all hope that it will not come to this. But it is up to the industry _ proprietors, editors and journalists _ to realize this hope, for no one else can.'' Britain's racy tabloids, the prime target of the ultimatum, conjured up a dire vision of their journalists being jailed for going on a favorite assignment _ dogging royalty _ if the government goes ahead with its threat. The journalists' union and editors' organizations also protested that the move threatened press freedoms. But amid the protests and finger-pointing, there was also rueful acknowledgment that the fiercely competitive popular tabloids sometimes go too far. In recent years, incidents have included a reporter posing as a doctor to get medical records of a dying TV personality to see if the man had AIDS. Last January, a reporter and photographer for a freewheeling weekly, Sunday Sport, barged into an intensive care ward to interview an actor suffering from brain damage. In an announcement in Parliament on Thursday, the government said it will establish a state-funded Press Tribunal headed by a judge or senior lawyer unless the press sets up within 12 months a new, voluntary watchdog body. If newspapers flout an 18-point code of ethics to be administered by the voluntary body, the Newspaper Complaints Commission, or it proves generally ineffective after six months, the tougher Press Tribunal will be appointed. The tribunal would have powers to stop publication of offending articles and force newspapers to pay compensation to people whose privacy has been violated, the government said. Waddington said the government also plans to create three new criminal offenses that would outlaw physical intrusion, bugging, photographing or tape-recording on ``private property'' to obtain personal material for publication. Private property would include hotel bedrooms and hospital wards. The moves were recommended by a panel, chaired by a Cambridge University dean, David Calcutt, which was appointed in April 1989, after growing complaints about press invasions of privacy. The opposition Labor Party, in rare accord with the Conservative government, welcomed the ultimatum, reflecting growing impatience with previous press promises to curb excesses. ``We believe in another freedom _ the right of individuals to live in freedom and in peace,'' said Roy Hattersley, Labor's deputy leader. Unlike most other Western European countries, Britain has no right-to-privacy laws or laws against physical intrusion. The ultimatum culminated years of complaints about the sexy, kiss-and-tell tabloids, purchased interviews, and foot-in-the-door pursuits of pop stars, royalty, politicians, criminals or little-known people suddenly in the limelight. The present watchdog body for Britain's 130 daily and Sunday newspapers and 1,800 other weekly papers is a Press Council that merely has powers to complain. The Association of British Editors called Waddington's ultimatum ``another turn of the screw against the free workings of the press.'' The 585,000-circulation tabloid, Today, headlined its report, ``Jail Editors to Protect The Royals.'' Others complained the regulations would hamper investigative journalism. But several influential newspapers and press executives welcomed the move.

DOC.HEAD: Miami Yanks Mandela Welcome Mat After Castro Praise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for New York-dated AM-Mandela-Jews listed on 9:15 p.m. digest update.
DOC.TEXT: The City Commission dropped a planned welcome resolution for Nelson Mandela on Friday and some Cuban exiles called for demonstrations during his visit here to protest Mandela's praise for Fidel Castro. Mandela is scheduled to address a labor convention in Miami Beach on June 28 as part of his U.S. tour. The political furor arose over Mandela's comments Thursday on ABC in which he thanked Castro, as well as Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and Libyan President Moammar Gadhafi for their longtime support of the once-outlawed African National Congress. Those remarks also prompted criticism Friday from American Jewish leaders. The statement ``pained many, many members of the Miami community,'' said Mayor Xavier Suarez, a Cuban-American. ``There was an unwilligness to analyze other struggles for freedom,'' Suarez said. ``It was sort of `He's my ally, and my ally can do no wrong.''' A proclamation welcoming Mandela and praising his struggle was dropped because such measures are traditionally approved by unanimous vote, and two Cuban-American commission members _ Victor DeYurre and Miriam Alonso _ have now objected, Suarez said. The mayor added that he also was troubled by the comments, although he said he strongly supports Mandela's campaign for a non-racial democracy. The Miami reaction was not only on an official level. Phone lines on Cuban talks shows lit up Friday, with almost all callers condemning Mandela. ``We Cubans should go protest,'' one caller to Radio Mambi said. ``Out with Mandela _ we have enough communists here.'' Tomas Regalado, the station's news director, said Cubans felt Mandela was hypocritical. ``This guy has a double standard on human rights,'' Regalado said. ``He wants human rights for black people in South Africa, but he's denying human rights to the black people in Cuba.'' Mandela said Western leaders should not assume that their enemies are the same as the ANC's enemies. He said Castro, Arafat and Gadhafi had been staunch supporters of the ANC at times when the West ignored the black South African cause. In New York, leaders of Jewish organizations also criticized Mandela. ``We believe Americans generally will be disappointed by his notion that the terrorism and human rights violations of the Gadhafis, Arafats and Castros of this world do not matter, as long as they provide aid to the African National Congress,'' said Robert K. Lifton and Henry Siegman, president and executive director, respectively, of the American Jewish Congress. Albert Vorspan, senior vice president of the 840-congregation Union of American Hebrew Congregations, stated: ``Nelson Mandela's statements of support for the PLO, Libya and Cuba during his visit in New York are disappointing. His problematic remarks have undone some of the good work accomplished at our meeting in Geneva in clarifying issues of concern to the Jewish community.'' Abraham H. Foxman, another member of the Jewish group that met with Mandela in Geneva two weeks ago, said Mandela's statements ``remain troubling and inconsistent.'' ``Americans will continue to support Mandela's struggle against apartheid. They are likely, however, to take issue with his remarks which reiterated his loyalty to ... sworn enemies of the United States and democracy,'' said Foxman, director of the Anti-Defamation League.

DOC.HEAD: College Literary Magazine Rejects NEA Grant In `Free Speech' Protest
DOC.TEXT: The editor of Gettysburg College's literary magazine rejected a federal arts grant Friday, saying he believes restrictions placed on the money violate the right to freedom of expression. Peter Stitt, editor of the Gettysburg Review, said new stipulations banning ``obscene or meritless'' art result in prior restraint. The stipulations were added to the National Endowment of the Arts grants last year after a furor over federal funding of an exhibit by Robert Mapplethorpe. Some of the photos had homoxesexual themes. The changes have brought widespread protests from artists and their supporters. The Gettysburg Review publishes poetry, fiction and non-fiction articles. It has never published anything considered obscene, Stitt said. ``My decision should not be construed as support for obscenity,'' he said. ``But, I cannot see any way for us to determine what the endowment considers obscene unless we submit the materials that we wish to publish to the endowment for review prior to the publication.'' Submitting marterial for approval, an action that could result in prior restraint, contradicts the First Amendment right to freedom of expression, he said. The NEA does not have a procedure for checking up on the thousands of photographers, dancers, urban designers, painters and other artists who receive federal grants each year. The journal received a $4,550 grant to increase its advertising budget. Stitt said the publication had asked for the grant before the new regulations were enacted last fall. Under the regulations, grant recipients were asked to swear off art that included ``depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific merit.'' All of the more than 4,000 grant recipients this year were asked to sign letters promising to comply with federal guidelines. At least two artists have declined to accept NEA grants because of the restrictions. Theater producer Joseph Papp refused a $50,000 grant and dance choreographer Bella Lewitzky declined $72,000. The New School for Social Research, which received a $45,000 grant to build a sculpture garden at its New York City campus, filed a lawsuit in May, saying the guidelines were unconstitutional. The lawsuit has not been settled. Congress currently is considering an Bush administration proposal to extend the NEA program for five years without any restrictions. The proposal, scheduled to be considered on the House floor in mid-July, could face amendments that would add restrictions or guidelines for grants, House leaders have said.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Son Refused To Believe Mother Was Dead
DOC.TEXT: He lived with his mother's corpse for more than six months, but the son of an elderly woman refused to believe she was dead, police said. The body of Florence V. Kowalewski, 77, was found seated in a chair Wednesday in the house where she had lived with her 47-year-old son, police Lt. Thomas Rowan said. ``He was at home with his mother and denied she was dead when police told him,'' Rowan said. ``She had been dead for more than six months and under a year.'' The son, whose identity was withheld, was admitted to the Erie County Medical Center for psychiatric evaluation. Cheektowaga is a suburb of Buffalo. Police were called to the house Wednesday by a social worker who became alarmed when no one answered her knocking at the door, Rowan said. An autopsy was inconclusive but the death was probably due to natural causes, he said. ``Right now we have no crime and no sign of any foul play,'' Rowan said. ``It appears Mrs. Kowalewski died in her bed. Her body was moved at least once and maybe another time in the house. It was in an advanced stage of (putrefaction) and there was some mummification.'' A neighbor described the mother and son as loners and said the son rarely ventured out, except at night. The son did not have a full-time job and police believe he lived on his mother's pension and savings.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Scientists Meet on Environmental Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: Now that the ``red phone'' linking Soviet and U.S. leaders in case of military crisis is becoming obsolete, the governments should establish ``green'' lines to battle ecological problems, officials said Friday. Scientists and government officials approved a series of recommendations to further communication and cooperation in conservation and wildlife management at the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Conference on Environmental Conservation. The weeklong conference of nearly 40 representatives from each country was held at Washington and Lee University. Edward LaRoe, a research director for the Fish and Wildlife Service, said the conference was the most comprehensive since the U.S.-U.S.S.R Agreement on Cooperation in Environmental Protection was signed in 1972. Delegation leaders said the increasing popularity of the environmental movement in both countries and the prospect of a peace dividend _ the shift from military to domestic spending _ could further environmental cooperation. The resolutions Friday included establishing ``green'' lines of rapid communication between governments during environmental crises like the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska and the nuclear accident in Chernobyl. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service spokesman Mike Smith said his agency is anticipating its largest budget ever in 1991. ``We believe we are going to have the level of funding necessary to begin some of these cooperative efforts,'' Smith said. The idea for ``green'' lines came from the Soviet delegation leader, Aleksei Yablokov, a zoologist and member of the natural resources committee in the Congress of People's Deputies. The lines would link key government leaders and experts in particular scientific fields. If the countries can have a ``red'' phone for use in a potential military crisis, ``Why not a `green' phone between the two nations?'' Smith said. Other proposals were to: _study areas in both countries that have undergone ecological catastrophes. _establish common information banks, with standardized methods for data collection and storage. _increase the number, size and types of ecosystems represented in networks of protected areas. _carry out wildlife inventories and monitoring activities in both health and disturbed ecosystems.

DOC.HEAD: `Lady Goetz' Sentenced in Gun Case
DOC.TEXT: A woman dubbed ``Lady Goetz'' for pulling an illegal pistol and shooting a would-be mugger delivered an impassioned speech on self-protection Thursday when she pleaded guilty to a reduced weapons charge. ``I deeply regret what has happened,'' Yvesnande Bureau, a 20-year-old department store clerk, told a judge in acknowledging that she knew carrying an unregistered gun was against the law. ``I was mugged in this city three times. ... When I finally used my own gun, it was only because I was frightened. I had to protect myself,'' she said. ``If this scenario keeps repeating itself, the city will be out of control.'' Ms. Bureau was arrested in March after an armed robber tried to push his way into a car with her and her friend Theresa Jackson, 19. Ms. Bureau fired her unregistered .22-caliber pistol and fired, grazing him in the head. He ran away, but a few minutes later a car pulled up to the women's car and someone opened fire, striking Ms. Jackson in the head. She died two days later. Clint Smith, 24, was arrested and charged with trying to rob the women. He is awaiting trial, held in lieu of $75,000 bail. No one has been charged in Ms. Jackson's death, but Ms. Bureau was charged with felony possession of a weapon, punishable by up to seven years in prison. On Thursday, she pleaded guilty to fourth-degree weapons possession, a misdemeanor. ``I find it a bit unfortunate when decent people have to resort to illegal activity to protect themselves,'' said trial judge Luigi R. Marano, sentencing her to four consecutive weekends in jail and 100 hours community service. With credit for the nearly five days she spent locked up after her arrest, she will probably have to spend only three more days in jail, said her lawyer, Barry Slotnick. After her arrest, Ms. Bureau's case elicited comparisons to that of subway gunman Bernhard Goetz who shot four teen-agers in December 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Free 1,000s from Quake Rubble as Death Toll Hits 36,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with report rescue workers finding fewer survivors, details; Pickup 7th, `Rescuers scooped...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TEH1,2,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers freed thousands of people Friday from buildings flattened by an earthquake in northern Iran, but Iranian officials said at least 36,000 people died in the world's deadliest tremor since 1976. Iran, at odds with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, appealed for international help. The government said it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups even though the two nations have no diplomatic ties. ``We want to be helpful without regard for our political differences with Iran,'' said Richard Boucher, deputy State Department spokesman in Washington. The magnitude of Thursday's pre-dawn disaster became more obvious as rescuers were able to get into the region about 125 miles northwest of Tehran near the Caspian Sea to view the destruction. Foreign-based reporters so far have been unable to get visas to enter the country. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, said 6,000 people were pulled from rubble and airlifted from the stricken Gilan and Zanjan provinces to hospitals. But IRNA reported later Friday that ``rescue workers are becoming less optimistic. The number of those taken out alive has dropped sharply.'' The news agency quoted an elderly survivor as telling rescuers in the village of Jamalabad in Zanjan province: ``If you had come earlier, you could have saved my daughter-in-law. I was talking to her until a few hours ago.''
