Iranian television, also monitored in Cyprus, showed scenes of devastation, including the remains of an entire row of hillside village houses that collapsed and slid down the hill. Rescuers scooped up rubble and used police dogs to find victims. They gently fed water to one man who was trapped in a mass of stones and earth, only his head protruding. The Iranian Red Crescent asked for help in providing shelter for 400,000 people left homeless by the earthquake. Iran's U.N. Mission in New York on Friday afternoon said that according to the latest estimates from the region, at least 36,000 people were killed and more than 100,000 were injured. IRNA in its most precise figures said 25,241 were killed in Gilan province and 3,709 in Zanjan province. The toll surpassed a quake that killed 25,000 people in nearby Soviet Armenia in December 1988, and a quake in Iran in 1978 that also killed 25,000. The quake's toll was the highest since July 28, 1976, when an estimated 200,000 people were killed in China by a quake measuring 7.8-8.2 on the Richter scale. Farhad Shad, a spokesman for the Geophysics Center at Tehran University, told IRNA that 140 aftershocks were registered after the killer earthquake, which measured 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale, according to geological stations in Tehran, Edinburgh, Scotland, and Golden, Colo. A scientist on Iranian television displayed a seismographic chart of the earthquake. It showed a straight pen-trace, then a sharp vertical jump when the pen actually jumped off the page, such was the intensity of the quake. More than 3,000 tons of relief supplies were flown to the region in 50 trips by air force transport planes, the Iranian news agency quoted an air force commander identified only as Gen. Naderian as saying. The agency said 10 C-130 transport planes and 30 Chinook helicopters were involved in the evacuation of victims after weather conditions improved. Earlier, poor visibility hampered rescue operations. The United States sent a message of condolence and expressed willingness to provide humanitarian aid. Israel, which also has no relations with Iran, did the same. President Hashemi Rafsanjani flew to the village of Roodbar in the heart of the region and told Iranian television that ``this disaster is much worse than anything we have heard from the media.'' ``Realistic casualty figures would be a lot higher than those already announced,'' said Rafsanjani, who appealed for foreign help to aid the victims. ``Everyone is helping, but with a calamity this disastrous, nothing could be enough,'' said the president as he stood beside a helicopter. In scenes shown on television, masked rescuers in white aprons pulled dust-covered bodies from under concrete slabs. Corpses were laid on blocks of ice in open trucks. The state-run television interviewed one middle-aged man from Roodbar, a mountainside village in Gilan province, who said he was sleeping when the temblor struck. ``It was so strong,'' he said. ``I was thrown several meters, I ended up by the olive trees,'' outside his home. ``Then a big boulder hit the house. The house collapsed. I lost all four of my children.'' The Islamic Republic News Agency said one man, Bahrouz Hakimi, lost 27 family members in the village of Manjil, also in the heart of the region. Families flooded donation centers in Tehran and handed over fistfuls of cash to rescue committees. ``Whatever extra things you have at home _ medicines, clothing _ please bring them,'' one woman tearfully told the television. There were large piles of clothing and blankets, as well as dozens of kerosene heaters lined up against the wall. The Red Crescent Society in Tehran issued an international appeal for surgical thread, blood bags, orthopedic surgical equipment, tents, sheets, blankets and medicine, including antibiotics and vitamins. The director of Iran's Blood Transfusion Department, Dr. Ahmad Milaniania, said there was no need for ``foreign blood,'' because Iranians had responded well to hospital appeals for donations. The U.N. Disaster Relief Organization in Geneva was coordinating offers of assistance as they poured in from around the world. The first team of French doctors to arrive set up a center to treat the wounded, and other nations began flying in tons of equipment and medical supplies and hundreds of rescue workers. The French government announced it was sending a civil defense team of 195 people and 18 search dogs, along with 24 tons of equipment, on a special Air France flight Friday. Iran reportedly said it would accept aid from all countries except Israel and South Africa. The European Community announced in Brussels it would give $2.4 million in aid. Syria, an ally of Iran, sent a plane with 11 tons of medicines, food and clothing.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Floridians Oppose `Nasty' Record Ban, Arrests
DOC.TEXT: Most Florida voters responding to a new poll said it was wrong to outlaw 2 Live Crew's record and arrest the rappers for singing sexually explicit songs. Fifty-three percent of the registered voters responding to the Mason-Dixon poll disagreed with a federal court ruling that the group's recored, ``Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' is obscene, the pollsters announced Friday. Thirty-eight percent of the respondents agreed with the ruling. In order to rule the record obscene, the court had to find it violated community standards of decency. The poll, conducted for newspapers and broadcasters around the state, was conducted last week among 627 randomly selected registered voters. The margin of error was 4 percent. The poll also found 54 percent of those surveyed said it was wrong for Broward County Sheriff's Nick Nararro to order the arrest of band members after a concert two weeks ago, while 37 percent supported the arrests. Band leader Luther Campbell was buoyed by the poll results. ``That's great,'' he said. ``Nobody in the United States should be able to tell somebody else what they can listen to.'' Navarro refused to comment on the poll results. ``The sheriff's really not interested in the poll,'' said Navarro's spokesman, Al Gordon. ``He's interested in the law.'' The pollsters also found Floridians seem to be growing tired of the controversy. They jokingly asked if both Campbell and Navarro should be banned from the talk-show circuit _ and one of three of those responding said yes.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Stay of Execution for `Black Widow'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday refused to block the execution of ``Black Widow'' killer Judi Buenoano, whose lawyers had claimed that a malfunctioning state electric chair posed cruel and unusual punishment. U.S. District Judge Patricia Fawsett said tests on the chair showed the equipment ``was in good working order.'' She extended the temporary stay of execution until 9 a.m. Monday, and it was rescheduled for 9:01 a.m., said Jon Peck, spokesman for Gov. Bob Martinez. Ms. Buenoano's chief defense lawyer, Billy H. Nolas, said the decision would be appealed to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. Ms. Buenoano, 47, known as the ``Black Widow'' killer because of convictions for the fatal poisoning of her husband, the drowning of her son and the attempted murder of her boyfriend, had been granted a temporary stay of execution Thursday. The judge said a polyurethene sponge, since removed from the electric chair, was what caused sparks, smoke and fire to leap from the head of executed killer Jesse Tafero last month. But she said that and other equipment problems had been corrected by the state. Nolas contended the defense's claim that the electric chair may malfunction has not been resolved. ``We are still concerned that our client may literally be burned at the stake,'' he said. Prison officials called in an independent electrician to inspect the chair for damage, and he testified late Friday that he found no problems with the equipment. ``If there had been a crack or a fault, there is no way I would have gotten that good reading'' from his testing meter, said the electrician, Thomas Brandies of Jacksonville. The state contends that Tafero received such a powerful bolt of electricity during his execution that he did not suffer, despite the flames and sparks. The Florida Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an appeal from Buenoano on the same basis. Ms. Buenoano's lawyers also cross-examined her trial lawyer, James Johnston, to prove he was ineffective counsel in the 1985 first-degree murder trial here. He was quizzed closely about why he did not introduce possible mitigating circumstances to convince the jury to sentence his client to life in prison instead of the electric chair. Ms. Buenoano was sentenced to death for the fatal arsenic poisoning of her husband, Air Force Sgt. James E. Goodyear, in Orlando in 1971. She also was convicted of killing her paralyzed son, Michael Goodyear, 19, by pushing him from a canoe in a 1980 outing and of attempted murder in a car bombing that injured her boyfriend, John Gentry, in 1983. She would be the second woman executed in the United States since the U.S. Supreme Court lifted its ban on capital punishment in 1976. North Carolina killed Velma Barfield by lethal injection in 1984 for poisoning her boyfriend.

DOC.HEAD: President Of Women's College Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The president of Mills College, whose students went on strike last month and overturned a plan to admit male students, has resigned, the school announced Friday. Mary S. Metz told the school's board of trustees Thursday that she was leaving immediately to pursue other opportunities, said Mills spokeswoman Vickie Bates. Bates gave no other reason for the departure of Metz, president of the exclusive school since 1981. Metz didn't respond to a telephone request for comment. The trustees named Virginia B. Smith, former president of Vassar College and a trustee of Mills since 1988, as acting president. The trustees accepted Metz's resignation with reluctance, said F. Warren Hellman, president of the board. ``She has given Mills energetic, effective and visionary leadership for the past nine years,'' he said. Metz was named president emeritus, an honorary position, Bates said. The school's trustees in May announced they planned to overcome the school's financial problems by admitting male undergraduates. But they backed down May 18 after students went on strike, claiming their education would suffer if men were admitted to the 138-year-old school, one of only 94 all-women colleges nationwide. School officials said they could keep Mills from having to admit men by doubling the alumnae association's annual gift and by increasing enrollment. ``(Metz) feels she's leaving the college in a position of strength,'' Bates said. ``Now the college is completely committed to one goal, one mission, which is to remain a women's college and increase recruiting and fundraising at the same time.'' Metz earlier was provost and dean of faculty at Hood College in Frederick, Md., and assistant to the chancellor at Louisiana State University. She also taught French at both Hood and LSU. Mills had 777 undergraduate students and 264 graduate students at the end of the 1989-90 school year.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Fires Gay Agent Who Sued Agency
DOC.TEXT: The FBI summarily dismissed an FBI agent who had sued the agency for attempting to fire him because of his homosexuality, the man's lawyer said. Two FBI officials came to agent Frank Buttino's home Wednesday morning and read a brief termination order from FBI headquarters, said Buttino's lawyer, Richard Gayer. ``He was shocked, very upset,'' Gayer said Thursday from San Francisco. ``He didn't think they would be gross enough to fire him before the hearing.'' FBI spokesman Gene Reihl in San Diego declined comment and referred calls to spokesman Charles Steinmetz in Washington D.C., who was unavailable Friday. The FBI placed Buttino on administrative leave in September after a 20-year career. His security clearance was revoked May 29 without explanation. On June 8, Buttino filed a suit in U.S. District Court in San Francisco seeking to stop the government from firing him. The 45-year-old Buttino has handled counterespionage, terrorism investigations and other sensitive cases, Gayer said. Gayer said the firing order ``makes the FBI look cruel and callous. ... It's obvious from their approach that they intend to fight tooth and nail on this. Now we have something really tangible to fight.'' According to the bureau's hiring policy, the agency does not discriminate based on sexual preference. ``They gave no explanation why the agent's security clearance was revoked or why he was fired,'' Gayer said. ``Just that, suddenly, they don't trust him any more.'' Buttino's lawsuit alleges that the FBI regularly discriminates against gays, Gayer said. After the FBI learned in 1988 that Buttino was homosexual, he provided details of his personal life to eliminate any concern he could be blackmailed, Gayer said. The agent's San Diego supervisors and colleagues, with whom he has worked for 17 years, continue to trust and respect him, Gayer said. ``What Washington is saying is, `We don't trust you because you're gay,' '' Gayer said. ``It's significant that everyone he worked with supports him. But there are two or three people in Washington who have never met him or spoken to him, and they are the ones with the power to revoke his security clearance.'' Buttino was five years away from qualifying for a full government pension. He must regain his job within a year or he will lose that pension, Gayer said.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Pours In from Around the World for Earthquake Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD remarks by U.S. official and Israeli foreign minister, Iran reportedly rejecting Israeli aid, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Putting aside their troubled relations with Tehran, Britain, the United States and Israel joined nations around the world in offering aid Friday to earthquake-devastated Iran. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, in a message to his Iranian counterpart Ali Akbar Velayati, said: ``We are very saddened by the terrible loss of life in yesterday's earthquake in Iran. ... The government is keen to do what they can to help.'' Britain and Iran severed diplomatic relations in March 1989 after the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered Moslems to kill British author Salman Rushdie for his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' A member of the Iranian interests section that operates through the Pakistan Embassy in London said the British offer was ``very kind.'' He spoke on condition of anonymity. The United States also does not have diplomatic relations with Iran, but the White House offered humanitarian assistance and sent a message of condolence. The State Department said Iran indicated it would welcome earthquake relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian organizations. ``We want to be helpful without regard for our political differences with Iran,'' said deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. Israel also offered assistance. ``Israel is very sorry for the grave natural disaster in Iran and is prepared to give the Iranians immediate aid as it has done for various other nations,'' said Eliza Goren, the Foreign Ministry spokeswoman. Foreign Minister David Levy offered to help Iran search for trapped quake survivors. The offer was made through the League of the International Red Cross. Israel has had no diplomatic ties with Iran since the Islamic revolution ousted the Shah in 1979. Iran reportedly said humanitarian aid would be welcomed from all nations except South Africa and Israel. The family of one Westerner held hostage by pro-Iranian groups joined in the outpouring of sympathy for Iran, which was hit by a major earthquake Thursday that killed tens of thousands of people. The brother of one British hostage, Terry Waite, said he wrote to the Iranian interests section to express ``my profound distress and grief at the tremendous loss of life.'' David Waite told The Associated Press he wrote ``that Terry is someone who has great love for the Iranian people and that if he should learn about it (the earthquake) he himself will be very distressed.'' Terry Waite is the special envoy of Anglican Church Archbishop Robert Runcie. A plane loaded with British relief supplies was scheduled to fly to Tehran over the weekend, the government said. It would be joining planes, supplies and personnel rushing from all over the world to aid the thousands of earthquake victims. A statement from the U.N. Disaster Relief Organization in Geneva said the most immediate needs were medicine, medical supplies and tents. Others include canned food, blankets, clothing, vehicles and heavy-duty equipment. The organization was sending two senior officials to the stricken areas, and a special task force was established at the Iranian president's office to coordinate relief, the United Nations said. The first team of French doctors arrived Thursday, only hours after the quake, and opened a center to treat the wounded. The French government promised to send a civil defense team of 195 people and 18 search dogs, along with 24 tons of equipment. In Geneva, the International Red Cross said radio reports received from the Red Crescent of Iran indicated that at least 400,000 were homeless in northern Iran. Red Crescent is the Islamic equivalent of the Red Cross. Paer Stenbaeck, secretary-general of the League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, said cash contributions were arriving in response to an appeal to members around the world. Early donors included the governments of Sweden, Finland and Japan, he said. Many others followed. Stenbaeck said the Iranians, being used to earthquakes, had ``a remarkably effective relief operation'' and did not need blood plasma, satellite communications equipment, sniffer dogs, used clothing, doctors, technicians or more relief workers. Three thousand trained rescue workers were already deployed in the disaster area, and the Iranian Red Crescent had its own tent factories, food processing plants and warehouses, he said. Iraq, which fought Iran in the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war, was among the first Arab nations to send a note of condolence. ``We are ready to provide any assistance you may require,'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said in a message to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The United Arab Emirates was the first Gulf state to send supplies. The Soviet Union sent a rescue team. International Rescue Corp., a private British charity, sent a 17-member rescue team to Iran after receiving an Iranian request for help, team coordinator Terry Price said. The team took portable satellite communications equipment and instruments to detect victims under rubble. Brian Ruberry, a spokesman for the American Red Cross in Washington, said the organization was raising money rather than shipping supplies, and had established a toll-free nationwide telephone number for people wanting to make contributions. ``We're attempting to raise money to send to the Red Crescent Society to help buy tents, blankets, food, medical supplies and emergency lighting,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Biologists Find Second Gray Wolf Den In Washington State
DOC.TEXT: A den of gray wolves was discovered in the Cascade Mountains this week by biologists who howled to attract the elusive, endangered predators. The den was the second found this year in Washington, the state Department of Wildlife said Friday. The presence of the den was indicated when state and federal biologists spotted two wolf pups near the Pasayten Wilderness Area in the Okanogan National Forest, said Ed Isenson, a state wildlife spokesman. ``To say we're excited is an understatement,'' he said. ``Two wolf dens in Washington after their eradication decades ago is truly a happy event for everybody.'' Gray wolves have been been listed as endangered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service since 1967 in every state but Minnesota and Alaska. Sightings of adult gray wolves have been reported off and on for years in Washington state the most recent 15 years ago. But breeding wolves have been unknown in Washington since the turn of the century, making the recent discoveries remarkable, said state endangered species specialist Harriet Allen. State and federal biologists discovered the second den Monday during a ``howling survey,'' in which biologists emulate wolf calls and hope for an answer. Isenson said the biologists saw two wolf pups cross in front of their headlights shortly after the officials had howled. On May 23, biologists confirmed the existence of a wolf den in the Hozomeen area of the Ross Lake National Recreation area, roughly 40 miles northwest of the second discovery. Biologists believe the breeding wolves in Washington came from nearby British Columbia, Isenson said.

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Sununu Says She Liked Her Job Too Much to Challenge Douglas
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Sununu, wife of White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, said Thursday she decided against running for Congress because she likes her job too much and her son is too young. ``In another couple of years, I think it would have been perfect,'' Mrs. Sununu said while attending the dedication of the Christa McAuliffe Planetarium. When she earlier said she might run for the GOP nomination in the 2nd District, she criticized Republican Rep. Chuck Douglas as failing to represent traditional New Hampshire morals, but declined to be specific. Mrs. Sununu, who is director of special projects for the Republican Governors Association, said Thursday that she didn't make up her mind until the June 15 deadline to file. She said she had considered flying to New Hampshire from Nebraska to file the necessary papers. ``I really love my job and it was a tough decision for me to decide whether to give up something I really like ... as opposed to something I'm not really sure about,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Abuses Spur Vote To Cut Off Aid to Zaire
DOC.TEXT: A House committee on Thursday voted to cut off military aid for Zaire to protest human rights abuses, President Mobutu Sese Seko's alleged corruption and his failure to carry out promised political reforms. The decision by the House Appropriations Committee is expected to be upheld by the full House when the foreign aid bill reaches the floor next week. The committee ``does not believe that U.S. interests in Zaire should override our concerns with respect to corruption and human rights abuses,'' the bill said. The committee ``seriously questions the administration's insistence on providing U.S. taxpayers' dollars to a government whose head of state has reportedly amassed a personal fortune of as much as $6 million while Zaire remains a very poor country,'' it said. U.S. military aid to Zaire this year was $4 million. In addition, the United States provided almost $50 million in food and development assistance. A group of lawmakers is preparing a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker III asking that all U.S. development aid be channeled through private voluntary organizations rather than through the government of Zaire. The letter also criticizes the ``backward steps'' taken by Mobutu since he pledged last April to lift a ban on opposition parties and allow free elections, said a source familiar with the letter. Some members of Congress have accused the Bush administration of ignoring Mobutu's human rights abuses because of his support for U.S. policy in Africa. In recent years Mobutu has played an important role by serving as a conduit for U.S. arms to the rebels fighting the Soviet-backed government of Angola. The administration on Thursday praised a report by an inquiry commission in Zaire for bringing to light important facts about a May 11 military raid against university students at Lubumubashi University. The panel said it could not determine how many students were killed when masked soldiers launched the raid in revenge for the beating of three students who were government informers. Differing reports put the death toll between 50 and 150. The panel said the governor of Shaba Province authorized the attack, but he remains free and no one has been charged in the attack. The United States has not condemned the incident, initially saying it could not confirm reports of a massacre and subsequently saying its embassy had found out that one or two students were killed. Belgium decided to freeze all cooperation with its former colony once it learned of the killings last month. The Belgian government welcomed the commission's report but said it would not resume cooperation with Zaire pending government action on the findings of the report.

A cooperative nutrition education program is being started in public housing projects in eight cities, the government said Thursday. The program will begin this summer and early fall, said officials of the departments of Agriculture and Housing and Urban Development. A private partner in the project is Kraft General Foods Foundation. Officials said the project ``will unite the urban education experience and university research base'' of the Agriculture Department's Extension Service, HUD's facilities, public housing authorities and tenant associations, and support services and financial aid from Kraft General Foods. The eight selected cities and their designated public housing developments are: Philadelphia, Pa., Norris; Decatur, Ga., Swanton Heights; Washington, D.C., Lincoln Heights; Houston, Texas, Cuney Homes; New York, N.Y., Ingersoll-Whitman; Tampa, Fla., Robles Park; Chicago, Ill., Robert Taylor Homes; and Los Angeles, Calif., Imperial Courts.

DOC.HEAD: Compromise May Move Oil Spill Measure
DOC.TEXT: A compromise over limiting liability in oil spills may help move a bill on that issue that has been beached in Congress, House members said on Thursday. A compromise offered by Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., would allow a five-year trial period to see if international standards of liability are adequate or can be changed. ``I think it's a sound approach. It goes more than halfway,'' said Rep. Jack Fields, R-Texas. The House has approved letting international standards guide how much responsibility an oil or shipping company must take for a spill. The Senate version of the bill lets states set those standards. Nineteen states have laws requiring companies to assume unlimited liability for damage from a spill. ``This compromise will allow us to enact the complete oil spill legislation,'' said Rep. Don Young, R-Alaska. The congressmen, during a hearing by the Coast Guard and navigation subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee on response to recent oil spills, urged the Senate to agree to Studds' resolution of liability limits, the main issue tying up the bill's passage. Studds proposed a trial period of up to five years for the less stringent international protocols. During that time, the United States would push to strengthen international liability limits. If they couldn't be strengthened, the United States would return to its own standards.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Statistics on U.S. AIDS Cases
DOC.TEXT: Here are the latest statistics on acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the United States, as reported by the national Centers for Disease Control:
DOC.HEAD: Number of Cases
DOC.TEXT: Total cases reported since June 1981: 136,204. Total deaths: 83,145, or 61 percent of all cases.
DOC.HEAD: Transmission Categories
DOC.TEXT: Homosexual or bisexual males: 80,281, or 59 percent. Intravenous drug abusers: 28,727, or 21 percent. Homosexual male and drug abusers: 9,149, or 7 percent. Heterosexual cases: 6,724, or 5 percent. Transfusion or blood cases: 3,425, or 3 percent. Hemophilia patients: 1,322, or 1 percent. Children of parents with AIDS or at risk: 1,914, or 1 percent. Other or undetermined transmission cause: 4,662, or 3 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Age and Race
DOC.TEXT:
Childhood cases (under age 13): 2,315, or 2 percent. Cases among whites: 75,684, or 56 percent. Cases among blacks: 37,850, or 28 percent. Cases among Hispanics: 21,319, or 16 percent. Cases among Asians or Pacific Islanders: 835, or 1 percent. Cases among American Indians or Alaskan natives: 185, or 0 percent.
(NOTE: These statistics are through May 1990 and have been rounded to the nearest whole percent. Cumulative totals are for AIDS cases reported since June 1981, and include at least 75 cases subsequently found to have occurred prior to that date.)

DOC.HEAD: `Maids of Honor' Opens off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``Maids of Honor'' by Joan Casademont tackles the same area as Beth Henley's Pulitzer Prize-winner, ``Crimes of the Heart.'' ``Maids of Honor,'' too, is a play about zany, mixed-up sisters. But the play is more of a crime than a winner. Despite verbiage, it's simplistic. It opened Thursday night at the WPA Theater. Three excellent actresses play the sisters. Elizabeth McGovern, veteran of the films ``Ordinary People'' and ``Ragtime,'' made the most of Izzy Bowlin, the impulsive cub reporter on a Boston newspaper. Kyra Sedgwick, who had her Broadway debut in ``Ah, Wilderness!'' was the calm, introverted sculptor Annie. Laila Robins, who made her Broadway debut in ``The Real Thing,'' played the bride, Monica. The writing is overheated, with thickets of words growing from a rather small root. The Bowlin parents are dead. When alive, alcoholic Dad beat Mom and made the daughters feel unlovable. They still do. Monica says she's 33, a famous TV talk show host and has been to seven therapists. She talks like an adolescent, breaking up with Roger, about to marry wealthy, dishonest inside-trader Chuck, pregnant, sure both men find her unlovable and will hit her any minute. The bridesmaid sisters find themselves unlovable, too, and mess up every relationship from fear of being abused. Despite good performances, the Bowlin sisters become boring. Three male actors are less well cast. The wedding dress and bridesmaids' dresses are lovely and the set, of a kitchen in Marblehead, Mass., is effective. Mimi Maxmen designed costumes and Edward T. Gianfrancesco designed the set. Max Mayer directed. Casademont, a 1988 graduate of the Yale School of Drama, is making her professional debut as a playwright.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes on Military Base, Two Letter Bombs Found
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with release of two suspects after questioning, police suspicion of IRA responsibility, details. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `The letter...'
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded on a military base northwest of London Thursday, but a security guard had spotted a suspicious rucksack and the base and a nearby senior citizens' home were evacuated shortly before the blast. No injuries were reported from the blast at the Royal Air Force's 250-acre administrative base, Stanmore Park, police said. On Wednesday night, postal workers intercepted letter bombs addressed to the government minister in charge of Welsh affairs and to a Conservative parliamentarian who represents a Welsh contituency. The incidents at the base and in London appeared to be unrelated. No one claimed responsibility for the explosion at the military base, but suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army. ``We can't say who was responsible at this stage, but it looks as if the IRA are the main suspects,'' said Detective Chief Superintendent Derek Willison, second-in-command of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad. Two men driving in the area after the explosion were picked up and questioned about the blast, a Scotland Yard spokesman said. They were later released without charge. Ministry of Defense officials were investigating the attack while police forensic teams and anti-terrorist officers searched the base. Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad was called in to look for possible links with other recent attacks on military personnel. There have been at least eight attacks on military personnel or facilities in Britain since February. They are blamed on the IRA, which is seeking to end British rule in Northern Ireland. A civilian security guard on routine patrol found a suspicious looking blue rucksack between a perimeter fence and an administrative building shortly after 9 a.m., police said. He then called an inspector from the Harrow Police. The base, which contains living quarters for 40 air force officers and their families, and a nearby home for about 30 elderly people were evacuated, police said. An explosives expert was called, but the bomb exploded around 9:40 a.m. before he arrived on the scene. A police spokesman credited the quick evacuation with saving lives. ``They would have all been within the area of the bomb if they had not been evacuated,'' he said of the elderly people. Wing Commander Simon Appleton said there had been ``an apparent breach of perimeter security at the base.'' Willison said there was an outside chance that the bombers threw the explosive device over the 6{-foot wooden perimeter fence topped by barbed wire that surrounds the base. In the other bomb incident, investigators were looking into the possibility the two letter bombs had been sent by Welsh extremists, police said Thursday. No group claimed responsibility for the incendiary devices, a Welsh police spokesman said. The letter bomb addressed to Welsh Secretary David Hunt was intercepted Wednesday night by workers in the Westminster Palace mail room. A second letter bomb sent to Nicholas Bennett, a Conservative member of Parliament, also was intercepted by workers in the mail room at the House of Commons on Wednesday night. Bennett accused the Welsh organization Sons of Glendower of sending it. He said he had been targeted because he represented a Welsh constituency. Police were investigating two other letter bombs sent Wednesday, one of which slightly injured an office worker at a Welsh boat yard. The other, sent to a restaurant in Dolgellau, Wales, failed to go off and was handed over to police. Welsh nationalist extremists have waged a 10-year arson campaign aimed primarily at English-owned businesses and properties.

DOC.HEAD: Second Nuclear Test In Eight Days Detonated At Nevada Site
DOC.TEXT: Scientists conducted the second nuclear test in eight days Thursday, detonating a weapon deep beneath the surface of the Nevada Test Site. The Department of Energy said the explosion appeared to be as success. ``It was just a routine test,'' DOE spokesman Jim Boyer said. The explosion, which was not announced in advance, had a yield of less than 20 kilotons. The DOE classifies its tests as either less than 20 kilotons or between 20 and 150 kilotons. The blast registered a 4.1 on the Richter Scale at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. It followed a June 13 nuclear detonation that shook highrise buildings in the Las Vegas area and registered 5.6 on the Richter Scale. The latest test was the third announced this year by the DOE. Last year, a total of 12 nuclear detonations were announced. The test was the 702nd since testing began at the Nevada site in 1951.

DOC.HEAD: House Defeats Proposal to Move Primary to September
DOC.TEXT: The Illinois House rejected a proposal Thursday to push the 1994 Illinois primary back from March to September. Supporters said the change would cut campaign costs and boost voter interest by shortening the election season. Opponents complained it wouldn't leave enough time between elections. Under the proposal, sponsored by Rep. James DeLeo, D-Chicago, the 1994 primary would be held on the Tuesday after the second Monday in September. The primary now is held on the third Tuesday in March. The general election is on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November. The Senate-approved bill was defeated 71-37 in the House. ``Other states hold September primaries,'' said Rep. Peg Breslin, D-Ottawa, an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for state treasurer. ``It's imperative that we shorten the campaign season.'' In 1988, 15 states and the District of Columbia held September primaries. Only four other states _ Arkansas, Maryland, Mississippi and Texas _ held primaries in March. Rep. Grace Mary Stern, D-Highland Park, argued that holding the primary in September wouldn't leave enough time to mail absentee ballots. Similar legislation has been considered almost annually by the General Assembly for the past 12 years. This year's bill was sponsored by Senate President Philip Rock, D-Oak Park, who said it would reduce the cost of campaigning and increase voter interest.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Find 23rd Victim of Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Authorities searching through debris Thursday at a dam 25 miles downstream on the Ohio River found the 23rd victim of the flash floods that swept through this Appalachian hamlet last week. The victim, whose sex and identity were not immediately determined, was found at the series of locks at the dam at Hannibal, said Belmont County coroner's investigator Chuck Vogt. Vogt said he didn't know if the victim was on a list of 11 people missing since the June 14 flood. At least four of the people listed as still missing were known to have been in the area before the flood, he said. Authorities were unsure about the other seven. Engineers planned to use cranes mounted on three barges to remove debris backed up at the dam, said Steve Wright, a U.S. Army Corps of Engineer spokesman. The debris mostly consists of lumber from houses and parts of trees that were washed down the Wegee and Pipe creeks the night of the flood.

DOC.HEAD: Student in Hospital After Setting Self Afire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with official news agency report identifying self-immolation victim as unemployed man with history of mental disorder sted student, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A 32-year-old man set himself on fire in a city east of Sofia on Thursday after reading a statement alleging fraud in Bulgaria's recent elections, the official BTA news agency said. The man was rushed to a hospital in Stara Zagroa, about 150 miles east of Sofia, the capital, the news agency said. State radio earlier identified the man as a student. But BTA said he was unemployed, had three criminal convictions, including one for rape, and was under psychiatric supervision because he had previously tried three times to commit suicide. The news agency said the man set himself on fire afte reading a statement about alleged election irregularities to a group of protesters. In Sofia, meanwhile, four students at Kliment Ohridski University were in their 10th day of a hunger strike, and about 100 students were staging a sit-in protest. In order to dramatize their protest, some students experienced in mountain climbing began a ``suspension strike'' Wednesday, dangling on ropes attached to the university's roof. Initially the students protested what they claimed was a ``news blackout'' and alleged manipulation of Bulgaria's national elections held on the past two Sundays. In the vote, the former Communist Party, which has renamed itself the Socialist Party, won 211 seats in the 400-seat Parliament. Now the students also demand the resignation of TV director Pavel Pisarev and an independent investigation into whether President Petar Mladenov urged the use of tanks against demonstrators in December. The pro-democracy demonstrations led eventually to the ouster of the hard-line government of Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Kills Five in the Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Ofelia pounded northern Luzon island Friday with heavy rains and winds of up to 68 miles per hour. At least five people died in landslides, officials reported. Forecasters said the storm roared ashore early Friday on the east coast of Cagayan province, about 130 miles north of Manila, and was expected to cross the mountains of northern Luzon during the day. Storm warnings were raised over 13 Luzon provinces, and small craft were warned to remain in port. Residents of the affected provinces were told to be on alert for landslides and flooding. The Office of Civil Defense said a 60-year-old man and a child were killed in a landslide early Friday in the northwestern province of La Union. Three children died and six other people were injured when mud and debris lossened by heavy rains crashed down on their shanty dwellings Thursday in the Manila suburb of Pasig, police and Red Cross officials reported. The Canadian embassy said the storm delayed the arrival of a Canadian warship, the HMCS Provider, due in Manila Friday with 88 Vietnamese refugees picked up in the South China Sea. Officials reported flooding and landslides elsewhere in northern Luzon. Complete reports were unavailable because of poor communications. Traditionally, most casualties in Philippine typhoons are not caused by high winds but by flooding and landslides because rampant logging, much of it illegal, has bared huge tracts in the mountains. About 20 tropical storms or typhoons strike the Philippines yearly.

Lawmakers who defeated a proposed constitutional amendment against burning the American flag are bracing for a fierce fight on the campaign trail but say they sense a change of heart among many voters. ``Something that folks loathe almost as much as flag burners is politicians who demagogue, who wrap themselves in the flag for some partisan votes,'' Rep. Ben Jones, D-Ga., said after the measure failed to gain the necessary two-thirds majority Thursday. Democratic lawmakers who voted against it told reporters they detected a change among voters and said their mail is no longer running so heavily in favor of the amendment. The House voted 254-177 for the measure, which President Bush had been pressing since June 11, when the Supreme Court threw out the 1989 Flag Protection Act as unconstitutional.

Democrats, unable to override President Bush's veto of a bill to let federal workers join political campaigns, now want to extend the ban to Bush's Cabinet and hundreds of other presidential appointees. ``What's good for the goose is good for the gander,'' Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., said in introducing the new bill Thursday. Earlier, the Senate failed by two votes to override Bush' veto of the legislation to broaden federal workers' political rights. Pryor's new bill would extend the 1939 Hatch Act's ban on federal workers' political activities to the more than 350 employees on the White House payroll and another 600 presidential appointees. In vetoing the earlier bill Friday, Bush said that allowing federal workers to participate in campaigns ``would inevitably lead to repoliticizing the federal work force'' and ``destroy its essential political neutrality.''

Some in this city once notorious for political patronage were skeptical that a U.S. Supreme Court ruling outlawing the system of jobs for political work will put such abuses to rest. But Michael Shakman, a Chicago lawyer whose lawsuits helped pare patronage in the city, said the ruling Thursday could affect hiring practices throughout the country. ``It should result in a much fairer system to applicants for jobs who are no longer going to be required to give a political loyalty oath, in effect, in order to get the job,'' Shakman said. Fred Cooper, a Georgia Republican Party official, predicted a barrage of lawsuits alleging discrimination.

The government's list of foreigners barred from the country for political reasons is far longer than previously thought, and most names were added since the Reagan administration, documents show. Details of the so-called ``lookout book'' emerged in documents released in response to a lawsuit brought by a prize-winning Colombian journalist who was turned back at a New York airport four years ago. The list, previously estimated by immigration lawyers to have some 40,000 names, has 353,324 entries from 146 countries, territories and other areas. More than two-thirds of the entries appear to come after 1980. Officials cautioned there was no way of knowing how many individuals were on the list, because some of the names are entered more than once.

DOC.HEAD: Poverty and Pollution in Overcrowded Tehran
DOC.TEXT: The capital of Iran, jammed with poor peasants hunting jobs that aren't there, has become a morass of poverty and pollution. Its population has doubled to 8 million since the Islamic revolution of 1979, swollen by a birth rate of 3.5 percent a year and migration from the countryside. That is about one-seventh of the national population, 55 million. ``Tehran and other over-populated cities have expanded so much that a remedy has to be found,'' the daily newspaper Abrar declared. ``The problems are so complex that it seems even the most skilled planners are at a loss to find a workable program.'' Beyond the 8 million officially counted, Tehran has a floating population estimated at 2 million, most of them in shantytowns on its southern edge. Those squalid slums were the bedrock of support for Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died a year ago. In the park-studded northern suburbs, on the lower slopes of the Alborz Mountains overlooking the city, wealthy Iranians still live comfortably in their mansions and earn millions from real estate. Housing is in short supply, power cuts are frequent and there is no piped sewerage system. Drug abuse is rife despite a nationwide crackdown. Drinking water is becoming scarce and authorities speak of rationing. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said Tehran is ``the most polluted city in the world.'' Tehran's 1.5 million motor vehicles clog the streets in a single, vast traffic jam and the city is covered by choking smog. It may take an hour to travel five miles in central Tehran. These days, newspapers call Tehran traffic ``the national enemy'' instead of Iraq, with which Iran was at war for eight years until August 1988. Resalat, another daily, said in May that city buses are stuck in traffic jams for so long they burn 22 gallons of gas on a 30-mile route. It estimated Tehran residents spent 1.2 billion hours a year in traffic jams. On some days, the state radio advises old people to stay indoors because of the polluted air and warns mothers not to take young children out. Officials acknowledge planning has become a nightmare. A subway project is stalled, although President Hashemi Rafsanjani ordered it speeded up. The first 7-mile section, linking Mohseni Square to Imam Khomeini Square, was supposed to open in December. It didn't. ``We've been hearing about this metro (subway) since we were kids,'' a resident said. ``Now we're grown up and they're still just talking about it.'' A global survey published in May said Tehran was the world's most expensive city in dollar terms. The study by Corporate Resources Group of Geneva based its findings on prices of items ranging from food to leisure. If it had included housing costs, Tehran's numbers would have been even higher. A midtown apartment of about 325 square feet costs 200,000 rials a month ($2,857 at the official rate of exchange) to rent, plus a security deposit of 5 million rials ($71,428), Resalat reported. ``A civil servant, with several years' service, receives a monthly salary of 80,000 rials ($1,142). Assuming he manages to save 30,000 rials a month, he can save 360,000 rials a year,'' the paper said. ``He would have to work for a century to be able to afford to buy a suitable house!'' The price of eggs has doubled in a year and meat costs $27 a kilogram _ 2.2 pounds. Trousers that cost $100 a year ago now sell for $157. A Peykan sedan, based on the old British Hillman, costs $100,000. Residents of Tehran say they can barely survive on average monthly pay of 70,000 rials, about $1,000 at the official rate. ``I have to have two jobs that bring in a total of 100,000 rials,'' said Ali, a 42-year-old civil servant who moonlights as a taxi driver. Every disaster area has its share of people who do well, and Tehran is no exception. Expensive restaurants are crowded and grocery stores selling at black market prices _ 10 times normal rates _ are well-supplied with goods and customers. In government-run stores, where ordinary housewives spend hours in line, the shelves are bare.

DOC.HEAD: `P.O.V.' Documentary Series Starts Strong Third Season
DOC.TEXT: Three women convicted of crimes against the state are put in an underground prison. They're strip-searched daily, isolated from other inmates, and kept under 24-hour surveillance by guards and video cameras, even in the shower. Everything they do, including their conversations, is logged by their jailers. This isn't the gulag, but a federal prison. And it isn't fiction, but a documentary film, ``Through the Wire,'' airing Tuesday night to open the third season of ``P.O.V.,'' the independent filmmakers' series on PBS. ``Through the Wire'' is typical of the kinds of risk-taking, unconventional documentaries offered in the 12-week run of ``P.O.V.'' _ the cinematic abbreviation for ``point of view.'' The film examines the High Security Unit of the federal prison at Lexington, Ky., which was condemned as a sensory deprivation tank for U.S. political prisoners almost from the day it opened in 1986. The women's cells get virtually no natural light or ventilation. Their visiting rights, correspondence and reading matter are severely limited. They are barred from training, rehabilitation or recreation programs. Psychologists call the technique ``small group isolation.'' It makes prisoners easier to manage. It is scary to think about it being used against people convicted of politically motivated crimes. Next week's ``P.O.V.'' is just as unconventional. ``Metamorphosis: Man into Woman'' follows two years in the life of Gary, a man who suffers from ``gender dysphoria,'' the conviction that he is a woman trapped in a man's body. ``Metamorphosis'' follows Gary as he undergoes preliminary plastic surgery, therapy and other, subtler processes he must go through to live as a woman and qualify for ``sex reassignment'' surgery. It's a subdued and sympathetic portrait of a person braving a profound transformation. It's engrossing to watch Gary (and his friends and co-workers) cope with his struggle to become ``Gaby.'' In ``Through the Wire,'' U.S. Bureau of Prisons officials contend the high-security unit is not to punish or brainwash the women, but because they ``may be subject to rescue attempts by outside groups.'' The women are: _Susan Rosenberg, indicted in the 1983 bombing of the U.S. Capitol, serving 58 years for possession of weapons and explosives, with recommendation against parole; _Alejandrina Torres of the FALN Puerto Rican independence movement, serving 35 years for seditious conspiracy to bomb a U.S. military installation, with recommendation against parole; _Sylvia Baraldini, serving 43 years for conspiracy and racketeering in aiding and abetting the bloody 1981 Brink's armored car robbery in Nyack, N.Y. ``Through the Wire,'' produced, directed and co-written by Nina Rosenblum, has weaknesses, including the assertion that the women's crimes were ``non-violent'' when in fact they conspired in or furthered very violent acts indeed. There's also a jarringly unnecessary ``simulation'' of male guards at surveillance monitors watching one woman pacing back and forth, and another women showering with her back to the camera. We got the idea without it. And there are montages of home movies and still photos showing the women in their childhoods and pre-radical days. It suggests the obvious: That even cute, well-adjusted kids from nice families can become dedicated revolutionaries. And the film finds no irony in its portrayal of revolutionaries who attack a government they view as fundamentally evil, break its laws _ and then complain that the state isn't playing by the rules in the way it punishes them. Even so, it becomes obvious in the course of the film that these women are suffering in a punishing, oppressive environment. Rosenberg especially seems to decline physically and emotionally. None of them flourishes. Eventually, the women sue the Bureau of Prisons. In July 1988, U.S. District Judge Barrington Parker orders that Rosenberg and Baraldini be moved in with other inmates. He forbids the consideration of ``past political associations or personal political beliefs'' in deciding inmate transfers. He does not find that the unit's conditions unconstitutionally cruel, but says the prisoners' treatment ``skirted elemental standards of human decency.'' ``Through the Wire'' concludes with a few ominous notes: Parker's ruling subsequently was overruled by an appeals court. The Lexington unit was closed, but the Bureau of Prisons opened a new high-security prison in Marianna, Fla., in September 1988. And there are 16 prisons with similar high-security units currently under construction or in planning in the United States.

Elsewhere in television ... RISKY BUSINESS? ``TODAY'' TAPS TOP GUN RAIN MAN: ``Like Thunder,'' the auto racing movie starring Tom Cruise, Robert Duvall and Nicole Kidman, gets a five-day scrutiny on NBC's ``Today'' show this week. The usually TV-shy Cruise, star of ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' ``Rain Man'' and other box-office hits, appears on two interview segments this week. Co-stars Duvall and Kidman have their own segments, and ``Today'' rounds out the week with producers Jerry Bruckheimer and Don Simpson. End Adv PM Mon June 25

DOC.HEAD: Woman Helps Keep Elvis Alive At U.S. Postal Service
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Pat Geiger, known around town as ``the Elvis Lady,'' has spent the past seven years keeping Elvis Presley alive. Elvis the postage stamp, that is. From the kitchen table of her tidy, comfortable home on Route 10, Geiger runs the ``Elvis Postage Stamp Campaign.'' Her goal is to convince the U.S. Postal Service to give ``The King'' its stamp of approval. ``Without question, Elvis Presley is the perfect subject for a U.S. commemorative postage stamp,'' Geiger said. ``He was and, even though he left us 13 years ago, continues to be one of this country's greatest goodwill ambassadors.'' Her devotion may pay off. A Postal Service official says Elvis is, indeed, still alive _ in a postal sense. ``There's a very good chance that sometime in the future there will be an Elvis stamp,'' said Frank Thomas, a Postal Service marketing specialist in Washington, D.C. ``Personally, I think there will be.'' The major obstacle for a Presley postage stamp is ``concern over the lifestyle issue,'' Thomas said. The Postal Service has received mail complaining that honoring a known drug abuser ``sends a bad message'' to America's youth, he said. But Geiger scoffs at that notion, pointing to other stamp subjects with controversial private lives. Presley stamps already have been issued in at least seven countries, including West Germany, she said. Since beginning her campaign in 1983, Geiger said she has gone through five postmasters general and is now on her sixth, Anthony Frank. Frank reportedly said soon after taking office that he supports an Elvis stamp. But after the ensuing outcry over Presley's well-documented drug abuse _ the King died of an overdose in 1977 _ Frank retreated and said the issue requires further review. His wavering prompted Geiger to publicly call him a ``wimp.'' It also renewed her determination to honor the man she credits with changing her life. ``I will not give up until either Elvis gets his stamp or I die, whichever comes first,'' the 70-year-old great-grandmother said over a lunchtime beer. To understand the extent of Geiger's passion for Presley, one must visit her house. It is wall-to-wall _ and floor-to-ceiling _ Elvis. Posters line every wall, most highlighting Presley's 1970s jumpsuit phase. Bookcases are stuffed with Presley tomes, both reverential and scandalous. Shelves burst with videocassettes of Presley movies, and photo albums hold thousands of pictures. That's not including her records and tapes. The first Presley picture Geiger bought, a black-and-white shot taken at a 1968 press conference, will be buried with her, she vows. ``Pictures are my addiction,'' Geiger said, then adds, ``Pardon me, Evis, for using that word.'' Presleymania came late in Geiger's life. Although her older son dressed in pink and black in the 1950s to emulate Presley, Geiger did not convert until a 1968 TV show known as the ``Comeback Special.'' ``I looked at that man in that black leather suit and said `Phew!,''' Geiger said. ``I sat in that chair and said, `Nobody is that good looking.' It was kind of sudden. I was never the same after that night.'' The postage stamp entered her life in 1983, when a fellow Presley fan mentioned the idea. After some investigating, Geiger learned ordinary citizens are not eligible for stamp consideration until 10 years after their deaths. So Geiger spent the next several years laying the groundwork for her big 1987 push. ``I thought it would be a simple thing,'' she said. ``Boy, was I naive.'' Postal Service officials have come to know Geiger well, Thomas said. She is, in fact, one of their best customers, firing off letters to anybody connected with the agency. ``You name `em, I've written to 'em,'' she said, waving a wrist adorned with an Elvis Presley watch. Commemorative postage stamps are nominated by the 15-member Citizens' Stamp Advisory Committee, which meets every two months, and then must be approved by the postmaster general, Thomas said. Although Presley has been eligible for three years, he still has not been chosen for the honor. Does this mean Elvis _ the stamp _ is dead? ``No, not at all,'' Thomas said. The committee might include Presley in a stamp series on American musicians, but that doesn't sit well with Geiger. ``Elvis was one of a kind! There will never be another!'' she said. ``He does not fit into a group!'' The committee will announce next year's commemorative stamps within a month, Thomas said. ``If they don't announce it, that doesn't mean it won't show up in 1991,'' he said. ``The fact that they're spending so much time on the subject is a positive sign.'' Meanwhile, Geiger waits impatiently and spends her days mostly on Presley-related matters. There are the constant letters from supporters around the world, the radio appearances, the newspaper interviews. ``How did I get here? I absolutely do not know,'' she said. ``Next to my children, he's the most important person in my life. I don't know what I'd do if there wasn't an Elvis.''

DOC.HEAD: Sludge, Sawdust, Fuel Commercial Compost Operation
DOC.TEXT: Using a farm machine like a giant mixing spoon, Don Wilkinson whips up a batch of sewage sludge, sawdust and paper-mill waste, carefully protecting his recipe for garden feed and fill. ``It's hard to get the formula. So we don't let it out,'' Wilkinson said, after climbing down a monstrous device that has just chewed up a 100-yard-long pile of the reeking, black concoction. Wilkinson is chief operator at the Hawk Ridge Compost Facility, which turns organic waste into products sold to contractors and nurseries. It's also hoping to turn a profit before long. After only six months, the facility already is paying its costs and looking forward to making money on its landscaping and garden supplements, which are made with industrial and municipal sludges long dismissed as useless. ``All we're doing is speeding up nature's own work,'' said Jamie Ecker, acting manager of Hawk Ridge. But the facility is a pioneer in what is widely seen as an industry of the future. Not only does it recycle materials that would otherwise be dumped in landfills, but it provides evidence that caring for the environment doesn't always have to cost money. ``The market for these kinds of recycled materials will take off and enhance our ability to make money on the venture,'' said William Ginn, president of the Yarmouth-based Resource Conservation Services Inc., which owns Hawk Ridge and is involved in a variety of recycling enterprises. ``We think composting is going to be one of the major solid-waste solutions,'' Ginn said. Each week, Hawk Ridge accepts 25 dumptruck loads of dried sewage sludge from nearly a dozen communities, along with six tractor trailers of sawdust and 10 dumptruck loads of paper-mill waste. Hawk Ridge is paid to take the sludge and mill waste, but it buys the sawdust, which is becoming increasingly scarce as more paper mills burn it for energy. Wilkinson and his assistant, Doug Knowlton, make a new batch of compost by taking a base of the old stuff, adding paper-mill sludge, a layer of sawdust as a bulking agent, and sewage sludge. Once the mixture reaches the crucial 131-degree temperature, it's turned by steel teeth protruding from huge rollers on a custom-designed machine, which is driven over the piles every day for 15 days. The heat resulting from bio-chemical reactions kills disease-causing bacteria in the compost heaps. While the process seems as simple as spreading manure, Ecker said it took time to develop a mixing and curing formula that results in a safe, odorless and commercially viable product using readily available wastes. The process is even tracked by computer to make sure each batch of compost is made according to ``recipe,'' said Wilkinson. Nora Goldstein, executive editor of Biocycle magazine, a journal of waste recycling, said she knows of no other facility that accepts such a wide assortment of wastes for composting. She also said it is one of few that is privately owned. A number of municipalities have their own sludge facilities and yard-waste sites. Since it opened in March, Hawk Ridge has turned out 6,000 cubic yards of composted material, Ecker said. Its commercial mix is used for such projects as landfill closings and highway and industrial park landscaping. A ``homeowners' mix,'' as Ecker calls it, is made without paper-mill sludge, which may contain tiny amounts of dioxin. That ensures it is completely safe for gardens. Ecker said the company is still in the start-up phase. ``We're not expecting to burn up the mortgage right away,'' he said. ``After all, no one has done this before on this kind of scale.'' But the possibilities appear endless. Hawk Ridge will be processing food and paper wastes from fast food restaurants in New Hampshire in July to see if composting is cheaper for them than other means of disposal, Ecker said. The facility is composting food wastes from a Maine processor, and may run trials of old supermarket produce. And an experiment mixing paper plates with sewage sludge ``was a huge success,'' said Wilkinson. ``It degraded nice.''

DOC.HEAD: Housing Shortage Reveals Dark Side of City of Light
DOC.TEXT: Not far from Satan's Alley and a dead-end street called God, 48 families live in a public square. They are victims of a war on squatters waged by a city of plenty with little room for its poor. Since March 15, when a winter moratorium on evictions ended, riot police arriving before dawn have cleared dozens of buildings. The evictions inspire denunciations, demonstrations and charges that the city of Paris, where housing prices are soaring, is trying to push the poor out of town. ``We're miserable here because we have nothing,'' said Assa Kan, a 30-year-old woman from Mali with six children. They are among 150 people who have lived under tents since May 2 in the Place de la Reunion. ``At night, it's really cold,'' she said, caressing the chapped cheeks of her 4-month-old daughter. ``All the children are sick.'' Hers is the largest of three camps set up by squatters or renters turned out of condemned buildings. Nine families camp at the foot of Sacre Coeur, the Montmartre basilica, and six live outside a city government office. In announcing the spring offensive, Paris officials said squatting had reached ``inadmissible'' proportions. ``The city is duty-bound to solve this problem'' and evictions are ``the only way to stop the multiplication of squatters,'' said Jean Tiberi, deputy to Mayor Jacques Chirac. Within days, 300 people were homeless, nearly half of them children. ``These people had a right to squat,'' said Abbe Pierre, a bearded Roman Catholic cleric who is France's premier champion of the needy. ``When a man is hungry, he has the right to take bread from the baker.'' Abbe Pierre's humanitarian organization, the Emmaus Community, provided tents for those evicted. A siege mentality prevails in the Place de la Reunion, which is ringed with rosebushes and dotted with orange and blue tents. Amenities consist of one water spigot, three portable toilets like those used at construction sites, and intermittent lighting at night via an extension cord from a nearby cafe. One tent serves as a kitchen. Mrs. Kan and others said they would remain until the city provided a suitable alternative. ``We are confronted with the unacceptable,'' Bertrand Main, deputy chief of the League of Human Rights, told reporters. ``Demands for rehousing are met with a wall of silence, incomprehension and, sometimes, contempt.'' Paris proposed temporary housing for the evicted in buildings scheduled for demolition in St. Denis, a poor northern suburb. Officials there objected. ``We don't have a money problem in Paris; we have a problem of land,'' Tiberi, the deputy mayor, said in explaining the housing shortage on French radio. ``For moral reasons ... we cannot accept the principle of rehousing squatters,'' who rob legal occupants of apartment space, he said. At a news conference, Abbe Pierre said: ``It is a crime to refuse lodging in a city like Paris, where several thousand apartments are vacant.'' The Committee Against Poor Housing, a protest group that finds vacant buildings for squatters, claims there are 3,000 to 4,000 vacant, government-subsidized Moderate Rent Housing units around Paris. The city denies it. Officials say the number of buildings occupied by squatters, most of them Africans, has grown from 36 to 187 in three years and 41 of the buildins are subsidized units, which have a waiting list of 50,000. Mayor Chirac said in a letter to Abbe Pierre, made public June 20, that rehousing evicted squatters would be a ``profound injustice'' to people on the waiting list. ``Paris is a city with heart,'' he said, ``but ... neither the capital nor the Paris region can take in all the misery of the world.'' Critics claim the city is being transformed into a ghetto for the elite. President Francois Mitterrand denounced those ``who enrich themselves while sleeping'' because they own ``a good piece of land or a nice apartment.'' Prices have risen so quickly, he said, ``that they are starting to exclude the possibility of suitable lodging for senior executives with salaries that can reach 50,000 francs per month,'' about $8,700. Frederica Koch and Amina Amara are among those keeping a vigil with the homeless at the Place de la Reunion. Ms. Koch was evicted last year from the rent-controlled apartment she occupied for 25 years and, at 58, is a squatter. She lost her job as a clothes cutter during a 10-year battle to keep her home. Ms. Amara, a single woman with five children, has been on a waiting list for a low-rent apartment for 15 years. After eviction from one building, she and her two youngest children spent a year in a shabby hotel and two months in a restaurant basement before squatting anew in December. ``This problem is too big for us,'' said Berhima Tembely, an immigrant from Senegal who paid a sympathy visit to the square. ``The rich people are treating us like dogs. You have to fight to live in this world.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs, June 28

DOC.HEAD: Khomeini's Ghost Still Stalks Iran
DOC.TEXT: The ghost of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini stalks the Islamic republic a year after his death, in the form of a power struggle among the Imam's disciples that remains unresolved. The revolution Khomeini began 11 years ago survives,however, frustrating the doomsayers who predicted it would fall apart when he was no longer there to unite the factions. Moves by President Hashemi Rafsanjani and his ``pragmatists'' toward a more liberal course have been stymied by anti-Western radicals who accuse him of straying from ` Imam,'' as Khomeini was known. Both groups claim to be Khomeini's true ideological heirs and invoke his commandments to justify their actions. An Iranian official, speaking anonymously, said Rafsanjani sought t`the path of theo legitimize his more liberal policies through subtle interpretations of Khomeini's teachings. In response, the 270-member parliament passed a law in May that makes changing Khomeini's writings a crime. The parliament is dominated by radical followers of Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a former interior minister. The radicals include Ahmad Khomeini, 44, the ayatollah's only surviving son. He has made no apparent effort to claim his father's mantle and is overshadowed by rotest demanding the government not involve itself in the hostage issue. Diplomats in Tehran say Rafsanjani appears determined to show the West he is moving the country away from isolation. In an effort to create a more liberal social and political climate, he has eased restrictions Khomeini placed on Iran's 55 million people. He cannot move quickly because of radical opposition and faces growing discontent from a populace whose expectations were raised when he gained power. There have been demonstrations against shortages, unemployment estimated at 4 million, and high inflation. Opposition groups say the Revolutionary Guards killed several protesters and arrested scores. Some progress has been made. Diplomats estimate inflation was trimmed from 30 percent to 20 percent in the past year and the government has contracts for major investment projects estimated to be worth billions of dollars. Rafsanjani's plans depend on oil revenue. It is expected to be about $15 billion this year, but nothing is certain in the volatile oil market. ``The authorities know they have at best one or two years grace before economic problems produce dangerous political dissatisfaction,'' Vahe Petrossian, an Iranian analyst based in London, wrote last month in the Middle east Economic Digest. A waiter named Khosrow in a Tehran restaurant said: ``All I want are three square meals a day for myself and my family. Someone has to rule, but I don't really care who it is so long as I have enough to provide a roof for my family. ``During the war I never complained, but enough is enough.'' Mehrdad, a taxi driver, said: ``I think most of the people are behind Rafsanjani and they know he's trying to do something good for us.'' Asked if restoring relations with the United States did not go against Khomeini's teachings, he replied: ``The Imam said we must strike a blow against the United States. How are we hurting the United States when we pay triple the price for American goods because we buy them through middlemen? ``We would strike a more effective blow if we resumed ties and rebuilt our economy and industry so we become truly independent and powerful.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, June 29
For Release Weekend Editions, June 23-24, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Beatty Has Goods To Sell But Also Looking for Way To Cope
By BOB THOMAS
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Warren Beatty, once among the most secretive of film stars, is suddenly popping up all over the place: Arsenio, Oprah, Letterman, ``Good Morning, America'' and ``Today.'' Why? Because he has some goods to sell, namely ``Dick Tracy,'' his stylish movie rendition of the old comic strip. But Beatty did virtually nothing to promote his last three films, ``Ishtar,'' ``Reds'' and ``Heaven Can Wait.'' He recently explained the change of heart. ``For 12 or 13 years I didn't do much in the way of interviews. That makes room for anybody to make up anything they want, and some of the results can be disturbing. I decided there was no way to cope with that unless you talk to people,'' he said. He has done more talking to the media in the past 10 days than at any time in his 30-year film career. At the ``Dick Tracy'' premiere last week at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., he conducted a news conference before a mass of reporters. Before leaving for a round of satellite interviews in New York, Beatty talked by telephone about the aftermath of the movie's opening. _ About the first weekend's gross _ $21 million from 2,200 screens: ``I've never had that kind of opening. The numbers are great. I really never expected anything like it. After all, `Dick Tracy' didn't have a following from a comic book or a TV series (like `Batman').'' _ About the reviews: ``They're amazing. Virtually unanimous. The only bad one we got was one of the first by some guy whose name I don't know.'' It was Joseph McBride of Daily Variety, who called the film ``a major disappointment.'' Executives from the Walt Disney Co. were so proud of the critical raves that they ran double-page newspaper ads reprinting them in toto. Beatty first became interested in ``Dick Tracy'' many years ago, but the project passed through other hands until he finally resolved to make it with Disney. Why did he wait so long? ``It is such a detailed picture that it wasn't something you could just go out and shoot. I was involved in other things, including a Howard Hughes story I've been wanting to do. Then I began getting ideas about how to do `Dick Tracy.' I think you get around to making a picture when you can no longer put it off.'' Most critics have praised the look of ``Dick Tracy'' _ the use of the same basic colors without different shades. Beatty said the concept originated in a conversation with playwright Herb Gardner (``I'm Not Rappaport''). ``He used to do a comic strip, and he told me how the printer had numbers for the colors on the rotogravure, which was the paper they used in those days. For instance, red might be number 2, and he would give the number to a hat, a car, a flower and so forth. I was captivated by that idea.'' Many reviewers commended the outlandish characters of Al Pacino and Dustin Hoffman as well as the sex-charged Madonna. Beatty does not appear to feel slighted that his own performance was sometimes overlooked: ``What appealed to me was that the material allowed for some outrageous performances. All the people were so interesting that it was good for the picture. ``In the comic strip, Dick Tracy was always the solid guy in the middle of all these weird characters. He was very, very straight, and that's how I played him.'' The initial prosperity of ``Dick Tracy'' has led to talk of a sequel. Beatty commented cautiously: ``I've never done a sequel, but I wouldn't totally rule it out. Then again, there are so many other things to do. And movies aren't the only thing in my life.''
