DOC.HEAD: No Party is Blameless in S&L Mess
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Since politicians in both parties aided and abetted the savings and loan scandal, it takes some rewriting of history to make the mess into a 1990 congressional campaign issue for either Republicans or Democrats. Both sides are trying, in a dispute that has them shouting about blame but saying little about solutions to the problems behind the biggest bailout in American history. After his spokesman waded into the S&L dispute, President Bush endorsed the counterattack, but claimed the high road. ``I think more important than continuing to pour fuel on that spark is continuing to work with the Congress in trying to get that mess solved,'' he said Wednesday. The White House already had provided a text for Republican revisionists by claiming that in the dead of night a decade ago, Democrats pushed through legislation to sharply increase the ceiling on deposit insurance and ease restrictions on savings and loan lending practices. In fact, Republicans collaborated on the measure, which had a GOP coauthor and overwhelming support in both parties. It passed the House 380 to 13, with only five Republicans voting no. The Senate approved it without a roll call vote. When President Jimmy Carter signed it on March 31, 1980, he called it a bipartisan, landmark reform, an important move toward deregulation and a boon to small savers. Democrats prefer to start the crisis clock running a bit later, after Ronald Reagan took office, putting the blame on his administration and his vice president, George Bush, for lax regulation of savings and loans. When Reagan signed a bill in 1982 permitting S&Ls to make commercial loans and increase consumer lending _ leeway that licensed riskier ventures with federally insured deposits _ he said it was a long-term solution to industry problems. ``All in all, I think we hit the jackpot,'' he said. Some jackpot. That bill, it should be noted, had Democratic sponsorship and support. Nor do Democrats talk much about the way House Democratic leaders stalled and sliced measures to start dealing with industry problems sooner, at costs that now look like a bargain. Resigned House Speaker Jim Wright had a hand in that; his involvement with savings and loan interests and his intervention with regulators were factors in his downfall. Four of the five senators involved in the most celebrated of the savings and loan cases are Democrats. The Senate Ethics Committee is investigating their intercession with federal regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. and his now bankrupt Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, after he gave them campaign contributions. So some Democrats have taken to arguing that the savings and loan crisis should be viewed in two installments, before Bush and after Bush. They argue that the Bush administration has mishandled the bailout, miscalculated the cost, and done too little to prosecute S&L wrongdoers and reclaim their take. Bush says his goal is to protect depositors and bring the guilty to justice, and that he's doing both. But almost across the board, both parties have their problems. ``There's plenty of blame to go around,'' said Sen. Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. ``In the final analysis, it lies everywhere.'' That's because of the attributes that have made savings and loan interests so powerful politically and in lobbying for their aims. There's a branch in almost every town, a bloc in every congressional district, all with money to spend on campaign contributions. That has led members of both parties to say, write and do things they may now regret. The standard explanation is that the letter, or phone call, or visit was in behalf of a constituent. ``There's enough _ a lot of responsibility for every place, but I see some disturbing signs of Democrats wanting to make this political to Republicans, and I just want to put them on notice that this plays both ways and we're ready to play,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in his surprise attack on Tuesday. ``A big part of the problem here is that in the dead of night a few years ago, the Democrats pushed through raising the limits to $100,000 per person,'' he said. ``I am sure the president is concerned about this becoming a campaign issue in 1992,'' said Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., a critic of the way the bailout is being managed, and a target of the Fitzwater attack. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo says the S&L crisis will be a heavyweight issue for Democrats in the 1992 presidential campaign. Cuomo, who could be the Democratic challenger next time, is making it one of his issues now, saying that because of lax regulators, the bankers ``stole everything in sight. They fouled up everything in sight and now you are paying.'' Sen. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo., who wants Bush to set up an independent commission to investigate the S&L situation, said ``The real danger with this terrible crisis is that it will deteriorate into partisan warfare.'' It is.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Policemen in Medellin: Profitable Targets
DOC.TEXT: A policeman in the Medellin cartel's hometown goes to work each day with an assault rifle, a bulletproof vest and a prayer. The drug lords will pay $4,300 to anyone who kills him. So far this year, more than 120 have been slain. Policemen say they live on nerve and in fear of being the next victim. Some routinely arrive home with pistol drawn in case an assassin lurks in the shadows. Dozens of of the victims were murdered while off duty. Police in Medellin are part of a national force of 80,000 men, which is part of the military and under Defense Ministry jurisdiction. The government, which declared war on drug traffickers last year, has sent 1,800 reinforcements in recent weeks to augment the normal force of 2,600. The killings continue at an average of one a day in this city of 3 million, Colombia's second-largest. If the same percentage of police officers was killed in New York City, which has a force of 26,000, the total would surpass 1,000. An Associated Press reporter talked with 30 Medellin policemen and accompanied seven on a patrol of a dangerous part of Medellin. An officer pointed out the spots where six comrades had been killed in the past two months. ``I get scared out here,'' one said. ``I see a movement in the shadows or hear a motorcycle moving toward me and the hair stands up on the back of my neck. I wonder if this is it. I wonder if I'm the next victim.'' None wanted his name used, figuring it would be a death warrant. High-ranking Medellin police officials refused to be interviewed about the dangers their men face. The patrolmen said the drug cartel's tactics had caused 300 police resignations in three months and recruiting was difficult. ``I'm ready to quit if I don't get a transfer out of here soon,'' a 20-year-old policeman said. ``We're just statistics.'' He and the others said they were frightened, and exhausted by working up to 18 hours six days a week, but most said they would not quit. ``You can die of hunger, too,'' a 12-year veteran commented. Their families are destroyed along with the policemen. An officer's widow gets only half his $95 monthly salary as a pension, said a spokesman for the national police in Bogota. Three widows said they could not support their children on that. ``My children don't get milk, they don't get meat, they don't know what eggs taste like,'' Ruth Duque said. ``When they get sick, we just pray. There isn't any money for medicine.'' Mrs. Duque's situation is even worse because she gets no pension at all. Her husband was killed March 23, 1988, before the pension law was passed. She said she makes the equivalent of about $102 a month working in a drugstore. She feeds her son and daughter, aged 4 and 3, one meal a day of rice and beans. Colombia's minimum wage equals about $100 a month. A quart of milk costs 75 cents and a one-pound loaf of bread $1. Unemployment is over 30 percent in Medellin, according to sociologists at the local university. The government says the rate is 10 percent, but doesn't count thousands of people who mow lawns, work as sidewalk peddlers or have other part-time jobs. ``I've been looking for a job ever since my husband was killed,'' said Socorro Rua. Her husband was killed May 19 by a man who stuck a gun in his ribs on a crowded bus. Her 15-year-old daughter, Liliana, turned her head away and tears coursed down her cheeks. Mrs. Rua also has a 6-year-old son, Carlos. They live in an apartment complex built by the government for policemen. The shabby three-room apartment costs only $20 a month, but even that may be out of reach because officials have told her the pension paperwork will take a year. Another widow, Carmen Montoya, said she had high hopes for their children when her husband was alive, but ``now we just try to get by day to day. My little boy wanted a toy car for his birthday. I cried when he asked me, because I knew I couldn't afford it. They don't get anything at Christmas.'' ``My little girl used to chatter and sing all the time before her daddy was killed,'' she said. ``Now she just stares and hardly says a word. ``I asked the police department to pay for a psychologist to see her, but they told me there is no money for that.'' Mrs. Montoya has two children _ Lina, 5, and Alexander, 3. She receives about $80 a month because her husband had 20 years on the force.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 1

DOC.HEAD: Korean War Still Unresolved on 40th Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 24th graf, `Men fought,' to CORRECT to Pork Chop Hill
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Korean War, sometimes called the forgotten war, began June 25, 1950. More than 5 million American men and women served in Korea, and more than 54,000 died. After 40 years, no peace treaty has been signed.

On a Sunday morning 40 years ago, North Korea sent thousands of troops across the 38th parallel into South Korea, starting a war that killed more than a million people, including 54,000 American soldiers. It is the only war the United States has entered in this century that remains unresolved. The Korean peninsula, divided after World War II, still is split between the communist North and the capitalist South. The invasion stunned and enraged the West. The North Koreans occupied Seoul, the South Korean capital, in three days and overran most of the southern half of the peninsula in six weeks. Fifteen nations sent soldiers to fight for South Korea under the U.S.-led United Nations Command. Another 25 provided medical aid, food and weapons. China, with war just across its border, sent hundreds of thousands of soldiers to help the North. When a cease-fire took effect 37 months later, the losses were staggering: an estimated 2.4 million soldiers and 4.4 million civilians killed or wounded. Military dead totaled more than 800,000. A land of remarkable beauty lay ravaged, treeless, burned Jand barren. The Korean War was a traumatic chapter in American history and its impact on succeeding generations has been profound. It was an inglorious war without victory, often nearly forgotten, patched into history between World War II and Vietnam. No peace treaty has been signed. ``It was a war in which we turned the tide against communism for the first time, in a victory regrettably sometimes ignored by history,'' President Bush said at a dinner for veterans of the war. Korea was the first confrontation of the big powers in the nuclear age. It intensified hostilities between East and West, and and spurred a U.S.-Soviet arms race that only now is ending. From it grew the notion that communism in East Asia could be contained with help from the U.S. military. That led to American intervention in Vietnam a decade later. Forty years after the battle, North and South Korea watch one another from behind barbed wire and concrete bunkers on either side of a demilitarized zone 2{ miles wide and 155 miles long. The single telephone line between them is in Red Cross offices. There is no mail, radio or television communication, no direct travel without the permission of both governments, which is hardly ever given. Nearly 9,000 American military personnel still are unaccounted for or listed as prisoners. Last month, in a gesture seen as a political overture to Washington, North Korea returned what it said were the remains of five American soldiers. It was the first such action since 1954. The American Korean War Veterans Association says it has reports from witnesses indicating some Americans still may be alive in North Korea or other communist countries. Sporadic dialogue has occurred between the Koreas over the years, but little progress has been made in lessening tension, mutual suspicion and distrust. They have accused each other of more than 1 million violations of the armistice agreement, an average of 75 a day since the war ended. Reunification of the peninsula, long a dream of Koreans on both sides, remains elusive. The United States keeps 43,000 soldiers in South Korea to deter another invasion. There are plans to reduce the number, but some U.S. forces are expected to remain indefinitely. For Washington, the conflict of 1950-53 was a war in which the politicians wrenched control from the generals. It is remembered as much for President Harry Truman's firing of Douglas MacArthur as for the general's bold strategy of pushing the enemy back with an amphibious landing at Inchon, a western port. Historians divide the Korean war into the first year of dramatic, far-reaching maneuvers and the next two years of static, positional battle. Americans were not prepared mentally or physically for a war fought in foxholes and trenches on rugged, mountainous terrain that was freezing in winter and scorching in summer. No place was so cold, so dirty. Grease from a hundred C rations was frozen to parkas and gloves. Underwear wasn't changed for months. Perspiration in boots turned to ice in winter. Blood froze on wounds before it could coagulate. Men fought hand-to-hand for small pieces of territory called Punchbowl, Pork Chop Hill, Heartbreak Ridge, Bunker Hill. Each changed hands many times. More than 5 million men and women served in the American forces. Their casualties were 103,284 wounded and 54,246 dead, including 33,629 killed in combat. The infantry bore the brunt of the fighting. What began as a crusade to save South Korea from communism enjoyed only brief public popularity. Soldiers returned home not to a hero's welcome, but to a public dissatisfied with an unpopular, unsatisfactory war. Weary soldiers, disheartened and dispirited, faded into the placid, properous American society of the 1950s, keeping their pain to themselves. Not until Vietnam veterans received public attention did the Korean vets begin to organize. They formed an association five years ago and are trying to raise $10.5 million for a memorial. Korea is the only war without a memorial in Washington. In South Korea, the war is called the 6-25 incident, reflecting the date it began and the Korean preference for numbering rather than naming events. Some South Koreans feel shame that the country needed help to defend itself and the anniversary is not a cause for celebration. Many people who remember those days remain deeply grateful to the Americans. Monuments have been built in rice paddies and town squares to all nations that sent soldiers and aid. The relationship between South Korea and the United States has changed dramatically in the past 40 years. South Korea's booming economy and growing pride in its own accomplishments make it less tolerant of pressure from Washington on economic, trade and political issues. Anti-American sentiment continues to grow. Visiting Korean-Americans say relatives and others scold them for wearing American-style haircuts and clothes, and for speaking Korean with American accents. Most Koreans disapprove of militants who burn U.S. flags and shout ``Yankee go home,'' however, and polls indicate they want American troops to remain.

DOC.HEAD: Swept Away: `I Thought This Must Be a Dream'
DOC.TEXT: It was a week of sadness in Shadyside, a time for goodbyes that were all too sudden and too soon. There were farewells to the young mother who sang in the church choir and to the little boys she loved so dearly. To husbands and wives who lived, then died together. To sons and daughters who played side by side. Ten days ago, they were victims of nature's fury, a flash flood that killed 23 people, a torrent of water that swept away lives, homes and businesses, ravaging the outskirts of this Appalachian foothills community. ``God never makes you face anything greater than you can handle,'' says Schools Superintendent Bob Henry. But, he says, ``Sometimes it really saps your faith.''

In the office of Jefferson Elementary School, school board member Bette Anne Ponzo fields calls at the makeshift crisis center and clutches two pieces of paper: one bearing the names of 23 dead, the other those of 11 missing. As more bodies are found, one list grows longer, the other shorter. In this town of 4,300, so many people have so many memories of the dead. Ronald Palmer remembers Jerry and Patsy Krupa, a young couple just starting out in life. ``They'd do anything in the world for you, help you in any way they could,'' says Palmer, 30, a firefighter who knew Jerry since kindergarten. Patsy's 28th birthday was last Sunday _ the day her body was found. Becky Glaser remembers her daughter's friend Kerri Polivka, 13, a gifted student. ``She danced. She sang. She did everything,'' Mrs. Glaser recalls. Mrs. Ponzo remembers John and Edna Andrecht. He was a retired school janitor; she baked breads and canned goods for friends. Mrs. Ponzo's husband, Ray, remembers the Humphrey boys, David, 10, and Danny, 8, who died with their 35-year-old mother, Sue. Sue was in the church choir and played flute when she was in high school. David was a budding saxophonist. Both played for Ponzo, the band director. ``Sue was quiet, but energetic,'' Ponzo says. ``David was the same. Must have been patterned after her. He tried hard.'' One generation, then another, now both gone. ``It's always hard for me when a young person goes,'' Ponzo says. ``I'm 59. I've pretty much done a lot of the things I should do, but they'll never have a chance. ...'' Mrs. Ponzo's eyes brim with tears. ``You watch kids grow up and have families,'' she says. ``When something like this happens, you hurt. They're part of you.'' ``Every time there's a loss here, somebody knows them,'' Mrs. Glaser says. ``Everybody knows everybody's kids. That's why you call it home.''

The Pipe and Wegee creeks, two normally tranquil tributaries of the Ohio River, erupted June 15 when 5{ inches of rain fell in less than three hours. A wall of water, 20 feet high and 300 feet wide _ as long as a football field _ tore through the hollows, ripping asphalt from the ground, snapping trees like toothpicks, hurling cars in the air and sweeping people out of their homes. It came so fast, there was no warning. But for every tragedy, for every death, there are amazing stories of survival in Shadyside, tales of people beating the odds, literally hanging on for their lives. Helen Saffle is one. On the flood night, the 54-year-old diabetic was at home when the power went out and the water rushed in. Soon it was waist-high. The couch started to float. She latched onto it. She thought she'd climb to the ceiling for air, but when she looked, the roof was gone. The raging water smashed her house to pieces and sucked her out. She grabbed a tank, let go, repeatedly ducked under the water to avoid debris. ``I kept calm. I prayed all the time,'' she says. ``Then I came up against something solid. It was a tree uprooted. ... I was completely naked. I had a gown but (had pulled it off because) it was smothering and choking me.'' ``I remember at one time I thought this must be a dream,'' she recalls. ``I said, `No, This is like the Johnstown flood.' '' A rescuer eventually heard Mrs. Saffle's screams and carried her to safety. She was bruised and cut, but otherwise unharmed. ``If it was God's will for me to die, I would have. He needed me for some reason.'' Perhaps it was divine intervention that brought the survivors through; perhaps it was their own wits and willpower. But many told similar stories. Nine-year-old Amber Colvin and her babysitter, Kerri Polivka, tried to float in a bathtub. The tub broke and Kerri was killed, but Amber clung to a log and wooden shingles in the Ohio River for seven hours before she was able to paddle to shore, about seven miles from home. ``I can doggie paddle a little, but I only had to do that once,'' she says. Ken Gibbons, who owned the now-destroyed 3 K's Night Club, grabbed his home's rafters as the house was ripped off its foundation. It carried him about 800 yards. ``You ever see a ball in a pinball machine? That's what it was like. I could hear it (the house) hitting stuff and crunching,'' he says, surveying his crushed 1979 red Corvette and shiny '83 gold Jaguar and clutching one of his remaining belongings _ the muddy 1947 wedding certificate of his late parents. His brother, Charlie, whose trailer was destroyed, was swept under a house as he tried to get his wife and neighbor onto a porch. Though Charlie Gibbons has heart trouble, he climbed a tree, inching higher as the water rose. ``When you're scared, you've got strength, believe me,'' he says, puffing on a cigarette. ``If his heart didn't get him, and the water didn't get him,'' says his wife, Fran, ``he says he's going to live forever.''

For rescuers, it was a week of facing death and destruction, eyeball-to-eyeball. ``You take a house, throw it in a big blender, with all its contents _ including human _ mix it up, spit it out, that's what it is,'' says Pat Swallie, a rescuer and public safety coordinator. ``We're seeing autos bent around trees bumper to bumper,'' he says. ``The dump trucks were like Tonka toys. The stench of decay, the smell of stagnant water, diesel fuel, raw sewage, dead animals.'' Though final damage estimates haven't been made, more than 850 houses in a three-county area of southeast Ohio were destroyed or damaged. More than than 500 National Guard troops, dozens of dog teams, mounted police, local fire and police and mine rescuers have worked with bulldozers, shovels and their hands, digging, probing and hoping for a miracle. One body was discovered 25 miles downstream in a logjam of debris near the Hannibal Dam. There have been other heartbreaking moments. One rescuer found his sister's body in the debris. He continued digging. Another discovered a woman clutching a pocketbook. Its only contents were tissues and a notepad from the funeral home where she eventually was taken.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: SHADYSIDE, OHIO: was taken.
DOC.TEXT: ``You never get used to it,'' Swallie says. The rescuers share their experiences. ``You don't hold it in. If you do, you're in trouble.'' But they forge on, if for no other reason than to end the uncertainty. ``People need to know, they need to bury their dead,'' Mrs. Ponzo says. ``They need to know there is a final resting place for them.'' ``We're pulling together, but it's hard,'' says firefighter Palmer, who aided in the search effort. ``We're doing the best we can. It's all so sad.''

Amid all the devastation, there are signs of renewal in Shadyside. ``I know we will never be the same again as a town,'' says Bobbi Brown, a schoolteacher. ``(But) you go on. You appreciate life more.'' Scores have lined up for applications for federal disaster aid, including Ken Gibbons, who estimates his losses at $300,000. ``Twenty years of work, 20 minutes it's all gone,'' he says, shaking his head. He's uncertain whether he'll rebuild his business. Fran and Charlie Gibbons will find another place to live. ``There ain't nothing here anymore,'' he says, staring at the rubble-strewn field where his trailer once stood. ``It's not even like home after 30-something years.'' His wife has nightmares of her home being encased in mud. ``It's like something you love, and now you're afraid of it,'' she says. But others are determined to stay. Even in its wretched condition, Shadyside is their home. Martha Wright Foster says her father's home is salvageable. ``He lived through the '36 flood, the Depression and World War II. ... He wanted this piece of property ever since he was a little boy. He wants back in.'' ``If you didn't have hope for starting over,'' says Mrs. Ponzo, ``there wouldn't be much sense in getting up.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Cohen is the AP's Midwest regional reporter, based in Chicago.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sun, June 24

DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy grew at its second slowest pace in 3{ years from January through March, the government reported. Analysts said they expect only modest improvement for the rest of the year. But the economists said any future growth would be fueled larely by exports because of a fall off in consumer spending, which had been a driving force for much of the economic expansion. The Commerce Department said Thursday the gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ grew at a revised 1.9 percent annual rate in the first quarter.

The first stock exchange in post-Communist Eastern Europe opened in Budapest, 42 years after it was closed by Communist authorities. Officials said Thursday they hope the fledgling Budapest trading floor will boost market-oriented economic reforms and become the stock exchange center for all of Eastern Europe.

Serious economic problems from tightened lending standards may yet emerge but borrowers have not suffered so far from a broad-based credit crunch, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said. ``To date, we have found that lenders have tightened their standards in certain sectors and locales, but that there has not, so far at least, been a broad-based squeeze on credit,'' Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday. ``Nonetheless, significant problems cannot be ruled out in the period ahead,'' he said. ``...We are attentive to the possibility that this more cautious stance in the granting of credit could cumulate to threaten the economic expansion.''

Donald Trump would need a short-term loan to avoid default on millions of dollars in bond payments if banks agree to forward the cash-needy developer $65 million, said an individual involved in the talks. The source, speaking Thursday on condition of anonymity, said that even if banks agree to lend Trump money there probably isn't enough time to finalize an agreement before a midnight Tuesday deadline. Trump missed a payment last Friday of about $43 million in interest and principal on two bond issues used to finance the Trump Castle hotel and casino in Atlantic City, N.J.

The Supreme Court has generally barred states and energy consumers from bringing federal antitrust suits against energy producers accused of conspiring to fix prices. In a separate decision Thursday, the Court stripped the Interstate Commerce Commission of its authority to relieve shippers of their legal obligation to pay carriers less than their official rates. In the price fixing case, the justices said in a 5-4 ruling that only direct purchasers of energy _ in this case utility companies _ may file such suits.

Japan will keep its ban on rice imports, despite signs that some Japanese would welcome them, because the nation's rice farmers need special protection, the agriculture minister said. ``We have opened the agricultural market, but there is a line beyond which we cannot pass,'' Tomio Yamamoto, minister of agriculture, fisheries and forestry, said Thursday. ``Agriculture is the foundation of our nation. ... In other countries, rice doesn't account for over half of all production the way it does here. That is a special circumstance for Japan,'' Yamamoto said.

East German lawmakers overwhelmingly approved economic merger with West Germany, ending four decades of failed socialism and taking their biggest and most difficult step toward unification. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl asked West Germany's Parliament on Thursday to also pass the historic economic treaty and promise that Poland's western borders were secure. Earlier in the day, East Germany declared a united Germany would not seek to reclaim former lands lost to Poland after World War II.

A federal bankruptcy judge approved Ames Department Stores Inc.'s plan to close more than 200 stores and authorized the discounter to pay $24 million to the 18,000 workers who will lose their jobs. Judge Howard C. Buschman III said Thursday he was ``very sad to be part of a case where so many people are affected,'' but he added, ``I believe it is a fair settlement and I will approve it.''

Perrier is back. But whether the French water will recapture its once-sparkling position in the U.S. bottled water market isn't clear. Hotels and restaurants, the staple of Perrier's sales, stopped carrying the water when benzene contamination forced the company to recall it worldwide on Feb. 9. Some distributors and industry officials say Perrier has received a tepid reception from hotels and restaurants since it was reintroduced in the United States in late April.

A brief round of buying near the close helped the stock market post a small gain Thursday in another quiet session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished 6.43 points higher at 2,901.73. The dollar was mixed, gaining against the yen but falling against the West German mark. Gold advanced. Bonds rose as buying interest picked up after a four-day slump. Cocoa futures prices fell sharply amid signs of improved supply prospects. Grain and soybean futures were mixed; livestock and meat prices were mostly lower; precious metals declined slightly; and energy futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Industry Optimistic About Stock Index Futures Bill
DOC.TEXT: A securities industry group pushing for passage of legislation to let the Securities and Exchange Commission regulate stock index futures says it is growing more optimistic each day there is no vote. ``I think right now it's a toss-up. A week ago I'd say we were a decided underdog,'' said Joseph R. Hardiman, president and chief executive of the National Association of Securities Dealers. ``Give us more time and I think we'll prevail.'' The NASD, which oversees the over-the-counter market, is part of the ad hoc Coalition for Intermarket Coordination that's been meeting with senators this week to push for passage of the amendement. Other members include: the American Stock Exchange, the Boston Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board of Options Exchange, the Pacific Stock Exchange and the National Securities Clearing Corp. Last month the Treasury Department unveiled legislation that would strip the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of authority over stock index futures and give it to the rival SEC. The administration and the SEC said the measure is necessary to prevent sharp rises and drops in market prices. The futures industry and the CFTC strongly oppose the bill. The proposal also would give the SEC authority to oversee stock index futures margins, the downpayment required of investors who buy the contracts on credit. The futures exchanges currently set those margins, which are generally much lower than those of securities. The SEC and Treasury have said low margins on stock index futures were partly to blame for the 1987 stock market crash and the 190-point drop last October. Stock index futures allow investors to speculate on movements in the stock market without buying the underlying stocks. The administration proposal was introduced as a separate bill in the House but will be included in CFTC market reform legislation that has been pending since last fall. ``Our position is getting stronger with every day,'' Hardiman added. ``If you'd asked us a week ago we would have said `Heavens don't let them take a vote now!' Today we're saying things are looking a lot better because we've had an opportunity to tell our story and the more people we tell it to the more ears we get that are willing to listen.'' In a joint interview with Philadelphia Stock Exchange President Nicholas A. Giordano and Options Clearing Corp. Chairman Wayne Luthringshausen, Hardiman said members of the group had spoken with 25 to 30 senators. ``I think there's a lot of undecided votes,'' said Luthringshausen, the coalition's chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Store Closures, Benefits for Thousands of Laid Off Workers
DOC.TEXT: The 18,000 workers who will lose their jobs when Ames Department Stores Inc. closes more than 200 stores this summer will receive vacation and severance pay under a plan approved in federal bankruptcy court. Judge Howard C. Buschman III authorized both the closures and the pay plan during a hearing Thursday. The pay plan, which will cost Ames $25 million, also includes checks for 6,600 workers laid off when Ames closed some stores just before its April 25 Chapter 11 filing. ``The employees have a stake in this company as well as everybody else,'' Buschman said. ``I don't think anyone in this room is comfortable with the notion that there are 18,000 people that are about to be terminated.'' The judge approved the company's plan to pay vacation and severance benefits over the objection of a committee of the company's creditors. ``The company's position is that ... we're trying to save the jobs of 32,000 people,'' spokesman Harris Diamond said, referring to the employees Ames expects to retain. ``The judge basically authorized them to go ahead.'' The judge also approved the closure of 219 of Ames' 679 stores in the eastern United States and two distribution centers. He delayed action until mid-July on a request to close two other stores after Albert Togut, an attorney for employees, claimed the stores weren't unprofitable, as Ames had said. The Rocky Hill, Conn.-based company filed for bankruptcy largely because of problems that stemmed from its $788 million acquisition of the Zayre chain in 1988. That purchase transformed Ames from a Northeast retailer into the country's fourth-largest discounter. Most of the stores slated for closure are former Zayre stores. The hearing was delayed for much of the day by the creation of a committee of eight former and current Ames workers to represent employees. The creditor's committee had requested that laid off employees be paid only a portion of the vacation and severance pay due them. Buschman, citing sympathy for the thousands of affected workers, called for an employees' committee to participate in negotiating an agreement. An analyst at a New York investment firm that specializes in bankruptcies said bringing employees into the negotiations could set a precedent. Although it remains to be seen how much power the employees' committee will have, ``it would change the face of bankruptcy if you have to take them into account,'' said Steve Lampe of R.D. Smith. The agreement calls for Ames to pay $7.8 million in vacation pay to the 18,000 workers, and $16.5 million in severance pay. It also calls for Ames to pay $850,000 in vacation pay to the 6,600 employees laid off just before the bankruptcy filing. The company employed about 55,000 people before the filing. Another part of the plan requires Ames to assign advisors to each targeted store to help employees search for jobs and write resumes. ``I recognize the tragedy,'' the judge said. ``I have been urging this debtor to give you people a good shot at getting jobs.'' The judge also approved Ames' plan to conduct ``going out of business'' sales at the stores, which are scheduled to close by the end of the summer. The sales will be managed by Jubilee Co. of Columbus, Ohio, and two other liquidation firms, said George Granoff, president and chief operating officer of Ames. Diamond said Ames expects to receive $144 million from the sales. On Tuesday, Ames reported first-quarter losses of $430.9 million, mostly because of the costs of closing stores. The loss gave the discount retailer a negative stockholder's equity, or net worth, of minus $74 million. The stores to be closed are in Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Virginia and West Virginia. The distribution centers to be closed are in Plant City, Fla., and Worcester, Mass. On Wednesday, Ames filed documents with Buschman seeking permission to reject employment contracts it had signed with four former top executives. The company said it cannot afford to continue paying the approximately $1.4 million a yar in salaries it owes to the four. Buschman has scheduled a hearing on the matter July 17.

DOC.HEAD: Source: Short-Term Loan Might Be Needed To Cover Trump Bond Payment
DOC.TEXT: Bankers working to cement a $65 million loan to keep Donald Trump from defaulting on millions in junk bond payments aren't likely to finish the paperwork in time, an individual involved in the talks said. As a result, the cash-squeezed developer is likely to need a separate short-term loan to make a $43 million bond payment by a midnight Tuesday deadline, said the source, who spoke Thursday on condition of anonymity. Even if the bank's complex plan to restructure Trump's debt is approved by lenders, there isn't enough time to finalize any agreement before the deadline, the source said. Last Friday, Trump missed the $43 million payment of interest and principal on two bond issues used to finance the Trump Castle hotel and casino in Atlantic City, N.J. Under the terms of the bond covenants, Trump has a 10-day grace period to make the payment before he can be declared in default. Defaulting on a total of $352 million in bonds could threaten Trump's licenses from the New Jersey Casino Control Commission and lead to his losing control of the Trump Castle. A default also could trigger other defaults in the developer's casino and real estate empire and force Trump to seek protection in bankruptcy court. A plan to lend Trump another $65 million and defer interest and principal payments has been held up by three Japanese banks and a West German bank. The four banks each hold $15 million worth of an outstanding $75 million loan made to Trump by Chase Manhattan Bank, said the source. The banks _ Sumitomo Bank, Mitsubishi Bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and Dresdner Bank _ have balked at a plan to put a second lien on the Trump Tower, the residential and commercial skyscraper on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, The New York Times reported Thursday. The banks' loans are protected by the current lien on the building, the newspaper said. The Times also reported that there was trouble in negotiations over whether cash flow from Trump's properties would be directed to the new loans. Trump's ability to move money from his cash-rich properties, such as the Trump Plaza casino, have helped him stay afloat, analysts have said. The bond agreement on the Plaza allows Trump to take all but $8 million annually from the available cash flow. He then can use the money to subsidize properties that drain cash, such as 100 acres of abandoned railroad yards on Manhattan's Upper West Side. Thus far, Trump has taken $50 million out of the Plaza in the form of dividends, said Larry Klatzkin, a bond analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The downturn in the New York real estate market and the struggling Atlantic City casino industry have cut into the amount of cash Trump has to spread around his empire. Assuming the Plaza continues generating cash, Trump would be able to draw on even more beginning next year. The agreements with bondholders, reached when the bonds were issued in 1986, will no longer require him to leave behind $8 million a year. Additionally, he would be able to draw upon the money he has been forced to leave in the casino. Late Thursday, Trump announced he sold a Dutch shipyard near Amsterdam for an undisclosed price. Trump bought the Amels shipyard a little over a year ago for $5 million to ensure completion of work on a 420-foot yacht, New York Newsday reported last month. Trump said through a spokesman, Howard Rubenstein, that he made a substantial profit on the sale.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Trends Show Japan's Markets Open, Ministry Says
DOC.TEXT: Japan's stubbornly high trade surplus with the United States is the result of ``natural'' factors, not closed markets, the trade ministry said in its annual report today. The ministry said Japan benefits by emphasizing exports of high value manufactured goods while the United States relies more on the sale of minerals and agricultural commodities. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry's 1989 white paper on trade and the economy also said statistics show Japan's mammoth overall trade surplus will continue to fall, despite the yen's relative weakness against other currencies. The report was released as Japan and the United States were preparing to meet June 25 for a final round of trade talks on economic reforms aimed at changing business practices and policies that inhibit trade and investment. It said difficulties in slashing Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States could be ``explained naturally.'' A gradual recovery in U.S. export competitiveness boosted U.S. exports to Japan 65.9 percent between 1986 and 1989, while U.S. exports to the European Community rose 62.9 percent, it said. But while the United States posted a $1.5 billion trade surplus with the EC last year _ a significant improvement over its $20.6 billion deficit in 1987, it ran a $49 billion deficit with Japan. That was a slight improvement from a record $56.3 billion gap in 1987, but still huge compared to 1980's $9.9 billion deficit, according to the U.S. Commerce Department. The report attributed the slower recovery in the U.S. trade balance with Japan to the composition of goods traded. Higher value manufactured goods account for 80.6 percent of U.S. exports to Europe, but only 58 percent of U.S. exports to Japan, it said. Other exports to Japan included grain, meat, lumber, iron ore and coal. The report said 78.1 percent of Japan's exports to the United States were machinery and transport goods for ``sustaining and expanding U.S. domestic industrial activity.'' In contrast, European exports included more primary products, it said. Japan's exports are increasingly high-tech products that are ``essential to the production and other economic activities of companies in the countries that are importing them,'' the report said. It said there were signs of a ``stable trend'' toward continued growth in imports and reduced reliance by Japanese companies on exports, despite the yen's relative weakness against other major currencies. The ministry said the yen's average value fell to 138 to the dollar in 1989 from 128.2 in 1988. In 1985, when the major industrial nations agreed to strengthen the yen to help correct trade imbalances, the dollar bought 238.5 yen. Economists have said a weaker yen, which makes Japanese products cheaper on world markets, could abort efforts to curb the trade imbalance. Indeed, the Japanese government earlier this week said the country's economy grew strongly in the three months ended in March because of a fresh surge in exports. The trade ministry said Japan's total trade surplus in 1989 was $76.92 billion, down from $95.02 billion in 1988. Imports grew 12.5 percent to $210.8 billion last year. For the first time ever, more than half of those imports _ 50.3 percent _ were manufactured goods, the report said. In 1985, only 31 percent of Japan's imports were manufactured goods. ``We consider the fact that imports rose, despite the weak yen, to signify that import expansion is here to stay,'' said Kazukiyo Higuchi, director of MITI's International Trade Research Office. But the ministry's figures also show that exchange rates and other factors brought the rate of increase in the value of imports down from 18.3 percent in 1987 and 25.3 percent in 1988. Growth in the volume of imports also slowed _ to 7.8 percent last year from 16.7 percent in 1988 and over 9 percent in 1987 and 1988. The report said Japan's exports climbed only 3.9 percent in 1989 to $275.2 billion, down from a 15.6 percent increase in 1988. Exports were down 2.2 percent to $66.7 billion in the first three months of this year. Manufacturers in many sectors have begun to wean themselves from strong dependence on exports, the report said. Automakers rely on exports for 34.6 percent of their sales, down from 46.4 percent in 1985, it said. Japanese industry as a whole gets only 20.2 percent of sales from exports, compared with 25.5 percent in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Treaty on German Unification
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of the treaty that prepares the economic merger of the two Germanys by July 2.

OVERVIEW _ The two Germanys agree to create a monetary, economic and social union as a first step to unification under the West German Constitution. The international implications of German unification need to be resolved in talks among the four victorious World War II powers _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Great Britain and France.

MONETARY UNION _ On July 2, the West German mark becomes the legal tender in East Germany. The West German Bundesbank, or central bank, will have full control over monetary policy in both countries. The economic union will be based on a free-market economy, including private property, competition and workers' rights.

CONVERSION RATES _ Workers will have their wages converted from East German marks to West German marks at a 1-1 rate. For savings deposits, East Germans 14 and younger will be able to convert up to $1,200 at a 1-1 rate. Those aged 15-59 will be able to convert $2,400 at the 1-1 rate. People 60 and older can covert up $3,600 at the favorable rate. All other savings will be converted at two East German marks for one West mark. East German pensions will be brought to West German levels, raising most of them. Debts will be converted at a 2-1 rate, more favorable to troubled East German companies.

DOC.HEAD: After Nearly Six Months, Mixed Success For Shock Economic Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The streets of Warsaw show an economic revolution in progress six months after the government jolted the country with market-oriented reform, but the faces of the people show the human cost. Poland's plunge into capitalism Jan. 1 was far bolder than any program undertaken by neighboring countries also shedding their communist past. Some people are obviously thriving. New Mercedes and Volvos with Polish license plates are a common sight on Warsaw streets. A few luxury boutiques sell dresses and suits for more than the average month's salary, and do not lack for customers. There has been a general enlivening of commerce. But there also is the pathetic sight of old people counting out a few zlotys to buy one or two rolls, and the banners announcing the sale of gas guns to counter the crime wave that police experts blame on the hard times. According to government statistics, the country has entered a deep recession. Poland's rocky experience during the first six months of switching to a market economy is giving pause to its giant neighbor to the east. Soviet officials so far have rejected radical economic reform along Polish lines, apparently admitting they do not have the political credibility to survive such a rapid transition. Instead, Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov proposed in late May a ``regulated market economy'' that called for bread prices to triple July 1 and other prices to double Jan. 1. Panic buying and popular discontent forced postponement of the bread price increases. Such half-measures typified Poland during the 1980s until Solidarity came to power and its economists declared it was impossible to leap a wide chasm in short steps. Bolstered by strong popular support, the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki instituted a plan that instantly liberated most prices after decades of control but kept wages tied down. State subsidies for enterprises were ended. The easy flow of bank credits were staunched by high interest rates. The deficit-ridden state budget was balanced. The Polish zloty was made fully convertible inside Poland, backed by a $1 billion reserve fund lent by Western nations. That eliminated the confusing array of legal, semi-legal and illegal exchange rates. After nearly six months, the plan's architect, Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, can claim a certain success, said Polish economics journalist Krzystof Bien in an interview. ``What he has managed to do so far has never been accomplished before,'' he said. ``However it is not yet the stage that would permit us to say that we are irrevocably on the road to a market economy. Everything we have achieved so far could be destroyed in a day,'' Bien said. The chief potential danger, he said, is a resurgence of inflation if the government relaxes its strict pay policies in response to recent industrial strikes and protests by small private farmers. Taming runaway inflation, estimated at more than 1,000 percent in 1989, has been the greatest achievement of the program so far. Prices spiked up when the plan was launched, but the tight controls on wages and lending soon brought them down. Statistics tell the story. Prices grew 79 percent in January, 24 percent in February, 4.7 percent in March, 8.1 percent in April and 5 percent in May. Freeing prices while holding down wages had an immediate effect on supplies in stores. Suddenly, the chronic shortages evaporated because of the drop in demand caused by the high pricetags. Then as supplies become more reliable, consumers stopped hoarding, further helping keep the shelves stocked. For consumers with money, Poland has become _ if not yet a shopper's paradise _ at least a country where one can find most of life's essentials and a few luxuries without irritating lines or complicated barters, bribes and deals. Sellers are chasing buyers, and not the other way around as before. Former luxuries such as bananas and lemons are now sold on the street, and food stands that have sprung up serve customers at night, on weekends and on holidays. Warsaw even has a 24-hour French grocery. On the down side, unemployment is about 400,000 people, or about 3 percent of the work force. Joblessness, officially non-existent a year ago, is expected to grow to 9 percent, or 1.3 million people, this year. Faced with high interest rates and reduced demand, many factories slowed production to a trickle. Output by government industry is down about 30 percent. The dire picture is probably offset somewhat by increased production in the private sector where government statistics are less reliable. With wages tied down by punitive taxes and prices steadily rising, especially in January and February, real incomes dropped dramatically _ down about 40 percent, according to official statistics. But again, the numbers do not fully reflect the burgeoning private business activity. ``I am an optimist,'' said Slawomir Rudnicki, the proud co-owner of the new French grocery. ``It would have been impossible to open this shop a few years ago.'' But in the next breath he goes on to present a long list of complaints against petty officials and regulations that still hinder business _ like the rule that the bottled mineral water he imports be submitted to a health check each time his truck crosses the Polish border.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe, MGM-UA Announce New Terms to Proposed Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. got four more months to try to acquire MGM-UA Communications Co. with a new deal that raises the purchase price by $100 million, the companies said. The new arrangement was announced Thursday amid questions over whether Pathe's top financial backer, Time Warner Inc., would bow out of the deal due to concerns Pathe was borrowing too much money. Under the new $1.3 billion acquisition plan, holders of common and preferred MGM-UA stock will receive $21.50 per share, up from the original buyout price of $20 a share, Pathe and MGM-UA said. But stockholders now will receive payments of $4 a share on July 20, with the balance of $17.50 expected to be paid on or before Oct. 23 of this year. The deadline for the former deal was to have been Saturday. Pathe, headed by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti, has extended its offer several times past its original closing date of April 30. Part of the $4 payment will come out of an escrow account into which Pathe already has deposited $200 million. The additional $53 million necessary to make the $4 payment to stockholders of record on July 10 is to be deposited by Pathe on July 16. Pathe intends to merge a newly formed subsidiary with MGM-UA, and MGM-UA will seek shareholder approval for the merger. Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda Corp. said it has agreed to vote for the merger. Pathe is obligated to consummate a tender offer if the merger is not concluded for any reason. In support of the acquisition, Pathe will deliver to escrow an additional $100 million, consisting of two installments of $50 million each to be paid on Aug. 21 and Sept. 20 of this year. Pathe's problems are with its chief backer, Time Warner Inc., which has agreed to loan Pathe $650 million. Time Warner would get a lien on the United Artists movie library, distribution rights to that library, and distribution rights to future Pathe and MGM-UA releases as part of the deal. According to a published report Thursday, Time Warner was contemplating pulling out of the deal. Daily Variety, citing anonymous sources, said Time Warner was considering the move because Pathe was relying on debt and not equity to finance its purchase of MGM-UA. Time Warner has insisted the $600 million remaining to close the deal must not come from borrowed funds and that Pathe put up $450 million of that equity itself. But Pathe said in a statement Thursday negotiations with Time Warner were continuing. A Time Warner spokeswoman agreed. ``We assume that the purpose of Pathe's obtaining the extension is to continue our discussions as to how Pathe can satisfy the conditions of our agreement, and we are continuing the discussions,'' said spokeswoman Marilyn Harris. She would not comment on the Daily Variety report. MGM-UA has been virtually dormant in movie production during the past two years, since Kerkorian put the company on the auction block. So far, Pathe head Parretti's proposed patchwork of loans through European affiliates of Pathe has failed to meet Time Warner's criteria.

DOC.HEAD: New Chairman Appointed
DOC.TEXT: Circle K Corp. has appointed a Cincinnati lawyer who is a partner with the law firm representing the company's largest shareholder as its new chairman. Phoenix-based Circle K, the nation's second largest convenience-store chain, on Thursday named Bart A. Brown Jr., a senior partner in the law firm of Keating, Muething & Klekamp, to replace Karl Eller. Keating, Muething & Klekamp represents American Financial Corp., Circle K's largest shareholder. Eller resigned as chairman and chief executive officer on May 7. Brown will be chairman. The post of chief executive remains vacant, the company said. Brown, 58, was picked for the job because of his expertise in acquisitions, dispositions and debt restructuring, a spokesman for Circle K said. Circle K is in deep financial difficulty, having filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors May 15 in U.S. Bankruptcy Court here, listing more than $1 billion in debt. Kevin Irwin, a colleague of Brown and the head of the bankruptcy department in their law firm, said Brown's strong business-law background makes him ideal for the post. ``He's one of the leading business (law) practitioners in Cincinnati,'' Irwin said. ``He has a very strong tax background and has had a great deal of exposure to bankruptcy. In terms of financial acumen, he's one of the more respected lawyers in town.'' Brown, who has practiced law for 35 years, has law degrees from the University of Louisville and Georgetown University. He ran his own Cincinnati law firm, Brown & Gardner Co., for 10 years, but merged with Keating, Muething & Klekamp in 1987, said Circle K spokesman Ray Cox. Circle K operates about 4,600 stores in 32 states.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Chief Warns Overproduction Will Bring Oil Price Collapse
DOC.TEXT: OPEC President Sadek Boussena Friday reiterated a warning to the oil cartel's members that they face an imminent collapse in sagging prices if they continue producing excessively. ``The situation is very serious and I'd say it's alarming if something is not done immediately to stop the slide in prices,'' he told a news conference. Boussena, Algeria's Mines Minister, arrived in Baghdad Thursday on the first stop of a tour of Middle East oil producers seeking to secure adherence to a May 2 Geneva agreement to limit production to 22.1-22.6 million barrels to day and shore up sinking oil prices. He had warned the 13-member Organization of Oil Exporting Countries earlier this month that if they did not stick to the agreement, prices will drop through the floor as they did in 1986. The Nicosia-based Middle East Economic Survey, a respected weekly oil review, estimated current OPEC production at 23.68 million barrels a day. Oil prices have recently slumped to $15 a barrel from OPEC's benchmark of $18. Boussena said the objective of his tour is to study ways of propping up prices. He declined to indentify the OPEC members who are producing more than their quotas. But the main violators are believed to be Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Iraq's Oil Minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim Al-Chalabi, did not hesitate to name the U.A.E. as one of the principal over-producers. ``Great harm is being done because the U.A.E. is not part of the agreement,'' Chalabi told the news conference. ``There's no justification whatever for giving away one barrel free for every three barrels we sell. It's simply unjustifiable and illogical,'' he said. Boussena said: ``We're all suffering great losses. But some of us are feeling the burden more than others because of their requirements and their economic and social problems.'' Boussena ruled out convening an emergency meeting of OPEC oil ministers to consider the crisis. But he said the next scheduled meeting on July 26 will do so. He said he saw no reason why some members were not abiding by the agreement. ``I'm not convinced by the reasons they give for their undisciplined behavior. It's simply illogical that they are overproduciung to sell their oil at cheaper prices while they could keep it and sell it at higher prices when the market situation improves,'' he said.. ``If the organization wants stable prices, then it should have a solid and durable agreement on production and prices,'' he added. But he sounded pessimistic on the prospect of general acceptance of an agreement. ``We only have the solidarity among us to respect our obligations and to abide by the agreements,'' he added. Boussena is scheduled to visit Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states in the next few days.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Modestly Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were modestly higher at midday Friday, boosted by reassuring British trade figures. Dealers said the trade figures, released late in the morning, were greeted with a sigh of relief. The figures were largely in line with expectations. But since Friday is the last day of a two week trading account and close to the half-year mark, the data failed to stir many investors from the sidelines, they added. London's Stock Exchange divides trading into two-week and three-week trading periods for accounting purposes. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 6.8 points, or 0.3 percent, at 2,377.1 at about noon (1100 GMT). Volume came to 312.5 million shares at midday, compared with 257 million shares at the same time Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Action Could Mean Lower Long-Distance Rates
DOC.TEXT: A Federal Communications Commission order that local phone companies reduce their access charges by $1.1 billion nationwide is expected to result in a further reduction in long-distance rates. The FCC on Thursday ordered the cut in rates charged to long-distance companies for access to local phone networks, effective July 1. Long-distance carriers typically pass along to their customers savings from such cuts. American Telephone & Telegraph Co., the nation's largest long-distance company, announced last month it would cut its rates by $160 million annually, effective July 1, in anticipation of the FCC decision. This would mean a cut of 2.5 percent in typical evening rates. Other phone companies such as MCI Communications Corp. and US Sprint usually follow suit to remain competitive. AT&T has decided on deeper rate reductions, however, since it had based its cuts on local phone company proposals to the FCC. The local companies in April had asked to reduce their access charges by just $405 million on July 1. The FCC ordered an additional $696 million cut Thursday, saying the local phone companies had underestimated likely calling demand by about 2.4 percent, or 7 billion minutes. The FCC also based its rate reductions, in part, on corrections of the local phone companies' cost estimates. ``There will be some further reduction beyond the $160 million AT&T proposed May 17,'' AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said. ``I don't know how much. ... But's it's good news for residential and small business customers.'' He said AT&T probably would announce additional cuts next week. ``We expect AT&T to file reductions in its rates to reflect these further reductions,'' said Kelly Cameron, an official in the FCC's common carrier division. Cameron said the long-distance price cuts would not necessarily be a direct flow-through of access charge savings. Before July 1989, when AT&T's earnings were restricted to about a 12 percent rate of return on its investment, the flow-through of costs generally were nearly automatic. But AT&T now is under a regulatory scheme that controls its prices within a prescribed range tied to the rate of inflation, not its profits. AT&T's May proposal for 2.5 percent evening reductions would reduce the price of a 10-minute direct-dialed call to anywhere in the United States to $1.53 or less from $1.58, Sunday through Friday, 5 p.m. to 11 p.m. AT&T's prices have dropped more than 40 percent since 1984. Separately Thursday, AT&T began offering corporate phone rates that match those of its competitors while undercutting rates AT&T is allowed to charge under its government-approved tariffs. A five-month waiting period for the plan under FCC rules expired at midnight Wednesday, said AT&T spokesman Andy Myers. Under the plan, AT&T must seek government approval each time it signs a contract to offer phone rates to a specific customer that match those offered to the customer by competitors, and are lower than AT&T is allowed to offer under its tariffs, Myers said. In addition, the FCC has an additional 12 to 15 months to continue its investigation into the so-called Tariff 15 plan, and could decide to disallow the plan during that period, said John Cimko, chief of the FCC's tariff division. So far, AT&T has filed seven requests, involving customers such as CBS Inc. and Pepsico, to offer competitive rates under Tariff 15, Myers said. The rate plan that went into effect Thursday is for Resort Condominiums International Inc. of Indianapolis. Cimko said the plan, in effect, was a test case for Tariff 15. Under FCC rules, AT&T must gain the commission's approval for all rate changes, while competitors may change rates at will. However, the FCC has said it will examine whether it should relax that requirement.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Extinguish Siberian Oil Tank Fire
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters have extinguished a fire at a Siberian oil tank farm that was ignited by a direct lightning strike and spread to 22 acres, the evening newspaper Izvestia said Friday. The newspaper said it took firemen a full day to put out the blaze that engulfed at least four of the oil station's 24 tanks at the Karkateyevy station, near Nefteyugansk in the Tyumen oil region of Western Siberia. The Tass news agency said on Thursday that the reservoirs at the station contain a total of 380,000 tons of oil. It said 160 firemen used 28 pieces of equipment to douse the blaze. No one was injured in the blaze and evacuation of the area was not necessary, Izvestia said. According to the regional executive committee, negligence was partly to blame for the blaze, which broke out Wednesday night. ``Lightning rods were not working, and there was no special foam to extinguish the blaze,'' it said. ``Also, taps on the pipes were not working and oil was going through them while they were burning.'' The newspaper did not give any estimate of damage or oil loss from the blaze.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan: Cutback in Bank Commercial Hasn't Hurt Economy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th pvs, Although fewer..., with Mosbacher statement. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A cutback in bank lending for commercial real estate construction and corporate mergers hasn't harmed the economy as a whole, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan says. ``With the exception, perhaps, of the troublesome situation in the New England region, credit availability more broadly appears not to be significantly impaired,'' Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday. ``Enough credit appears to be available to fuel'' economic growth nationally, he said. But he also warned, ``significant problems cannot be ruled out in the period ahead.'' ``We are attentive to the possibility that this more cautios stance in the granting of credit could cumulate to threaten the economic expansion,'' Greenspan said. Although fewer loans are being made to finance construction and mergers, the caution was justified by deteriorating conditions in those areas and was not a result of a crackdown by bank examiners, the central bank chief said. Greenspan was disputed by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher who issued a statement to the committee, saying, ``While real estate lending has been especially slow this year, other lending has also been reduced. ... Especially hard-hit have been small- and medium-sized businesses.'' He added: ``While the credit problem differs by region, it appears to be national in scope.'' Substantial credit is essential for U.S. firms to meet the challenge of foreign competition, he said. At the same time, a senior Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. official warned that commercial real estate difficulties were spreading beyond New England and the Southwest and were likely to get worse before they get better. ``We do expect some continuing slowing and softness in the real estate markets,'' said Paul G. Fritts, FDIC director of bank supervision. ``We don't think it's bottomed out in New England yet. We see some softness beginning to develop in California.'' Greenspan sought to reassure worried New England lawmakers, as well as senators from Pennsylvania, Maryland and Florida, who said business people in their areas are reporting great difficulty getting loans for what they consider credit-worthy projects. Some examiners and bankers may have turned overly cautious, Greenspan said, but ``whatever overreaction that may have occurred does not appear to have been widespread.'' ``Access to credit has not been reduced to an extent that it has had a dampening influence on the American economy overall,'' he said. However, Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy, D-Mass., who appeared before the Senate panel as a witness, said, ``Many bankers and people in the business community say that, while regulators may not have caused the economic downturn, they sure have greased the pole.'' Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass.,said residents of the Northeast are effectively paying for the savings and loan crisis twice. They are paying for 47 percent of the bailout, while only 10 percent of the costs are attributed to S&L failures in the region, he said. Now, regulators are being too tough on institutions in the Northeast for fear of repeating the mistakes they made in the Southwest, Kerry said. However, Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, senior Republican on the Banking Committee, warned against criticizing regulators too harshly, noting that they were pressured to ease up when economic trouble first hit savings and loans in the Southwest. ``Let's be careful. You don't have to have a long memory to remember that we went through this before,'' he said. ``... This senator, if he has to err, will err on the side of tougher regulation.''

DOC.HEAD: FTC Clears Way For Dayton Hudson-Marshall Field's Merger
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission has cleared the way for Dayton Hudson Corp. to acquire Marshall Field & Co. for about $1.05 billion, Dayton Hudson announced Friday. The proposed takeover was being examined under federal antitrust law, the Hart-Scott-Rodino Premerger Notification Act. The FTC did not issue an opinion on the merger, it merely said the waiting period was over, said Ann Barkelew, a spokeswoman for Dayton Hudson. The two retailers expected to complete the deal Friday, she said. The Marshall Field stores will become part of the department store division of Dayton Hudson. ``This was an opportunity to acquire a premier name in American retailing,'' said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive officer of Dayton Hudson. But he noted that the department store chains of Target and Mervyn's will ``continue to be our primary growth vehicles.'' Macke said announcements will be made early next week about operational and personnel changes at Chicago-based Marshall Field's. Gary Witkin, Marshall Field's former executive vice president of stores, has been named president of the Field's unit. Field Chairman Philip B. Miller and President Burnett W. Donoho announced their resignations the day after Dayton Hudson announced in late April that it would consolidate Field's administrative and buying operations in Minneapolis. Macke said the impact of the acquisition on Dayton Hudson's bottom line in 1990 ``is not expected to be material.'' Dayton Hudson's department store division's 1989 revenues were $1.8 billion and its operating profit totaled $179 million. Prior to the acquisition, the division had more than 22,000 employees and 37 stores. With the acquisition, the division will employ more than 31,000 people and operate 61 stores. Marshall Field's, sold by BAT Industries PLC as part of a restructuring, had revenue of approximately $1.1 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Supercomputers Heat up Pace in Bond Market
DOC.TEXT: The supercomputer is making a move on the credit markets. The profusion of ever more complex fixed-income instruments is forcing Wall Street investment banks to add high-powered silicon to their arsenals. The workstation has replaced the primitive yield calculator as the bond trader's standard tool. And increasingly, that workstation is backed up by the power of a supercomputer, or mini-super, with the number-crunching power to assess the impact of interest rate shifts on individual bonds or portfolios containing dozens of bonds. ``We're in a technical business, there's no doubt about it,'' says Tony Vignola, head of fixed-income research at Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``The capability of analyzing and processing information quickly is becoming an ever increasing means of staying competitive in the business.'' Technology's biggest inroads have been in the field of mortgage-backed securities, whose complex structures demand raw computing power. These securities represent packages of thousands of individual mortgages, some fixed-rate and some variable, with different pre-payment risks. What's more, the securities often are packaged further into structures like collateralized mortgage obligations, or CMOs, which group bonds in tiers of increasing risk and compound the complexity. ``Basically, all the value is in the details, and there are zillions of details,'' says Vincent Pica, co-head of institutional strategies at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Pru-Bache last year bought a low-end supercomputer from Intel Corp. and recently upgraded the machine using the company's latest high-speed computer chip. The iPSC@860, or hypercube as it's called, helps the investment bank to design new mortgage bond structures and to assess securities in the secondary market. The machine can evaluate how the bottom tier of a CMO will perform under scores of interest rate scenarios in about 90 seconds, compared with about 20 minutes for a desktop workstation, Pica says. Entire portfolio analyses that used to be done overnight now can be crunched out during the trading day. That speed means business, whether it's spotting a market opportunity for the firm or finding a trade for a client while the client waits on the phone. ``The race is to the swift,'' Pica says. Elliot Swan, manager of Intel's sales to the financial services industry, says the company has targeted its sales effort at up to 200 large investment banks, insurance companies and other institutional heavyweights. ``Everyone is overwhelmed with data,'' Swan says. ``Making sense of the data is really what this is all about.'' The state of the Street's technology can be hard to gauge, says Gary Smaby, who runs a research firm in Minneapolis that bears his name. The hardware itself, plus the applications software that allows bankers to manipulate bond data, is guarded jealously by firms seeking a competitive edge, he says. ``We don't want to discuss what we're doing for competitive reasons,'' says Peter Roche, a spokesman at Morgan Stanley & Co. The recent squeeze on Wall Street's earnings may be slowing the spread of high-priced supercomputers. Pru-Bache declined to say what it spent on its hypercube. Intel says the machine ranges from $250,000 to $3 million, with the most likely Wall Street model selling for around $1 million. Union Bank of Switzerland has invested about $450,000 in a low-powered hypercube at its New York securities operation in the past year, says Christian Gabathuler, the bank's U.S. head of information systems. The bank has used the machine only for research but hopes to put it to work in its credit market operations by the end of the year, he says. More common are so-called mini-supercomputers, says Smaby. They don't offer the computing speed of a true super, but they cost much less and can handle complex bond calculations many times faster than a workstation. Torque Computer Inc. sells a sort of turbocharged box for about $100,000 that can increase a workstation's computing speed as much as 50 times, says Sam Bogoch, the company's president. ``You literally turn hours into minutes,'' he says. That kind of power is fast becoming indispensable in Wall Street's race to design more exotic bonds and find extra basis points of yield. As Pica says of Pru-Bache's supercomputer, ``One year from now, we're all going to look back and say, `How did intelligent life exist without this thing.'''
