DOC.HEAD: Nissan Setting Up Dealers in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. on Friday began selling passenger and commercial vehicles in East Germany, the first Japanese automaker to do so through its own dealers, a company spokesman said. Kenkichi Shibata said the move followed sales and service contracts signed recently between Nissan Motor Deutschland GmbH, the company's wholly owned distributor in West Germany. Thirty-six Nissan dealerships officially opened Friday, and that number is expected to expand to 60 or 70 by year's end. Prior to the establishment of Nissan's East German dealer network, Japanese automakers have exported a small number of cars to the country. He said Nissan is targeting its sales of new cars in East Germany at 2,000 vehicles for the first year. The company currently sells about 100,000 cars and trucks through its 800-dealer network in West Germany. The company said the establishment of Nissan dealerships in East Germany was to accommodate the service needs of Nissan owners from the West. The number of visitors traveling to East Germany has been increasing since the removal of travel restrictions. Subsidiaries of Nissan Motor Deutschland, have set up offices in East Berlin to provide finance and leasing services. Six Nissan models to be sold in East Germany include Micra, Sunny and Bluebird passenger cars, Patrol, Vanette and Urvan commercial vehicles, he said. The Micra is a minicar not sold in the United States. The U.S. equivalent of the Sunny is the Sentra and the Bluebird is the Stanza. The Patrol, made in Spain, is similar to the Pathfinder sport-utility vehicle, the Vanette is a minivan and the Urvan is a commercial vehicle slightly larger than a Vanette.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Closing Most Stores
DOC.TEXT: Garfinckel's, one of the Washington area's oldest upscale retailers, will lay off a fourth of its employees, close seven department stores and open two smaller specialty stores for women. The retailer announced the changes Thursday after filing for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the District of Columbia. ``Garfinckel's existing business structure cannot produce either the merchandising mix or financial performance for the company to viably serve its customers or meet its debt obligations,'' George P. Kelly, chairman and chief executive officer of Garfinckel's said. ``Garfinckel's does not have the economies of scale, given its reduced revenue base and market share since 1987, to be a competitive retailer in this marketplace.'' The retailer is owned by an investment group headed by Middle Eastern investor Wafic Said. Said also owns a major stake in Washington Bancorporation, the parent company of the troubled National Bank of Washington. In recent years, Garfinckel's had been struggling to overcome changes in ownership, a heavy debt burden taken on to prevent a leveraged buyout and competition from other large stores such as Seattle-based Nordstrom Inc., that have come to the Washington area. A spokesperson for the company, who asked to remain anonymous, said 200 of the company's 850 employees will be laid off immediately. Garfinckel's nine stores, all located in the metropolitan Washington area, will remain open through an inventory liquidation process, the spokesperson said. The liquidation process, which will take about 60 days, will be directed by Schottenstein Stores Corp., officials said. The company will sell their leases on seven of the stores and will seek to reorganize and open two smaller specialty stores for women. Those stores will be located in prestigious Georgetown Park and Connecticut Avenue. A release issued by Kelly Thursday said the consumers' preference for specialty stores apparently led to the company's demise along with numerous changes in ownership. ``Changing ownership five times since the early 1980s subjected Garfinckel's to different marketing strategies so that its image among customers became significantly impaired,'' Kelly said. ``This was compounded by the deterioriating condition of the retailing industry generally following a number of recent bankruptcies.'' Garfinckel's Holding Co. is the parent company of Garfinckel's. The store currently has locations in Washington and suburban Maryland and Virginia. Garfinckel's once was a division of Allied Stores Corp. It was sold after the 1986 acquisition of Allied by Canada's Campeau Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Drier Weather Outlook Pressures Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower after a mixed opening today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting expectations for drier weather next week in the rain-weary Midwest. Abundant, and in some areas excessive, rain has delayed planting of soybeans and washed away some newly planted corn in the past week. But conditions are expected to turn drier next week and traders generally believe crop conditions overall are improving, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. But he said farmers have little time left to get soybeans into the ground without risking yield losses. ``This is it, this is the crunch time right now,'' Lespinasse said. ``It's now or never.'' In early trading, wheat futures prices were unchanged to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.38{ a bushel; corn futures were 1 cent lower to } cent higher with July at $2.84 a bushel; oats were { cent to 3\ cents lower with July at $1.37{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2\ cents lower with July at $6.01 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as slack demand for pork continued to exert pressure on prices. Live cattle futures were .07 cent to .58 cent lower with August at 73.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .37 cent lower with August at 85.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .13 cent higher with August at 57.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.9 cents to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents lower with July at 59.40 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: FBI Agent No Bumpkin
DOC.TEXT: An undercover FBI agent in a wide-ranging probe of corruption at the world's biggest commodities exchanges was ``no bumpkin,'' a federal prosecutor said today in concluding his case against three traders. Randall Jannett, who posed as a corrupt trader at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, was ``a special, special agent'' who accurately recalled how the three men _ all traders in the Swiss franc pit _ cheated their customers, Assistant U.S. Attorney James P. Fleissner told jurors at the U.S. District trial before Judge Ann C. Williams. ``Ladies and gentlemen, Randall Jannett was no bumpkin,'' Fleissner said. Defense attorneys for the defendants, Robert D. Mosky, Danny Scheck and David Zatz, argued throughout the six-week trial that Jannett was in over his head, incompetent at discerning what were and were not legitimate trades. Thursday, Mosky's attorney, Elliot Samuels, told the 12-member jury that his client was being unfairly blamed for ambiguous trading rules at the commodities exchanges. Federal prosecutors contend Mosky was the ringleader of a group of traders in the Merc's Swiss franc futures pit who routinely stole money from customers through various illegal trading schemes that prevented the customer orders from being executed in the open market. But Samuels, backed by testimony from a Merc official, contended a key trading rule that Mosky allegedly broke is subject to interpretation according to the customs and practices of the marketplace. ``Here's the (government's) game, folks: let's call the conduct fraudulent, and let's indict the guy,'' Samuels told the jury near the end of his two-hour closing argument. ``If they're not happy with the damn rules, let them go to Washington and get Congress to change it _ but don't Bob put Mosky in jail because of it,'' Samuels said. Congress already is addressing the vagueness of some commodity trading rules as part of a periodic examination of the industry that has taken on added weight after the Chicago corruption probe. Samuels referred specifically to the interpretation of ``open outcry'' trading, the accepted method of commodity futures trading in which traders crowd into recessed ``pits'' to buy and sell contracts for future deliveries of commodities through a combination of hand signals and shouted bids and offers. The federal charges are rooted in the premise that the defendants executed customer orders through pre-arranged or off-market trades instead of through open outcry, thus depriving the customers of the supposedly superior prices that result from competitive trading. The government contends the defendants used the profits from the illegal trades to cover their personal losses from trading errors. Samuels cited the testimony of Merc Executive Vice President Gerald Beyer, who indicated during cross-examination that the precise definition of a legitimate bid or offer _ whether a wordless hand gesture is sufficient, for example _ depends on the customs of each trading pit. Samuels said the government had not proved that Mosky had not executed customer orders through open outcry. Samuels suggested undercover FBI agent Randall Jannett merely missed Mosky's legal trades, then mistook the ensuing confirmation discussion between the traders as illegal, off-market trading. This is the first trial resulting from an unprecedented undercover FBI probe of corruption at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two biggest commodity exchanges. In all, 48 people were indicted and 16 already have pleaded guilty. Two other groups of traders face September trials. Mosky, Scheck and Zatz face more than a dozen counts each of mail or wire fraud and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. Each count carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $150,000 fine. Mosky also is charged with racketeering conspiracy, for which he could be sent to prison for 20 years and be forced to forfeit personal assets, including exchange membership.

DOC.HEAD: Top Sales Executive at Apple USA Leaves Post
DOC.TEXT: In the latest change among top executives at Apple Computer Inc., the company announced that William B. Coldrick, who had been senior vice president of sales for Apple USA, has left the post to become a part-time adviser to the president of the unit. Coldrick, 47, will work on strategic issues and special projects. He said Thursday he left his full-time post in order to spend more time with his family. Michael L. Dionne, 41, will succeed Coldrick in the top U.S. sales post. Dionne was vice president of Southwestern operations for Apple USA. A year ago, Apple gave Coldrick a compensation package worth $2.1 million a year to keep him at the company when he was considering going to a competitor, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday. Apple is still looking for a president for Apple USA, five months after Michael Spindler, Apple's chief operating officer, became acting president of the unit upon the resignation of former President Allan Z. Loren. Coldrick said Apple USA would have a new president soon. Also earlier this year, Apple's new-products developer, Jean-Louis Gassee, left the company.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks for More Money to Prosecute S&L Fraud
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs to include Democratic reaction, additional details of Bush proposal; picks up 5th pvs, bgng, Bush said... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, accused by members of Congress of being too sluggish on enforcement of savings and loan fraud, today asked lawmakers to double spending for the crackdown. ``We will not rest until the cheats and the chiselers and the charlatans spend a large chunk of their lives behind the bars of a federal prison,'' Bush said in a speech to U.S. attorneys at the Justice Department. The president also announced his support for an amendment to pending crime legislation that would devote more Internal Revenue Service and Justice Department investigators and prosecutors to financial fraud cases. Bush is asking Congress to increase next year's spending from the current $50 million to $100 million in the 1991 budget year. For 1990, the administration sought and received only $50 million, even though Congress had authorized $75 million. Bush also announced he was establishing a new position in the attorney general's office, a special counsel for financial institution fraud who will coordinate investigations and prosecutions in that area. On Capitol Hill, Democrats lashed out at the president's initiative as inadequate. ``It's too little and woefully late,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the House Banking Committee. He said $100 million may have been enough for 1990, but it is not enough for 1991. ``The administration is now moving only because the political heat is up,'' said Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. Bush said his administration is sending out ``teams of razor sharp prosecutors and auditors, recruited from their departments and other agencies, striking city by city, teams that will jump right into the paper chase, teams that will hit the trail while that trail is still hot.'' Bush was criticized by members of Congress this year for failing to take advantage of the full $75 million they authorized last August when they passed the savings and loan bailout package. Congress subsequently appropriated only the $50 million Bush had asked for. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said the administration could not use the full $75 million during the startup phase of the intensified S$L crackdown, but in the fiscal year 1991 wants to spend $100 million. In addition to beefing up the investigative and prosecutorial forces, the administration's legislative package would authorize wiretaps in bank fraud and financial fraud cases; freezing of personal and corporate assets of civil defendants in financial fraud cases and barring use of bankruptcy to avoid damages and penalties in these cases. Among those under investigation by thrift regulators is Bush's son, Neil Bush of Denver, a former director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan, one of the failed associations involved in the S&L probe. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater on Thursday defended the administration's anti-fraud efforts. Democratic critics have complained that the Justice Department has a backlog of nearly 7,000 cases. Fitzwater said last year there were 791 convictions for financial institution fraud involving losses of $100,000 each. Since 1987, he said, the government has issued 184 major S&L indictments with 159 convictions. The Justice Department has 530 failed institutions under investigation, up from 282 three years ago, Fitzwater said. With the $50 million already appropriated for this fiscal year, the Justice Department is hiring 368 new employees, including 202 FBI agents and 120 prosecutors. The department says it is creating special offices in 27 cities to go after financial institution fraud. Congressional critics pointed out, however, that U.S. attorneys' offices around the country asked for an additional 231 prosecutors and FBI field offices asked for more than 400 additional agents. Criticism on Capitol Hill has mounted with the administration's announcement a month ago that the S&L cleanup costs would be far greater than originally thought. The estimates now range from $89 billion to $132 billion, and officials have said the administration would need from $30 billion to more than $50 billion more in the next fiscal year alone. Fitzwater this week lashed out at Democrats who he said are trying to politicize the savings and loan issue. He said many Democratic lawmakers share the blame for the debacle, which mushroomed during the Reagan administration years. Bush said he approved of Fitzwater's statements.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Trading Assistant Gets 10 Months for Perjury
DOC.TEXT: Former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. trading assistant Lisa Jones was sentenced today to 10 months in prison for lying to the government during its investigation of the Wall Street firm. The punishment was eight months less than Jones received at her original sentencing last year. That term was thrown out by a federal appeals court that said the sentence was longer than prescribed by federal sentencing guidelines. U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand also ordered the one-time teen-age runaway who climbed to a $100,000-a-year job at Drexel to pay $25,000 in fines plus the cost of her incarceration. Jones, 27, was convicted by a federal jury in March 1989 of seven counts of perjury and obstruction of justice for lying to a federal grand jury investigating trading activities at Drexel. She was the first person convicted in the government's lengthy investigation of fraud on Wall Street. Prosecutors showed at her trial that Jones handled transactions that constituted illegal ``stock parking,'' which involves hiding the true ownership of securities. Jones had denied any knwowledge of such transactions. Jones worked at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., junk bond department as a trading assistant to Bruce Newberg, who was convicted last year of parking and other charges and sentenced to three months in prison. Newberg reported directly to Michael Milken, the ex-head of Drexel's junk bond department who pleaded guilty to six felonies earlier this year to settle wide-ranging securities fraud charges. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in March ruled that Sand wrongly gave Jones a sentence greater than the 10- to 16-month term recommended by new sentencing guidelines governing crimes that occurred after January 1987. Sand originally had added on to the term on grounds that Jones' perjury had severly impeded the government's Drexel investigation. Sand said today that Jones' perjury was ``not a sudden impulse. It was a persistent conduct of perjury on several occasions despite warnings'' from the government. Jones, who sobbed throughout the 90-minute sentencing, was ordered to continue to receive mental health therapy during her term. She is to report to a minimum-security prison camp in Phoenix in 30 days.

DOC.HEAD: GTE Northwest Telephone Employees in Three States Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with company confirming strike, adds background on company. No pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: More than 3,000 GTE Northwest telephone company workers in three states went on strike for higher wages today after talks on a new contract broke down, union and company officials said. Members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers walked off the job shortly after midnight in Washington, Oregon and northern California, said Douglas Weisner, business manager for Local 89. The bulk of the more than 3,100 affected GTE workers are in Washington and Oregon. They include telephone cable installers, splicers, operators and clerical workers. No new talks are scheduled, and pickets were up this morning at many GTE sites, said GTE spokeswoman Linda Gainer. Union and company negotiators met for several hours Thursday but failed to reach an agreement, Weisner said. Employees had been working under extended provisions of a contract that expired May 26. The union rejected a three-year offer earlier this week by 72 percent, Weisner said. Weisner said the company's latest offer included an 8 percent wage hike over three years, with a $270 ratification bonus for each employee. The union has been seeking an 11.5 percent wage increase over three years. Gainer said the company was disappointed at the strike and believes it made significant changes in the latest offer. In addition to the ratification bonus, she said, GTE agreed to some union demands on job and pay classifications. The phone company serves more than 672,000 customers in the three states. Most existing customers should only experience minor inconveniences, such as longer waits for operators, Gainer said. ``So much of our service is mechanized that the impact is not as intensive as it would have been in the old days,'' she said. GTE has 1,300 management employees working seven-day, 12-hour shifts, Gainer said. It also is bringing in 350 management employees from California and 100 retirees to help out, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Reject Investors' Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Creditors of Allegheny International Inc. have defeated a New York investment firm's plan for putting the small-appliance maker back on its feet. That means U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Joseph L. Cosetti will proceed with a June 28 hearing on the company's reorganization plan, despite pleas from the firm, Japonica Partners, and bank creditors who want more time to settle their differences and come up with a plan that can be approved. Japonica, which has purchased millions of dollars of the company's creditor claims, told Cosetti that creditors had rejected its $661 million reorganization plan. The plan was approved overwhelmingly by the classes of creditors Japonica holds controlling interest in _ unsecured creditors and subordinated debtholders. But opposition from bank creditors and common stockholders was enough to derail the plan. Joy Flowers Conti, a lawyer representing the banks, said proceeding with Allegheny International's $687 million plan will spark extensive litigation among the company, Japonica and creditor groups. But Cosetti said Thursday that allowing Japonica and the banks more time to negotiate a settlement would only delay the day it emerges from bankruptcy. Allegheny International, the maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code in February 1988. Eight of its reorganization plans have been scuttled.

DOC.HEAD: Philip Morris To Acquire Suchard
DOC.NOTE: EDS: grafs 2 NEW to UPDATE with Zurich stock exchange considering insider trading investigation, uppicks 2nd graf pvs: The combination
DOC.TEXT: Philip Morris Cos. will acquire the Swiss coffee and chocolate giant Jacobs Suchard AG in a deal valued at about $3.8 billion, the companies announced today. Separately, the Zurich Stock Exchange is considering opening an insider trading investigation involving Suchard stock. Press reports outlining the deal circulated Thursday while the market was still open. A spokesman for Suchard said the board has begun its own investigation into the possibility that information may have been leaked. The combination, which will link Suchard with Philip Morris's Kraft General Foods International unit, will create one of the largest coffee and confectionery companies in the world. Under the agreement announced in Zurich, Philip Morris will acquire Colima Holding AG, which holds a 60 percent stake in Suchard. Colima is owned by Suchard Chairman and Chief Executive Klaus Jacobs, whose stake in Suchard has been valued at about $1.4 billion at current exchange rates. Philip Morris, through Colima, would then launch a cash tender offer for all the publicly traded Suchard shares. The Suchard board has recommended shareholders accept the offer. Not included are certain assets that the Suchard board has agreed to sell to Jacobs. Those assets are described by the companies as ``not completely (fitting) in the new structure.'' They include Suchard's Canadian subsidiary, its E.J. Brach Inc. candy subsidiary, its industrial chocolate business and equity interests in certain foreign banks. ``This is a major opportunity for all of the parties _ consumers, customers and employees _ to build one of the best global coffee and confectonery business,'' said Jacobs, who will continue as Suchard's chairman but not its chief executive. Philip Morris spokeswoman Alice McGillion said Suchard would operate as a separate company within Kraft General Foods International. Last year Kraft General Foods International's revenues from European operations topped $3 billion. The Suchard acquisiton ``will permit us to more effectively compete throughout Europe with excellent brands and broad distribution and manufacturing capabilities,'' said Hamish Maxwell, chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, the tobacco and foods conglomerate. Rumors that Suchard was a takeover target have been circulating for weeks on the Swiss stock market, where Suchard shares have been pushed higher in active trading. Details of the deal surfaced Thursday in an article that appeared today in the Swiss weekly financial newspaper Cash. According to Cash, Klaus Jacobs had amassed a personal debt of nearly $500 million since he bought out his siblings' interests in the company last year. In addition, the company has experienced management and marketing difficulties at its Brachs unit, which ran up an operating loss of $50 million in 1989. The loss at the U.S. unit weighed on Suchard's group profit, which fell 10 percent last year to $194.6 million on sales of $4.7 billion. In addition, Suchard confirmed in April that it was considering slashing about 3,000 jobs _ or 19 percent of its work force in an effort to cut costs. At a press conference in April, Klaus Jacobs disclosed that the company was searching for possible alliances to help accelerate its plans to expand in various markets. He declined to identify any potential partners. Both he and analysts have predicted substantial improvement in the company's profit picture this year, and the Brachs unit is expected to break even. Among Suchard's prominent confectionery products are Tobler, Toblerone, Cote d'Or, Milka, Suchard and Night and Day coffee. The alliance with Philip Morris is expected to provide stiffer competition for Suchard's main competitors _ Nestle SA and Britain's Cadbury Schweppes. Jack Keenan, president of Kraft General Foods International, said he hoped ``currenct Jacobs Suchard managers will remain to participate in the global expansion of the combined businesses.'' Philip Morris, with 157,000 employees worldwide, makes Maxwell House coffee, Miller beer, Jello-O, Oscar Mayer processed meats and Kraft cheeses, mayonnaise and salad dressings. In addition, Philip Morris holds 7.5 percent of the world cigarette market. Headquartered in New York, Philip Morris reported a $2.9 billion profit last year on operating revenues of $44.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Growing Global Food Market Poses Challenges to U.S. Producers
DOC.TEXT: Technology has been a major reason for the United States' success in the world agriculture market, but this country risks losing its prominence, experts said at a conference. ``The day has passed when American agriculture had a lock on the world marketplace for food,'' U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. He joined international food experts, scholars and businessmen in Indianapolis in April to discuss global food trends during the 1990s at a conference sponsored by the conservative think tank Hudson Institute. The United States held 35 percent of the value of world trade in bulk agriculture commodities in 1988, Yeutter said, but in intermediate products such as flours and vegetable fats, the U.S. share dropped to 18 percent. Among consumer-oriented agriculture products, such as processed fruits, cut flowers and bakery products, American farmers have less than a 6 percent stake. In the past year Eastern Europe has begun moving toward free market systems. That won't help American farmers, but it may be a windfall for food processors, one analyst said. Richard Judy, a Soviet specialist at the Hudson Institute, said there will be a demand for companies involved in food processing and marketing. One of them is Central Soya, based in Fort Wayne. Since January it has formed joint ventures with Hungary's state-owned agribusiness concern to produce livestock feed and with a Yugoslavian company to produce soybean concentrates used in meat processing. Bioprocessing represents another opportunity. Genetically engineered microorganisms will be used to produce food, fuel, industrial feedstocks and commodity chemicals from corn, sugar cane and other crops, said John R. Campbell, president of Oklahoma State University. However, such products may meet resistance, including consumer fears. ``Technology has been one of the major reasons for the success in American agriculture,'' said John Urbanchek, a senior vice president for economics in the Washington office of the consulting firm Hill and Knowlton Inc. ``The problem is that the contribution of current technology is being rapidly exhausted and must be replaced if the U.S. is to retain its prominence as an agricultural producer and exporter, and to continue to supply American consumers with high-quality, safe and reasonably priced food,'' he said. Duane Acker, a former agriculture official with the U.S. Agency for International Development, said this country's system of research and farm extension once was the envy of the world, accounting for an estimated 75 percent of the public funds invested in that area. Today, estimates place that figure at 25 percent or less, Acker said. ``Though we continue to brag about our excellent system, we no longer have a corner on knowledge or technology,'' said Acker, now an administrator at the U.S. Department of Agriculture. To help the United States attain a ``globally oriented and internationally competitive'' agriculture system by the year 2000, Acker called for investment in agriculture research, links with gene banks and research institutions around the world, and U.S. investment in developing countries.

DOC.HEAD: Luxury Car Maker Rocked By Financial, Legal Woes
DOC.TEXT: Excalibur Automobile Corp., manufacturer of neoclassic automobiles fancied by wealthy collectors, has suspended production after being rocked by layoffs, lawsuits, bounced paychecks and allegations of mileage tampering. The suburban Milwaukee company, whose cars feature a minimum price tag of $75,000, hopes the restructuring will raise enough capital to move forward with a planned venture in Japan. ``Almost everybody likes to be part of Excalibur and the cars and the lifestyle image,'' said Scott Dennison, who took over as president June 1 after the resignation of Henry A. Warner. ``If we could build 120 cars a year, we could be profitable. We're really not in the car business, we're in the toy business,'' Dennison said. The company has been producing its 1930s-style cars at a rate of just one per week since January and has a backlog of 76 vehicles. Employees, incensed by unpaid wages, about 40 layoffs and allegations the company used old parts in new cars, picketed the company this week, threatening to set back any rebound by the 27-year-old company. Only five of the company's 45 workers remain on staff after the layoffs this month. ``We've used up just about all the tolerance we had,'' said Dan Neilson, a laid-off technician and one o the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet Union has been staunchly opposed. West Germany now is a mainstay of NATO and East Germany is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Shevardnadze said the Soviet proposal seeks to limit the strength of the German armed forces and ``to revamp their structure to make sure that they are rendered incapable for offensive operations.'' It said those reductions could be undertaken over a three-year period. Germany also would be prevented from producing or deploying chemmical or nuclear weapons. It also said that within six months of unification, all Western troops should leave West Berlin, which remains technically under military occupation by the United States, France and Britian. The four nations would reduce their military forces in the country during a three-year period following unification first by 50 percent, then ``bring them down to a level of token contingents, or completely withdraw them from Germany.'' There are about 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany, while a quarter-million U.S. troops are stationed in West Germany along with tens of thousands of British and French soldiers. Previously, the Soviets had said their troops would stay in what is now East Germany for several years, but had left unclear the exact plans for pulling them out. Shevardnadze, speaking earlier at a ceremony for the removal of the Western Allies' Checkpoint Charlie, said he wanted the Big Four Powers' troops out of ``greater Berlin'' within six months after unification. The proposal, as translated into English by the Soviets and distributed to the news media, apparently would also include the Kremlin's soldiers stationed just outside the city proper. The United States, France and Great Britain have an estimated 12,000 troops in West Berlin. An official reached by telephone in the office of the military attache at the Soviet embassy in East Berlin said there were no Soviet troops stationed in the city proper.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip; Drier Weather Forecasts Cited
DOC.TEXT: Crop futures prices closed moderately lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as forecasts for drier weather in the Midwest prompted some profit-taking after strong gains during the week. Drier conditions would allow farmers to finish soybean planting, which has been delayed by excessive rain in some of the most productive soybean regions, notably parts of Illinois and Missouri. The general perception among traders, though, is that crop conditions overall are improving, analysts said. William Biedermann, research director with the futures brokerage Allendale Inc., said Friday's selling was led by speculators and commodity investment funds. But he said the corn and soybean markets were underpinned by strong support among grain handlers. At the close, wheat futures prices were 4\ cents lower to { cent higher with July at $3.34 a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 4} cents lower with July at $2.82 a bushel; oats were 5 cents to 6\ cents lower with July at $1.34{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 7 cents lower with July at $6 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Roadside Pizza Man: If They Try It, They'll Like It
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto AT1 of June 18
DOC.TEXT: Take a ride around Austin these days and you're likely to spot a bunch of college students tossing white towels in the air. No, it's not some fraternity or sorority prank. They're imitating pizza-dough tossing to help generate business for HWY Pizza, a fledgling company that takes carry-out to new heights of convenience. Without ever leaving their cars, motorists can buy ready-to-bake pizzas for $4.95 from one of 11 roadside carts. Businessman Kerry Wood, 37, started the business with about $40,000 in late 1988, after first having the idea researched by University of Texas graduate students. But Wood said he already had a pretty good idea about the people who would buy many of his pizzas: working women between the ages of 24 and 49, with children. ``I think we knew this prior to the study that it was real attractive to working mothers because of the convenience of picking it up, and the fact that they're doing it (cooking) at home and the children like to help make it,'' said Wood, a Lima, Ohio, native. ``It's a lot of fun for them to make it. It becomes their dinner, and a way to help mom out,'' he said. Wood said he gets calls almost every day from customers praising the time-saving product. The basic pizza kit includes a 14-inch crust in an oven-ready, disposable pan, tomato sauce and cheese. Each extra ingredient _ pepperoni, black and green olives, jalapenos, mushrooms, Canadian bacon, hamburger and Italian sausage _ is 50 cents. One pizza will ``feed a husband, wife and two small children,'' Wood said. Wood estimates that about 110,000 pizzas have been sold since the business opened about 18 months ago. His pizza carts are open from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m. seven days a week. Wood said he plans to open a 12th cart in July, and eventually expand his business statewide. He's also hoping for a nationwide franchise in about 10 years. ``I think it would work well in the Northern states, more so than in Austin, because you're taking it home and you're cooking it yourself,'' he said. ``A lot of times, (Austin residents) just don't want to fire up the oven when it's 100 degrees outside.'' For now, the biggest problem Wood seems to face is getting people to try his pizza. He's had limited success with radio, television and billboard ads. The curb-side towel-throwing gimmick, while cute, didn't always work, especially when the tossers sometimes drop them on the pavement. ``(Customers) thought we were making them out on the street,'' Wood said. ``They have a tendency to think we might be making them in the back of our garage instead of in a health-approved commissary under the conditions that we have. ``We make them fresh every day, handmade. It's the freshest product that you can sell to the public.'' Wood said he solved the mistaken identity problem by bordering the ``phony dough'' towels in red.

DOC.HEAD: Court Reinstates Suit Against Oil Firms
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court today reinstated a potential multibillion-dollar lawsuit by the states of California, Arizona, Oregon and Washington that accuses oil companies of conspiring to fix prices and contrive a gasoline shortage in the early 1970s. The suit against seven major companies was dismissed in 1986 by U.S. District Judge William Gray of Los Angeles, who said the states had failed to present evidence of a conspiracy in violation of antitrust laws. But the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 3-0 decision, said today that evidence of information exchanges and parallel actions by the companies would allow a jury to find that a conspiracy existed. The ruling, if it stands, would send the case to trial. Robert Mittelstaedt, a lawyer for Chevron Corp., said no decision had been reached yet on whether to appeal. Expressing surprise at the ruling, Mittelstaedt said, ``We fully expect to win at trial, if it comes to that.'' The case is separate from another antitrust lawsuit by California that accuses six major oil companies of conspiring to depress the price of oil they pumped from state-owned tidelands in Long Beach. Gray's dismissal of that suit was also overturned by the appeals court, and a trial is scheduled for November.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Shareholders Give Final OK to Georgia-Pacific Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. shareholders gave formal approval Friday to a $5 billion takeover by Georgia-Pacific Corp., creating the nation's largest paper and forest products company. Shareholders of Norwalk, Conn.-based Great Northern cast the votes at a special meeting in Georgia-Pacific's hometown of Atlanta. Vote totals were not immediately released, although Georgia-Pacific said previously it controlled enough shares to ensure easy approval of the merger. The $65.75-a-share cash tender for the Great Northern shares was completed in March, giving Georgia-Pacific ownership of 96 percent of the company. A Georgia-Pacific spokeswoman said the merger, under which Great Northern will become a wholly owned subsidiary of G-P, is expected to take effect when merger documents are filed next week in Maine and Delaware. Great Northern is incorporated in Maine, and NM Acquisition Corp., the Georgia-Pacific subsidiary formed to handle the takeover, is incorporated in Delaware. Also expected to be completed next week is a commitment for a $4 billion revolving credit and term loan from a syndicate of 25 banks, part of a plan to pay for the debt associated with the takeover and provide working capital, said Georgia-Pacific spokeswoman Sheila Weidman. Friday's vote put a quiet stamp of approval on a merger that for nearly four months, beginning last Halloween, generated acrimony and lawsuits between the companies, state officials and conservationists. Great Northern officials accused Georgia-Pacific of lying about its intentions and said the Atlanta company would quickly sell off its woodlands and mills. Great Northern also charged the merger would violate federal antitrust laws. Georgia-Pacific ran full-page advertisements in newspapers accusing Great Northern's board of directors of selfishness for refusing to negotiate a deal. The angry rhetoric subsided Feb. 20, when the two companies jointly announced plans for the merger. William R. Laidig, who as chairman of Great Northern led the fight against the takeover, later stepped down. The new company has operations in every state except Alaska.

DOC.HEAD: Another Sign of the Times: Coniston Disbands
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Coniston Partners, one of the most prominent takeover strategists of the 1980s, said Friday it is closing up shop in response to the shrinking market for mergers and acquisitions. But the three men who led the investor group aren't going out of business. They're restructuring their operation to reflect the changing times. ``We're realistic,'' said Paul E. Tierney Jr., one of the three founding partners of Coniston. ``We're trying to adapt our investment policy to what we believe to be the current market environment and we think it's changed a lot.'' In its heyday, Coniston's biggest targets included Gillette Co., Allegis Corp. and TW Services Inc. Coniston said it was disbanding the $700 million investment pool it used to fund its takeover bids and proxy fights because of the scarcity of financing and suitable target companies. Most of the money will be returned to Coniston's investors. The trio will continue its investment in UAL Corp., the successor to Allegis, and its ownership of TW Services, the food service company whose operations include the Denny's restaurant chain. Tierney and his partners, Augustus K. Oliver and Keith R. Gollust, said they would secure financing for future deals on a case-by-case basis. Disbanding Coniston relieves the partners of their responsibilities to investors, which have become more difficult to fulfill with the changes in the takeover market, Tierney said. He noted Coniston had a 40 percent rate of return before the general partners' interests were subtracted _ ``a very difficult rate of return to achieve and sustain with the way the market is going.'' The trio plans to continue looking for acquisitions, but may move into areas such as real estate and foreign companies, where they have not been heavily invested, Tierney said in an interview. They will also look for companies in bankruptcy or financial distress that need investors, and will be involved in arbitrage, the practice of selling a security in one market and buying it for less in another market to profit from the price difference. The demise of Coniston marks the latest retreat of the 1980s corporate raiders following the collapse of the junk bond market last fall. The failure of the $6.7 billion buyout of Federated Department Stores Inc. by Campeau Corp. last September slowed takeover financing to a crawl and brought the merger boom to an end. Coincidentally, another big investor group, Shamrock Holdings Inc., also is shifting away from takeovers toward a different kind of venture. Shamrock, which failed in a 1988 hostile bid for Polaroid Corp., said it is forming a fund to help bail out companies that are faltering under heavy debt loads. News that Coniston was closing came on the same day that Philip Morris Cos. announced it would acquire the Swiss coffee and chocolate company Jacobs Suchard AG in a $3.8 billion deal. But there's no irony in that. The deals being done these days, including the Suchard acquisition, tend to be strategic moves by companies looking for expansion in a related industry. That was not the case with takeover strategists or corporate raiders like Coniston, who generally were investors seeking profits on their stock holdings. Tierney, Oliver and Gollust _ all Ivy League graduates _ formed Coniston in 1982 as the takeover boom was awakening. The partnership typically took a large stake in a target firm and pressured management to take actions to increase the price of the company's stock. One of its biggest successes came in 1987 at Allegis, the parent of United Airlines, the Hertz car rental company and two hotel chains. Armed with a 13 percent stake in the company, Coniston threatened a proxy fight and forced the Allegis board to fire Chairman Richard J. Ferris and shed all its assets except for United Airlines. Coniston came away with a $175 million profit. Allegis changed its name to UAL Corp. _ and the company's management eventually found itself again tussling with Coniston. The partnership is currently participating in a $4.38 billion plan by United Airlines employees to take UAL private. In 1988, Coniston lost a proxy fight for four seats on Gillette's board. The partnership and the company later reached an agreement under which Gillette bought back 16 million of its shares, giving Coniston a profit at least on paper. Last year, after a protracted fight, Coniston won control of TW Services.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Predicts Increase in Farm Real Estate
DOC.TEXT: Farm real estate values, including land and buildings, are forecast to rise 3 percent to 4 percent this year, the Agriculture Department said Friday. That would be near the 4 percent gain of 1989 and the fourth consecutive annual increase in farmland prices. The report by the department's Economic Research Service said the 1990 forecast reflects expectations of possible record net farm income, slightly lower inflation and recent changes in farmland values. Farm real estate prices averaged $693 per acre Jan. 1, up from $667 on Jan. 1, 1989. That was still far below the record of $823 per acre nationally in 1982, before land values tumbled.
