DOC.HEAD: First Bank System Ends Pursuit of Banks of Iowa
DOC.TEXT: Minneapolis-based First Bank Systems Inc. on Thursday terminated its planned acquisition of Banks of Iowa Inc., Iowa's biggest bank holding company, breaking off an 8{-year engagement. The courtship of Des Moines-based Banks of Iowa by First Bank had been at the center of an acrimonious debate over legalizing interstate banking in Iowa. Iowa's interstate banking law becomes effective in 1991. But Holmes Foster, chairman of Banks of Iowa, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting that the deal fell through because a weakened financial condition left First Bank System unable to obtain the necessary regulatory approval for the takeover. Foster said Banks of Iowa would begin discussions with other potential buyers, disclosing the institution already has been approached by three serious suitors. He did not identify the prospective purchasers and said there is no assurance any deal would be struck. Banks of Iowa stock fell 50 cents to $69.50 a share in national over-the-counter trading. First Bank System fell 25 cents to $14.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. First Bank System has assets of $20.2 billion and has 32 banks and trust companies with more than 140 offices in Minnesota, Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Washington and Wisconsin. Banks of Iowa has assets of $2.59 billion with 12 affiliate banks and a data processing company in Iowa. Under their December 1981 deal, First Bank agreed to pay 1.5 times Banks of Iowa's book value at the time the interstate banking law passed. At the time, First Bank also bought 550,000 shares of Banks of Iowa stock from a minority shareholder. Under the breakup agreement, Banks of Iowa will buy back the 550,000 shares for nearly $38 million, or $69 a share, pending regulatory approval. First Bank System said it expected a net gain of about $9.5 million on the sale of its stock and said the proceeds would be credited to a previously established reserve for its financial restructuring. The takeover agreement had been contingent on the approval of a law to allow interstate ownership and operation of banks. Minnesota authorized such deals in 1986. This year, after years of bitter legislative battles, Iowa passed an interstate banking law that will take effect at the beginning of 1991. The Iowa law allows interstate banking with institutions in adjoining states. But before the deal became legal, First Bank System ran into financial difficulties. Two years ago, First Bank System reported a $317 million loss as a result of a $497 million pre-tax loss on the sale of securities. In 1989, the company encountered loan problems. Foster told the shareholders meeting in Des Moines that even though First Bank System recently raised $175 million of new equity, neither company believed the Federal Reserve would allow completion of the deal or any other such transaction between the two ``either now or in the foreseeable future.'' Foster said the termination of the agreement will permit Banks of Iowa to pursue other deals with the help of The Chicago Corp., an investment banking firm.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Airways Orders $800 Million Worth Of 747-400s From Boeing
DOC.TEXT: Thai Airways International has ordered five more Boeing 747-400s in a deal worth about $800 million, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Thursday. The national airline of Thailand has now purchased eight of the jumbo jets, and two are in operation. So far this year, Boeing has announced orders for 219 jetliners worth nearly $18.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Industry Optimistic About Stock Index Futures Bill
DOC.TEXT: A securities industry group on Thursday stepped up its lobbying for passage of a Bush administration proposal to transfer regulatory authority for stock-index futures. Last month the Treasury Department unveiled legislation that would strip the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of its authority over stock index futures and give it to the Securities and Exchange Commission. ``I think right now it's a toss-up. A week ago I'd say we were a decided underdog,'' said Joseph R. Hardiman, president and chief executive of the National Association of Securities Dealers. ``Give us more time and I think we'll prevail.'' The NASD is part of an ad hoc Coalition for Intermarket Coordination that has been meeting with senators to push for passage of the amendement. Other members include: the American Stock Exchange, the Boston Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board of Options Exchange, the Pacific Stock Exchange and the National Securities Clearing Corp. ``Our position is getting stronger with every day,'' Hardiman said. ``If you'd asked us a week ago we would have said `Heavens don't let them take a vote now!' Today we're saying things are looking a lot better because we've had an opportunity to tell our story and the more people we tell it to the more ears we get that are willing to listen.'' In a joint interview with Nicholas A. Giordano, president of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, and Wayne Luthringshausen, chairman of Options Clearing Corp., Hardiman said members of the group had spoken with 25 to 30 senators. ``I think there's a lot of undecided votes,'' said Luthringshausen, the coalition's chairman.

The administration and the SEC said the index futures measure is necessary to best regulate the securities, which some critics hold responsible for sharp rises and drops in market prices. The proposal also would give the SEC authority to oversee stock index futures margins, the down payment required of investors who buy the securities on credit. The commodity futures exchanges currently set those margins, which are generally much lower than those for securities. The SEC and Treasury have said low stock index futures margins partly were to blame for the 1987 stock market crash and the 190-point market drop last October. Stock index futures allow investors to speculate on movements in the stock market without buying the underlying stock. The administration proposal, strongly opposed by the futures industry and the CFTC, was introduced as a separate bill in the House but will be included in CFTC market reform legislation which has been pending since last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against most major currencies Friday, with most activity centered on the sale of Canadian dollars as the deadline approached for Canada to approve controversial constitutional accord. Gold declined domestically and overseas. The U.S. dollar gained against the Canadian dollar in New York trading as the midnight Saturday deadline approached for approval of the Meech Lake accord. The agreement, which would recognize French-speaking Quebec as a ``distinct society,'' will expire if not approved by all 10 provinces by the deadline. There has been speculation that Quebec will try to separate from Canada if the accord is not approved. The approaching deadline has caused money to leave Canada, pushing the currency down against the dollar, said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer in Barclays Bank PLC's foreign exchange department in New York. Canada's central bank intervened in the market in an attempt to bolster the currency. The U.S. dollar late Friday rose to 1.1785 against the Canadian dollar compared with 1.1758 late Thursday in New York. Overall, however, currency trading was slow Friday. ``This market is still rather confused and without conviction,'' Hatcher said. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.4110 Swiss francs, down from 1.4135; 5.6215 French francs, down from 5.6265; 1,226.75 Italian lire, down from 1,228.25; and 1.6740 German marks, down from 1.6795. In London, the British pound jumped to $1.7330 from $1.7255 late Thursday. The pound was up at $1.7330 late in New York, compared with $1.7200 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates were: 1.6737 West German marks, down from 1.6795; 1.4085 Swiss francs, down from 1.4150; 5.6220 French francs, down from 5.6385; 1.8835 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8885; 1,227.25 Italian lire, down from 1,231.00; and 1.1816 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1748. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.15 yen to a closing 154.75 yen. Later, in London, it also was quoted at 154.75 yen and in New York it closed at 154.90 yen, up from 154.75 yen late Thursday. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery was off 30 cents a troy ounce to $350.40. Later, Republic National Bank in New York reported a late bid of $349.50 an ounce, 40 cents lower from Thursday. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $348.75 a troy ounce from $350.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $349.40 from $350.50 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 82 cents close at $350.83. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.83 a troy ounce from $4.84 bid late Thursday. In New York, silver for current delivery closed at $4.81 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, down from $4.82 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Up Slightly Due To Boost From Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Government bond prices rose marginally Friday in sluggish trading due to a last-minute drop in the stock markets. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond rose [ point, or $1.25 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 8.47 percent from 8.49 percent late Thursday. The bond market had little reaction to a series of government economic reports, traders said. The Commerce Department reported that personal income edged up 0.3 percent in May and personal spending was unchanged from April. The department later reported a 3.9 percent increase in durable goods orders to U.S. factories in May. The two reports seemed to cancel each other out, said Elizabeth Reiners, a bond market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The durable goods report showed a strong industrial sector, but that was offset by weaker-than-expected personal consumption data, she said. Bond prices moved in a tight range Friday until late afternoon, when stock prices on Wall Street plummeted in the last half-hour of trading on those markets, said James Marshall, a government securities trader at Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago. ``That caused the short end especially _ but the whole Treasury (security) market _ to end up on the plus side,'' he said. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks, up more than 10 points earlier in the day, dropped by 44.55 at 2,857.18 by the close. Computer-driven program selling was blamed for the drop. Marshall said investors typically flock to short-term Treasury securities, such as two- and three-year notes, when stock prices plummet. Treasury securities are regarded as a liquid, safe investment. Prices of the short-term governments were up from 1-32 point to 3-32 point, intermediate maturities rose from 1-16 point to 3-32 point, and long-term issues were up [ point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.70 to 1,157.68. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 8.00 percent as the discount lost 1 basis point to move to 7.75 percent. Yields on six-month bills dropped to 8.02 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points to 7.62 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.08 percent as the discount dropped 2 basis points to 7.54 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds remained at 91 5-16 point. The average yield to maturity also was unchanged, at 7.54 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Memo Downplays Significance of Talks With Other Carriers
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines officials plan to meet representatives of at least two other carriers that have expressed interest in the troubled company, but Eastern played down the possibility of a merger or buyout. In a memorandum distributed to its employees Wednesday, Eastern said Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines have requested discussions and certain information about Eastern ``concerning the possibility of future business relationships.'' ``Sharing the appropriate information or meeting to find out what someone has in mind does not mean a merger or takeover, or that one is planned or imminent,'' the memo stated. ``It does not mean that Eastern is charting a course to relinquish our independence.'' The memo noted that Martin Shugrue, the airline's court-appointed trustee, ``must continue to evaluate all options while seeking to act in the best interests of Eastern, our employees, creditors and the traveling public.'' Eastern spokesman Robin Matell declined to elaborate on the planned talks or what information the carriers requested. Both Pan Am and Northwest have acknowledged publicly they are looking for possible mergers or acquisitions. Eastern is attempting to reorganize under Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection. It filed for protection on March 9, 1989, five days after a crippling strike by Machinists, flight attendants and pilots. Eastern recently sold its Latin American routes to American Airlines for $310 million but still is negotiating final points of the deal. American contends an Eastern hangar at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport is in worse condition that Eastern claimed. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland has given the two carriers until Aug. 15 to reach an agreement. Eastern had agreed to place $7.2 million in an escrow fund to pay for cleaning up the terminal, but the two carriers now disagree about whether the amount should be a cap for the repairs.

DOC.HEAD: Machine Tool Maker to Offer 3 Million Shares
DOC.TEXT: Cincinnati Milacron Inc. says it plans an offering of 3 million shares of common stock at $18 a share. Of that total, 2.4 million will be offered in the United States by a syndicate headed by First Boston Corp., Milacron said Thursday. The remainder will be offered internationally by underwriters headed by Credit Suisse First Boston. The company has 24.4 million shares outstanding. Cincinnati Milacron reported 1989 sales of $851 million. It is a leading maker of machine tools, robotics, grinding wheels and metalworking fluids.

DOC.HEAD: Report: UAL Unions Wooing Boeing, GE
DOC.TEXT: The unions seeking to buy out the parent of United Airlines reportedly are trying to persuade Boeing Co. and General Electric Co. _ two of United's chief equipment suppliers _ to invest in the takeover. United Employees Acquisition Corp., the entity formed by the unions to handle the acquisition, is seeking either a cash or debt investment from Boeing and GE, the Wall Street Journal reported Thursday. In return, the companies would receive either preferred stock or a note in UAL Corp., the Chicago-based parent of United, but no common stock. The newspaper, citing unidentified union officials, said the labor group also discussed giving Boeing and GE preferred-supplier status if they join in the $4.58 billion buyout. UAL stock settled up 50 cents Thursday at $156.50, well below the $200-a-share offer by the employee group. Steven Mathews, a spokesman for the unions, refused to comment Thursday on the report. Bruce Bunch, a spokesman for General Electric, also refused to comment. Telephone calls to Seattle-based Boeing were not returned. Both Boeing, the world's biggest maker of commercial aircraft, and GE, a maker of jet engines and electronic equipment used in airliners, have a long-term relationship with United. United has announced intentions to order about $15 billion in new aircraft, a contract Boeing is seeking. General Electric is competing with other engine manufacturers to provide engines for some of the aircraft being considered. An investment by either company could reduce the buyout group's dependency on bank financing. The labor group has until Aug. 9 to secure financing for a takeover. The group recently hired former Chrysler Corp. vice chairman Gerald Greenwald to direct the search for financing.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Bellies Seen Heading Lower After Supply Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf, `West Texas ...,' to CORRECT changes in West Texas Intermediate oil to cents sted fractions of a cent.
DOC.TEXT: Pork belly futures, which have taken a severe beating in the past two weeks, are expected to fall even further after a government report Friday showed a greater supply than the market had expected. But analysts said the report would quickly be overshadowed by the Agriculture Department's quarterly hogs and pigs tally, which is due out next Friday. In trading Friday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, frozen pork belly futures fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound for the fifth time in the last seven trading sessions. On other commodity markets, energy futures rose; grains and soybeans were lower; orange juice advanced; and precious metals retreated. Frozen pork bellies settled .95 cent to 2 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at 59.40 cents a pound, the first close below 60 cents since April 18. In livestock trading, hog futures ended .15 cent lower to .78 cent higher with August at 57.95 cents a pound; live cattle were .30 cent to .78 cent lower with August at 73.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .67 cent lower with August at 84.75 cents a pound. A pork belly is the part of a hog from which bacon is made. Slack demand for pork has weighed heavily on hog and belly futures for the last two weeks, and the USDA's monthly cold-storage report Friday offered no support. The report, which was released after the close, showed 105.5 million pounds of bellies in the nation's commercial freezers as of May 31, nearly 3 million pounds above market expectations. The number was 26 percent below the year-ago level and about 7 percent higher than the 10-year average, said Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in Chicago. Analysts predicted another limit drop in belly futures Monday but said traders are likely to then turn their attention to the upcoming hogs-and-pigs report. ``The big thing's coming down the pike a week from today,'' said analyst Dale Durchholz of AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill. Levitt estimated the report will show a 1 percent decline in the U.S. hog herd since last year. But he said it also likely will show an increase in farrowing intentions, meaning that beginning this summer the number of hogs being born will be larger than a year ago. ``That is more negative to the longer term situation in the market than anything a monthly cold-storage report could show,'' Levitt said. Crude oil futures made their strongest advance since June 12 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, boosted by technical factors. Once the August crude contract pushed above the $17.30-a-barrel barrier, the market ``just jerked'' higher, said analyst James Steel at Refco Inc. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 25 cents to 52 cents higher with August at $17.46 a barrel; heating oil was .75 cent to .99 cent higher with July at 48.66 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent to 1.35 cents higher with July at 61.37 cents a gallon. Crop futures fell moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade as forecasts for beneficial dry weather in the Midwest prompted profit-taking after strong gains during the week. Wheat futures settled 4\ cents lower to } cent higher with July at $3.33} a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 4{ cents lower with July at $2.82 a bushel; oats were 5 cents to 6\ cents lower with July at $1.34{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 7 cents lower with July at $5.99{ a bushel. Orange juice futures continued to rebound from a recent sharp decline on the New York Cotton Exchange. Future deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice settled .45 cent to 4.75 cents higher with July at $1.839 a pound. Precious metals were little changed on New York's Commodity Exchange, where gold settled 30 cent to 50 cents lower with June at $350.40 a troy ounce; and silver was 1.1 cents to 1.3 cents lower with June at $4.813 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Quaker Oats Reorganizes In Anticipation of Flat Sales Year
DOC.TEXT: Quaker Oats Co., anticipating poor sales and earnings in its current fiscal year, said Friday it will lay off hundreds of workers and reorganize the management of its largest division, U.S. grocery products. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer William D. Smithburg said in a statement that the Chicago-based company expected flat or slightly lower sales and earnings for the year ending June 30. Smithburg said several hundred positions will be eliminated during the next fiscal year. He did not say exactly how many or where the cuts will be made. The reorganization of the grocery products division involves a number of management changes. Smithburg also said he will become president and chief operating officer of Quaker in September, following the retirement of Frank J. Morgan, who currently holds those positions.

DOC.HEAD: Two Top Positions Filled at Bank of New England
DOC.TEXT: Leo R. Breitman has been promoted to vice chairman and senior credit policy officer of the financially troubled Bank of New England Corp., the bank said Friday. Breitman's former position as president of Bank of New England will be filled by D. Bruce Wheeler, executive vice president of First Nationwide Bank in California and a former Bank of Boston executive, according to a statement by the bank. As senior credit policy officer, Breitman will set credit policy for the corporation and its subsidiary banks. As president and chief operating officer of the bank unit, Wheeler will oversee corporate, commercial and retail banking and commercial real estate. Breitman, 49, has been president of the Connecticut Bank and Trust and was president and chief operating officer of Patriot Bank from 1985 to 1987. Wheeler, 43, was with Bank of Boston from 1982 to 1989. Prior to joining Bank of Boston, he was a general manager of Crocker National Bank's international banking subsidiary in New York City. Bank of New England Corp. is a Boston-based interstate bank holding company with assets of $25 billion and banking offices in four New England states. The bank, which lost more than $1 billion last year, has announced plans to streamline its operations through a combination of layoffs, attrition and sales of assets. Much of the bank's trouble has been blamed on shaky construction loans that were exposed with the recent downturn in the Northeast real estate market.

DOC.HEAD: Buyer Found For Troubled, Famous Furniture Maker
DOC.TEXT: A buyer was found Friday for Kittinger Co., less than a month before the famous furniture maker was to have auctioned off its equipment and closed. Kittinger, which once made furniture for the White House and Colonial Williamsburg, was sold to Pittsburgh businessman Michael Carlow, its parent firm, Ladd Furniture Inc. of High Point, N.C., said in a news release. Ladd, which has owned Kittinger since July 1989, had said in February it planned to close Kittinger because it had been unable to find a buyer. David Ogren, Kittinger's president, could not be reached for comment. There was no answer at his office telephone. Carlow has an unlisted telephone number in Pittsburgh. John Ong, a Ladd spokesman, said he could not elaborate on the news release, which described Carlow only as ``a prominent Pittsburgh businessman.'' He said the company would hold a news conference Monday in Buffalo. A day earlier, Kittinger announced it lost its 54-year-old contract with Colonial Williamsburg to make its licensed 18th-century furniture reproductions. Ogren said then that the contract accounted for $3 million of the company's $16 million in sales in 1989. ``We held on and we held on,'' said Richard Schreiber, the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation's vice president. ``Finally, it just comes to the point where it becomes quite apparent that the company is going to be shut down.'' Ong said he did not know whether the sale of Kittinger was closed before or after the cancellation of the Colonial Williamsburg contract. He said the loss of that contract would not affect the sale, but refused to comment on what effect it would have on the company's continued viability.

DOC.HEAD: First Case in Commodities Probe Heads to Jury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs to reflect jurors break without reaching a verdict, will reconvene Monday; picks up 4th graf pvs, `Mosky and.'
DOC.TEXT: An arrogant, young commodities broker devised ``the perfect scam'' to skim customer profits, a prosecutor said Friday as the first case in a sweeping probe of the world's largest commodities exchanges went to the jury. Robert Mosky, 34, facing fraud and racketeering charges, regularly and illegally circumvented the rules of trade at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Swiss franc futures pit, Assistant U.S. Attorney James P. Fleissner said during closing arguments. Jurors were unable to reach a verdict after deliberating two hours Friday afternoon. They will resume at 10:30 a.m. EDT Monday. Mosky and two other traders in the Swiss franc pit, Danny Scheck and David Zatz, were the first to stand trial in a lengthy FBI investigation of corruption at the Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade. In all, 48 people have been indicted and 16 already have pleaded guilty. Mosky was alleged by prosecutors to be the ringleader of a group of traders who routinely stole money from customers by trading schemes that prevented customer orders from being executed in the open market. ``It's the perfect scam,'' Fleissner told jurors who heard testimony in U.S. District Judge Ann C. William's courtroom for more than six weeks. ``You can do it _ and you can't get caught.'' Mosky, Scheck and Zatz were charged last August with more than a dozen counts each of mail or wire fraud, and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. Each count carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $150,000 fine. Mosky also was charged with racketeering conspiracy, which carries a maximum prison term of 20 years. He also could be forced to forfeit personal assets. The government alleged that the three men executed customer orders through pre-arranged or off-market trades instead of through open outcry. By doing so, prosecutors said, customers were denied the superior prices that would result from open competitive trading. The defendants were accused of shifting their personal losses from trading errors into their customers' accounts, then hiding their practices by changing or destroying trading records. During closing arguments, Fleissner argued Mosky was arrogant and greedy. Once the undercover probe of the exchanges was revealed in January 1989, Fleissner said, Mosky told a colleague prosecution tape recordings were probably worthless and bragged, ``If no one talks, they've got no tapes.'' But in closing arguments Thursday, Mosky's attorney, Elliot Samuels, said his client had been scape-goated by over-eager prosecutors trying to enforce ambiguous commodities trading rules. ``If they're not happy with the damn rules, let them go to Washington and get Congress to change it _ but don't put Bob Mosky in jail because of it,'' Samuels said. His concluding remarks differed considerably from those made by the attorneys of Scheck and Zatz, who instead attacked the credibility of government witnesses, including that of FBI agent Randall Jannett, who posed undercover as a corrupt trader. But Fleissner said Jannett was ``no bumpkin.'' ``Did Agent Jannett make mistakes?'' Fleissner asked rhetorically. ``There were mistakes. ``But you go back and count those mistakes up _ see how far you get on your second hand,'' he instructed the jury.

DOC.HEAD: As Default Draws Near, Bankruptcy Could Be Next For Trump
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with movement by banks. No pickup. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: A syndicate of banks Friday began to soften its opposition to a $65 million loan and restructuring plan that would help Donald Trump avert default on a casino bond issue. However, a final agreement on the plan, which would suspend some payments on bank loans in return for equity in some of Trump's properties, still had not been reached. A group of four banks _ three Japanese and one German institution with a combined $75 million loan to Trump secured by Trump Tower _ had opposed the restructuring because it would put a new lien on the Fifth Avenue skyscraper. The four banks are Sumitomo Bank, Mitsubishi Bank and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan and the Dresdner Bank of Germany. They reportedly don't like the idea of someone else having a claim to property that secures their loans. On Friday, some of the Japanese banks began to acquiesce, said a banking source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The foreign banks are tied into a large network of lenders to Trump, led by Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust and Manufacturers Hanover, that pressed Trump to restructure his finances after he asked for a fresh loan to cover the bond payment. The payment was due last week on bonds issued to finance the Trump Castle hotel and casino in Atlantic City, N.J. Under a grace period, he has until midnight Tuesday to make the $43 million payment. Trump issued a statement Friday afternoon confirming there had been progress. ``An overwhelming number of participating lenders, representing both national and international financial institutions, have now joined the major banks in supporting our plan,'' Trump said in a prepared statement. ``I am confident that the handful of remaining banks will choose to join us to get this restructuring deal put together,'' he said. Trump has until midnight Tuesday to finalize the plan or the banks could move to seize his assets. A 10-day grace period started after he failed to make the initial June 15 midnight due date. If he defaults, bankruptcy court could become the most attractive building in Manhattan to the struggling developer.Failing to make the payment on the Trump Castle bonds could trigger defaults on bank loans secured by other properties that could be seized, said analysts. If faced with seizure by his bank lenders, whom he owes about $2 billion, bankruptcy court could provide Trump with time to avoid a foreclosure and get a better price by selling assets in an orderly fashion. ``He could risk losing everything now, or retain things to sell'' under bankruptcy, one analyst said. If the banks took a property, they could get a bargain if the market value of the property exceeds the balance of outstanding loans against it, analysts said. There is some risk for the banks, who may not want to take on real estate in the slumping New York market. They may fare better by loaning Trump enough money to get him through his cash crisis and look at selling properties when Manhattan real estate prices recover. While it is possible Trump would take all his properties into bankruptcy court, it is more likely that he would only need to protect those to which the banks could lay claim. The bond obligations on Trump's two other Atlantic City hotel-casinos, the Trump Plaza and the Taj Mahal, protect them from defaulting domino-style after a Trump Castle default. However, the terms of the bank loans are not public like bond agreements, so there is no way of knowing for certain which have the commonly-used cross-default clauses. Even if the foreign bank problem is solved, paperwork on the compex deal probably couldn't be completed before the deadline, one individual involved in the talks said. If all sides agree to the restructuring and loan, it is likely a short-term loan could be arranged to help him make his payment, the individual said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Trump cannot negotiate an extension of the bond payment deadline, said Paul Levine, spokesman for First Fidelity Bank in Newark, N.J., trustee for the bonds. The language in the bond agreements allows for no extension after the 10-day grace period, he said. Trump has raised some cash through asset sales recently. On Thursday he announced he sold a shipyard near Amsterdam in the Netherlands. New York Newsday reported last month that he paid $5 million for the shipyard to make sure work was completed on a 420-foot yacht being built for him. Through a spokesman, Trump said he made a substantial profit on the sale, but would not disclose the price.

Philip Morris Cos. said it would acquire Swiss coffee and candy conglomerate Jacobs Suchard AG in a $3.8 billion deal creating the third-largest food company in Europe. The combined company, linking Suchard with Philip Morris's Kraft General Foods International unit, would have annual revenues of $6.7 billion and a broad reach across the growing European consumer market. Only Nestle SA and Unilever NV would be larger. The deal, announced Friday, could also produce an insider trading investigation, Swiss officials said.

A syndicate of banks began to soften its opposition to a $65 million loan and restructuring plan that would help Donald Trump avert default on a casino bond issue. However, a final agreement on the plan, which would suspend some payments on bank loans in return for equity in some of his properties, still had not been reached, a banking source said Friday. A group of four banks _ three Japanese and one German institution with a combined $75 million loan to Trump secured by Trump Tower _ had opposed the new loan and restructuring because it would put a new lien on the Fifth Avenue skyscraper.

President Bush said he wants to double spending to pursue savings and loan fraud, but Democrats said the proposal was too little too late. Bush's proposal Friday also would establish ``rapid response teams'' and name a Justice Department official to direct the effort. Democrats said they found little new in the plan and called it an admission that past anti-fraud efforts had failed. The program would double spending for Justice Department and Internal Revenue Service investigators and prosecutors to $100 million in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1.

The two Germanys, for 40 years the most visible symbol of the Cold War divide, took their biggest step toward unification by reaching final agreement on economic merger. In East Berlin on Friday, representatives of the World War II victors and vanquished gathered to discuss German unity, and one of the most notorious markers of East-West conflict _ Checkpoint Charlie _ was removed from the Berlin Wall.

Personal spending was flat in May, the government said in a report indicating growing caution among consumers who have been a major source of strength for the economy during seven years of growth. The Commerce Department said Friday that consumer spending remained unchanged at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.66 trillion after seven straight months of gains, including 0.5 percent in April and 0.3 percent in March.

Orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods jumped 3.9 percent in May, the government reported. Analysts said it was further evidence the economy's sluggish manufacturing sector may be bouncing back. The Commerce Department said Friday that orders for durable goods _ items such as automobiles and appliances expected to last at least three years _ totaled a seasonally adjusted $128.2 billion after falling 4.2 percent in April.

Lisa Jones, a teen-age runaway who became a $100,000-a-year trading assistant at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was sentenced to 10 months in prison for lying to a grand jury investigating Wall Street fraud. U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand on Friday reduced his original 18-month sentence after an appeals court threw out the term on grounds it was longer than mandated by federal sentencing guidelines. Jones, 27, was convicted last year of seven counts of perjury and obstruction of justice for lying in January 1988 to a federal grand jury investigating trading activities at Drexel.

Soviet oil exports dropped nearly 10 percent last year, according to figures provided by the CIA, raising concerns about domestic oil shortages and cuts in supply to Eastern Europe. The export drop reflected a decline in oil production caused by aging wells, labor unrest and bureaucratic chaos, U.S. officials said Friday. The Soviet Union exported 3.69 million barrels of oil a day in 1989, down from 4.08 million in 1988, according to the newly compiled CIA figures.

Coniston Partners, one of the most prominent takeover strategists of the 1980s, is closing up shop in response to the shrinking market for mergers and acquisitions. Coniston's biggest targets included Gillette Co., Allegis Corp. and TW Services Inc. Coniston said Friday it was disbanding the $700 million investment pool it used to fund its takeover bids and proxy fights because of the scarcity of financing and suitable target companies. Most of the money will be returned to Coniston's investors.

Computer-program selling overpowered an attempt to rally the stock market Friday, The Dow Jones industrial average fell 44.55 to 2,857.18. The dollar was mixed against most major currencies. Government bond prices rose marginally. Pork belly futures fell the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound; energy futures rose; grains and soybeans were lower; orange juice advanced; and precious metals retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell Withdraws Complaint Against Minolta
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. said Friday it will drop its week-old campaign to halt imports of autofocus cameras made by Minolta Camera Co. Honeywell said it was withdrawing its complaint before the International Trade Commission because an expedited trial date of Sept. 3, 1991, was set in a corresponding civil suit. But Minolta, the Japanese camera-maker, said Honeywell withdrew its ITC action because it is bound under contract to settle the dispute in court. Honeywell's autofocus patent infringement lawsuit has been pending for more than three years. When Honeywell announced June 14 it was asking the ITC to ban imports on Minolta Maxxum cameras and other models, the company said a trial was two years away. Honeywell said it was calling for the import ban in hopes of getting quicker relief. The Minneapolis-based company said it is unjustly losing millions of dollars in royalties while the case is being litigated. The lawsuit accuses Minolta of infringing on four Honeywell patents. The ITC action sought to ban imports of Maxxum cameras and others, including AF-Tele and Freedom Dual models. Honeywell contends that Minolta breached a 1979 contract calling for Honeywell to share patented technology and trade secrets. Minolta was restricted to using only Honeywell-made autofocus modules under the contract, Honeywell said. Instead, Honeywell alleges, Minolta used Honeywell autofocus technology while developing a module of its own. Minolta said Honeywell's patent claims are ``invalid and unenforceable.'' The Japanese company said its own autofocus innovation dates to the 1960s and is well documented by many U.S. patents. The suit seeks unspecified damages and a sales injunction. ``Honeywell's filing (with the ITC) was in clear violation of a prior court order,'' Minolta spokesman Michael Gross said. ``Their withdrawal was solely to avoid the consequences of this violation.'' Gross said a court hearing had been set for Monday in U.S. District Court in Newark, N.J., to challenge the ITC filing. He said Honeywell ``ran the risk of being formally ordered by the court to withdraw.'' Christopher J. Steffen, Honeywell vice president and chief financial officer, said the company was dropping its ITC action because it was ``very pleased that our case has been accelerated by more than one year.'' ``The fixed trial date will end Minolta's continued efforts to delay the court case, and will produce a decision in the same time frame as the ITC action,'' Steffen said. But Gross said it was Honeywell's legal maneuvering that prompted delays in the case. He said the September trial date came as no surprise to Minolta. ``We're very happy with the trial date,'' Gross said. ``We welcome Honeywell's decision to drop its ITC complaint and abide by its 1988 agreement to adjudicate this case in the federal court.''

DOC.HEAD: Roy Disney Investment Vehicle Forms `White Squire' Fund
DOC.TEXT: Shamrock Holdings, the private investment company headed by Walt Disney's nephew Roy Disney, has formed a partnership to bail out companies overburdened by debt, Shamrock's chief strategist said Friday. The $450 million fund raised money primarily from previous investors in Shamrock, the company that last year failed to acquire Polaroid Corp. after a long, highly publicized bid. Several such funds have emerged recently with the intent of rescuing companies that overleveraged themselves during the borrowing frenzy of the 1980s. ``It's all you're going to be seeing for the next two years,'' Shamrock's chief executive, Stanley P. Gold, said in a telephone interview. Shamrock's fund, Trefoil Capital Partners, is allowed to attempt hostile takeovers under the terms of the partnership. However, it is expected to concentrate on friendly, ``white knight'' deals. Shamrock takes a 1 percent fee for managing the partnership. A white knight is a third party that often acquires a stake in a company to help a takeover target avoid an unfriendly merger. ``We want to do three or four deals,'' Gold said. ``About $150 million to $250 million is the ideal.'' The partnership already has offered to provide capital for struggling companies, including Southland Corp. and Ames Department Stores. Both filed for protection from creditors in U.S. Bankruptcy Court. Shamrock also was interested in investing in Koor Inc., Israel's biggest conglomerate, which is struggling to service a $1.2 billion debt. That offer, basically a restructuring in which creditors would forgive some Koor debt, is typical of those Trefoil will make, Gold said. Trefoil said it would buy a stake in Koor with $100 million of new equity if the banks and bondholders would forgive half of their $1.2 billion in Koor debt. No deal has been worked out yet. ``They're trying to restructure their debt,'' Gold said. ``They may come back to us after they make some progress.'' At a time when junk bond and bank financing for big investors is hard to come by, the fund will provide Shamrock with a ready source of funds so it can move fast if it spots an attractive deal. Gold said the partnership expects to complete its first deal by the end of the year. Shamrock owns the Music Plus music and video stores in Southern California and the Sound Warehouse chain in Texas. It also owns 15 radio and three television stations, 15 percent of oil field equipment maker Enterra Corp., and has various real estate holdings. Trefoil is looking into deals in similar industries, officials said.
